{"uri": "8218472302", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "10:13:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T10:13:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T10:12:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/irish-woman-trapped-in-dubai-and-facing-charges-after-alleged-attack-in-her-home-in-a-living-nightmare/a142422227.html", "title": "Irish woman trapped in Dubai and facing charges after alleged attack in her home 'in a living nightmare'", "body": "The Taoiseach has said he is ready to intervene in the case of Irish woman Tori Towey who is facing criminal charges and has been banned from leaving Dubai in what he called \"the most appalling circumstances\".\n\nTori Towey (28) suffered severe bruising and other injuries that required hospital treatment after she was allegedly attacked in her home, according to Detained in Dubai.\n\nThe advocacy group has urged the Irish Government to intervene to have the charges against her dropped and allow her to travel home.\n\nMs Towey, who is from Boyle in Co Roscommon, is now facing charges \"of attempted suicide and the abuse of alcohol,\" the D\u00e1il heard today, and is desperate to come home.\n\nLocal Sinn F\u00e9in TD Claire Kerrane, who knows the family, told the Irish Independent:\n\n\"I spoke to Tori and her mother earlier today, along with my party leader Mary Lou McDonald.\n\n\"Tori is in a living nightmare. She must be allowed to return home urgently.\n\n\"This young woman has been treated in the most horrific way and simply wants to go home.\"\n\nSinn F\u00e9in leader Mary Lou McDonald told the D\u00e1il that Ms Towey had been the victim of domestic violence and is subject to a travel ban over alleged charges as she urged the Taoiseach to intervene.\n\nRadha Stirling, CEO of advocacy group Detained in Dubai, described the case and the travel ban against Ms Towey as \"outrageous\".\n\n\"Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive\", added Stirling, who has helped in numerous domestic violence cases including that of Dubai's Princess Latifa.\n\n\"The UAE used to charge rape victims with sex outside marriage. Now they're charging domestic violence victims with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\n\n\"We are calling on Dubai authorities to urgently drop the charges against Tori, remove the travel ban and let her fly home to Ireland with her mother.\n\n\"We are also calling on Ireland's prime minister Simon Harris, the head of Foreign Affairs Miche\u00e1l Martin, Ambassador Alison Milton and local TDs Michael Fitzmaurice, Claire Kerrane and Denis Naughten as well as the UAE's Ambassador to Ireland, HE Mohammed Hmoud Hamad Rahma Alshamsi to help bring Tori home.\"\n\nWhile speaking to RT\u00c9 Radio One's Morning Ireland, Ms Stirling has confirmed Ms Towey is currently living in an Airbnb.\n\n\"Right now, she's just happy to be with her mother in safety, because this is all very recent, but she is able to leave the apartment and move freely within the country,\" she said.\n\nMs Towey would like Taoiseach Simon Harris to speak to Ireland's counterparts in the UAE.\n\n\"Just simply say: 'We can't have this. This is obviously an error on behalf of the Dubai police. This never should have been charged or prosecuted'.\n\n\"And they need to be trained on victim care more than anything, and hopefully the Government of Dubai will see that these charges shouldn't happen and they need to protect women.\n\n\"It's terrible PR for the country. You're going to have people worried to go there in the future. And of course, this is on the back of historically charging rape victims with sex outside marriage so they don't have the best reputation to start with. They've been trying to improve it.\n\n\"So I think there'll be agreeable with the Irish government if there's enough diplomatic pressure put on them, letting them know that we absolutely want Tori home and there's just going to be no negotiation on that,\" she added.\n\nTori Towey is due to appear in court next week.\n\n\"In a best-case scenario, they will simply say: 'We're not going to proceed beyond this hearing- and we're going to let you go'.\n\n\"When it comes to a case like this, it's all about diplomacy. Without the support of the Irish government, she would be likely to face prison and charges and deportation.\n\n\"With the support of the Irish government and diplomacy and there has been a lot - various members of the Irish government have contacted UAE ambassador to Ireland, and of course, Ireland's ambassador in the UAE, and they're trying to get those diplomatic talks happening.\n\n\"If that happens, that is the best and fastest way to get her home,\" Ms Stirling added.\n\nThe 28-year-old Emirates Airlines cabin crew employee, now faces lengthy imprisonment in jails that are notorious for human rights abuses and torture, according to Detained in Dubai.\n\nMs Towey moved to Dubai in April 2023 for a job with Emirates.\n\nThe airline gave her time off work to recover after she suffered the injuries at her home, according to the human rights group.\n\nSinn F\u00e9in leader Mary Lou McDonald told the D\u00e1il she said she had spoken to Ms Towey and that her mother had travelled to Dubai to be with her.\n\n\"Tori wants to come home, simple as that. She is a Roscommon woman and she wants to come home,\" she said.\n\n\"I am asking now, as a matter of absolute urgency, that we have a statement from this House, that you intervene Taoiseach, that the ambassador is called and that it is made absolutely plain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way, and an Irish citizen, an Irish woman will not be treated in this way.\"\n\nMr Harris responded saying he was not aware of Ms Towey's case, and thanked Ms McDonald for bringing it to his attention and that of the Foreign Minister Miche\u00e1l Martin.\n\nHe pledged to work \"to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be, based on what you tell me, the most appalling circumstances\".\n\nLocal Sinn F\u00e9in TD Claire Kerrane, who knows Ms Towey's family, said the flight attendant was in a \"living nightmare\".\n\n\"I am determined to work with the ambassador, Foreign Affairs Minister and anyone necessary to ensure that her release is secured without delay,\" she told the Irish Independent.\n\nAccording to Detained in Dubai, Ms Towey found out there was a travel ban against her when replacing her passport, but wasn't sure why.\n\nShe arranged to fly home to Ireland but when she arrived at the airport, was told a case against her had been dropped but that the travel ban remained.\n\n\"She attended the police station who assured her the travel ban would be lifted but it never happened. She was stuck,\" said Ms Stirling.\n\nTori was told nothing could be done and that the cases against her were going to court on July 18, according to Detained in Dubai.\n\n\"The UAE has gone to great public relations efforts to promote alcohol as legal in the country. In reality, people are still regularly charged with alcohol consumption and possession,\" added Stirling.\n\nA spokesperson for the Department of Foreign Affairs confirmed it is aware of Ms Towey's situation.\n\n\"The Department of Foreign Affairs is aware of the case and is providing consular assistance.\n\n\"As with all consular cases, the department does not comment on the details of individual cases.\"", "source": {"uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Belfast Telegraph"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": She faces a lengthy jail sentence if convicted, according to advocacy group Detained in Dubai, which is assisting her family.\n\nMary Lou McDonald, the leader of opposition, told parliament that Ms Towey was \"under incredible stress\".\n\n\"Tori is a Roscommon woman and she wants to come home,\" the Sinn F\u00e9in leader said on Tuesday.\n\nIn response, the prime minister vowed to work with Ms McDonald \"to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be, based on what you tell me, the most appalling circumstances\".\n\n\"Thank you, deputy McDonald, for bringing the case of Tori to my attention,\" Mr Harris said, according to Irish broadcaster RTE. \"I am not directly appraised of the situation, but I'm very happy to be directly appraised of it now.\"\n\nMs McDonald described Ms Towey as \"the victim of the most gross domestic violence\" and said she was under extreme stress after her passport was \"destroyed\".\n\n\"There was a travel ban imposed on her and she had gone to the authorities seeking protection many times but to absolutely no avail,\" Ms McDonald told parliament.\n\n\"But following one particularly severe beating in which her husband repeatedly tried to slam doors on her arms and break her limbs, she escaped upstairs and she attempted to take her own life. Unfortunately Tori now faces charges in Dubai of attempted suicide and the abuse of alcohol. The system over there, rather than protecting this woman who is an Irish citizen, chose instead to detain her to charge her.\"\n\nThe foreign ministry told Sky News it was \"aware of the case and is providing consular assistance\" but declined to elaborate.\n\nClaire Kerrane, MP from Roscommon, said Ms Towy was \"living in a nightmare\" and must be allowed to return home urgently. \"Tori is a survivor of serious domestic abuse. She needs to be brought home.\"\n\nMs Towey moved to Dubai in April 2023 and has been staying in a rented property with her mother Caroline.\n\n\"We are calling on Dubai authorities to urgently drop the charges against Tori, remove the travel ban and let her fly home to Ireland with her mother,\" said Radha Stirling, the chief executive of Detained In Dubai. \"Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive.\"\n\nMs Towey's case will be heard in court on 18 July.", "source": {"uri": "independent.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Independent"}, {"uri": "8218715275", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:42:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:42:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:42:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/news/irish-news/tori-towey-case-dubai-update-33210620", "title": "Everything we know about the case of Irish woman Tori Towey detained in Dubai", "body": "Authorities in Dubai have dropped the charges against Irish woman Tori Towey, who is now set to return home after a travel ban imposed on her was lifted.\n\nThe 28-year-old, a native of Boyle in Co Roscommon, was facing criminal charges - including attempted suicide and consuming alcohol - in the UAE and has had her passport destroyed.\n\nShe has worked since April 2023 for Emirates Airlines as a cabin crew member and is based in Dubai - the largest city in the UAE.\n\nREAD MORE: Irish woman charged with attempted suicide in Dubai 'very nervous' and wants to come home, says aunt\n\nREAD MORE: Sister of woman strangled to death by partner 'very upset' at verdict of murder by reason of insanity\n\nAccording to the advocacy group Detained in Dubai, Ms Towey was charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption after the latest in a series of violent assaults she has allegedly suffered at the hands of her husband.\n\nHer case had been listed for hearing in a Dubai court next Thursday, July 18.\n\nAccording to campaigners, the 28-year-old air steward was accused of breaking strict laws in the Muslim country - even though she is the victim of an alleged attack in her home.\n\nDetained in Dubai said that Ms Towey wanted to leave the Middle Eastern state after receiving hospital treatment for severe bruising and other injuries - but was detained.\n\nSinn F\u00e9in President Mary Lou McDonald TD raised the case in the D\u00e1il on Tuesday after speaking with Ms Towey and her family along with Roscommon TD Claire Kerrane.\n\nMs Towey allegedly attempted self harm after suffering severe bruising during a violent attack by her husband at her home in Dubai, Ms McDonald told the Dail.\n\n\"Following one particularly severe beating in which her husband repeatedly tried to break her arm, Tori escaped upstairs and she attempted to take her own life,\" the Sinn Fein leader said.\n\n\"Tori now faces charges in Dubai of attempted suicide and the abuse of alcohol. The system over there, rather than protecting this woman who is an Irish citizen, chose instead to detain her, to charge her. She's now under the most incredible stress.\"\n\nMs McDonald told the Dail that Ms Towey's passport was blocked and she cannot return to Ireland.\n\n\"Tori wants to come home. It is as simple as that. She is a Roscommon woman, and she wants to come home,\" The Sinn Fein TD told the Dail.\n\nTaoiseach Simon Harris vowed to intervene to help Ms Towey and \"see how we can support an Irish citizen\" in the \"most appalling circumstances\".\n\nHuman rights lawyer Radha Stirling, CEO of campaign group Detained in Dubai, is assisting Ms Towey and her family and called on Dubai authorities to \"urgently drop the charges against Tori\".\n\n\"Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive,\" Ms Stirling said.\n\n\"It's amazing that authorities did not intervene for Tori's protection, given the state her body was in when she was hospitalised the first time.\n\n\"Emirates Airlines, the Irish Embassy and the UAE medical and police services could certainly have done more to help Tori.\"\n\nShe added: \"The UAE used to charge rape victims with sex outside marriage. Now they're charging domestic violence victims with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption. Dubai police need to be educated on victim care.\"\n\nOn Wednesday, Mr Harris told the Dail that the travel ban imposed on Ms Towey has been lifted and \"the embassy will take take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go\".\n\nThe Taoiseach said he had spoken to Ms Towey and her mother and told them getting her home was \"a priority issue\".\n\nMr Harris added: \"No effort will be spared by us, by Ireland, to make progress on this matter and to get Tori Towey home.\n\n\"She doesn't need to come home after a court case because she is not a criminal. She is a victim of gender-based violence. We expect her to be able to return here to Ireland as an Irish citizen without delay.\"\n\nIn an update shared on social media on Wednesday afternoon, Detained in Dubai said the charges against Ms Towey have been officially withdrawn by police in Dubai and the travel ban lifted.\n\n\"Tori and her mother are both over the moon and we are ever grateful for widespread support of the public, the media and the Irish government,\" the advocacy group said.\n\n\"We hope her transit at the airport will go smoothly and that no further attempts will be made to keep her in the country. Well done Ireland!\"\n\nAre you affected by this story?\n\nIf you or someone you know has been affected by the issues raised in this article please contact:\n\nSamaritans helpline 116 123 Aware helpline 1800 80 48 48 Pieta House on 1800 247 247 The ISPCC on 01 676 7960\n\nJoin the Irish Mirror's breaking news service on WhatsApp. Click this link to receive breaking news and the latest headlines direct to your phone. {"uri": "2024-07-416730548", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "21:56:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T21:56:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T21:38:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/news/13103706/emirates-air-hostess-charged-attempting-suicide-dubai/", "title": "Emirates air hostess charged with attempting suicide after brutal 'attack'", "body": "Tori is currently staying in a rented property in Dubai with her mother Caroline, who travelled to be with her daughter\n\nAN Emirates air hostess has been charged with attempting suicide in Dubai after claiming she was brutally attacked in her own home.\n\nTori Towey says she suffered severe bruising and other injuries that required hospital treatment in the alleged attack.\n\nThe 28-year-old, who works in the United Arab Emirates as an airline cabin crew member, then attempted to take her own life in the wake of the domestic violence assault.\n\nShe survived but was taken to a police station where authorities charged Tori, from Co Roscommon, Ireland, with attempted suicide and alcohol cosumption.\n\nTori's passport was blocked from use, and she cannot return to Ireland.\n\nTori is currently staying in a rented property in Dubai with her mother Caroline, who travelled to be with her daughter.\n\nThe young woman, who is being supported by her mum Caroline in Dubai, told the Irish Sun: \"I'm glad I'm with my mother now but I don't know what's going to happen in court next week.\n\n\"I'm desperate to go home to Ireland and put all of this in the past. I'm asking the Taoiseach to please help us.\"\n\nTori's mother Caroline added: \"We are calling on our local representatives, the Department of Foreign Affairs, embassy and Taoiseach to please do everything to get my daughter home safely.\n\n\"She's been through the worst time of her life and needs to come home with me and heal.\"\n\nThe family are being assisted by the Detained In Dubai advocacy group.\n\n\"We are calling on Dubai authorities to urgently drop the charges against Tori, remove the travel ban and let her fly home to Ireland with her mother\", said Radha Stirling, CEO of Detained In Dubai.\n\n\"She has been charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption\", said Ms Stirling.\n\n\"Strangely, the UAE has gone to great public relations efforts to promote alcohol as legal in the country. In reality, people are still regularly charged with alcohol consumption and possession.\n\n\"Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive.\"\n\nSpeaking to Sky News from her home in Co Roscommon, Tori's aunt Ann Flynn said: \"She's doing her best.\n\n\"It's very stressful, it's stressful for all the family.\"\n\nShe described her niece as \"a beautiful young woman\", who is \"fun-loving and loved to travel\".\n\nMs Flynn added: \"She got the job of her dreams working for Emirates, and she could continue travelling with work.\"\n\n\"She loved Dubai, and had a good network of friends there.\n\n\"It's an awful situation for any young person to find themselves in. The only thing we want to do is get her home as soon as possible.\"\n\nSinn Fein president Mary Lou McDonald raised Ms Towey's case in the Irish Parliament on Tuesday afternoon.\n\nMs McDonald told Dail Eireann that Ms Towey has been the victim of domestic violence and is subject to a travel ban over alleged charges.\n\nShe said she has spoken to Ms Towey, and that the 28-year-old's mother has travelled to Dubai to be with her.\n\n\"Tori wants to come home, simple as that. She is a Roscommon woman and she wants to come home,\" she said.\n\n\"I am asking now, as a matter of absolute urgency, that we have a statement from this House, that you intervene Taoiseach, that the ambassador is called and that it is made absolutely plain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way, and an Irish citizen, an Irish woman will not be treated in this way.\"\n\nMs McDonald urged the Irish Prime Minister Simon Harris to \"urgently intervene\" in the case and ensure that Ms Towey could return to Ireland.\n\nIrish premier Simon Harris has said he will work to intervene in the shocking case.\n\nMr Harris responded saying he was not aware of Ms Towey's case, and thanked Ms McDonald for bringing it to his attention and that of the Minister of Foreign Affairs Micheal Martin.\n\nHe pledged to work \"to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be, based on what you tell me, the most appalling circumstances\".", {"uri": "8217793969", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "00:25:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T00:25:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T00:23:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-13617427/irish-airline-stewardess-dubai-stranded-domestic-assault.html", "title": "Woman 'trapped in Dubai and facing jail' after trying to take her life", "body": "An Irish air stewardess is reportedly trapped in Dubai and facing jail after drinking alcohol and trying to take her own life having allegedly suffered domestic abuse.\n\nTori Towey, 28, from Boyle in County Roscommon and who works for Emirates Airlines in the UAE, said she was attacked in her home and has now been banned from leaving the state.\n\nShe said she tried to take her own life after the attack, which left her with severe bruises and injuries.\n\nBut after being taken to a police station, Ms Towey is reportedly now facing charges of alcohol consumption and attempting suicide by a court in Dubai.\n\nShe said she is unable to leave the country as her passport was blocked, meaning she can't travel back home to Ireland.\n\nTori Towey has been left stranded in Dubai after being faced with an attempted suicide charge\n\nTori was pictured with extensive bruises over her body, which she says are from an assault\n\nSpeaking through outreach group Detained in Dubai (DiD), who are assisting the family, Ms Towey said: 'I don't know what's going to happen in court next week.\n\n'I'm desperate to go home to Ireland and put all of this in the past. I'm asking the Taoiseach to please help us.'\n\nThe DiD has said Ms Towey could face a lengthy prison sentence in a jail known for 'human rights abuses and torture'.\n\nIrish premier Simon Harris has said he will work to intervene in the 'appalling' case, while Sinn Fein president Mary Lou McDonald raised Ms Towey's case in the Irish Parliament on Tuesday afternoon.\n\nMr Harris thanked Ms McDonald for bringing the case to his attention, saying: 'I'm not directly appraised of the situation, but I'm very happy to be directly appraised of it now.'\n\nHe said he would work with the deputy 'to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be - based on what you tell me - the most appalling circumstances'.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs told the Irish Daily Mail it was aware of the case and was offering consular assistance.\n\nMs McDonald told Dail Eireann that Ms Towey has been the victim of domestic violence and is subject to a travel ban over alleged charges.\n\nMs Towey, who graduated from the Dublin Institute Of Technology, moved to the UAE in April 2023\n\nTori is pictured in 2021, before her move to the UAE - where she now hopes to return to Ireland\n\nShe said she has spoken to Ms Towey, and that the 28-year-old's mother has travelled to Dubai to be with her.\n\n'Tori wants to come home, simple as that. She is a Roscommon woman and she wants to come home,' she said.\n\n'I am asking now, as a matter of absolute urgency, that we have a statement from this House, that you intervene Taoiseach, that the ambassador is called and that it is made absolutely plain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way, and an Irish citizen, an Irish woman will not be treated in this way.'\n\nMr Harris responded saying he was not aware of Ms Towey's case, and thanked Ms McDonald for bringing it to his attention and that of the Minister of Foreign Affairs Micheal Martin.\n\nHe pledged to work 'to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be, based on what you tell me, the most appalling circumstances'.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs told the Irish Daily Mail it was aware of the case and was offering consular assistance.\n\nRadha Stirling, CEO of Detained in Dubai (DiD) claims Tori's husband went after her with a knife and punched her, before slamming her arm in the bathroom door trying to break it. She says he was later fired by Emirates over his alleged behaviour.\n\nMs Stirling said: 'We are calling on Dubai authorities to urgently drop the charges against Tori, remove the travel ban and let her fly home to Ireland with her mother. She has been charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\n\n'Strangely, the UAE has gone to great public relations efforts to promote alcohol as legal in the country. In reality, people are still regularly charged with alcohol consumption and possession. Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive.'\n\nRadha Stirling, CEO of DiD says Tori's husband attacked her with a knife and punched her, before slamming her arm in the bathroom door trying to break it. Pictured the injuries said to be from the alleged attack\n\nThe 28-year-old moved to the UAE in April 2023 when she was offered a job as a flight attendant with Emirates\n\nShe explained: 'Tori arranged to fly home to Ireland but, when she arrived at the airport, was told a case against her by her husband had been dropped but the travel ban remained.\n\n'She attended the police station who assured her the travel ban would be lifted but it never happened. The next day, Tori and her husband had some wine and he became enraged, accusing her of having an affair.'\n\nMs Towey then attempted to take her own life and ended up in a police station.\n\nMs Stirling explained: 'The next thing she remembers is an ambulance crew and police waking her up. She was taken to Al Barsha police station and kept for several hours before going home again.\n\n'Her mother pleaded to the Irish Consulate but in the absence of their assistance, boarded a flight to Dubai. When she arrived, she wasn't allowed to see Tori alone, her abuser wouldn't allow it.\n\n'The three met at Emirates mall then attended the prosecutor's office to find out what charges had been registered against her.'\n\nThe airline hostess has been told 'nothing could be done' and that the case will be going to court on July 18.\n\nIf you need to talk to someone, call the Samaritans for {"uri": "8218212255", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "07:28:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T07:28:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T07:27:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-13618945/Lifeline-air-stewardess-trapped-Dubai-charged-attempting-suicide-battered-South-African-husband-authorities-Irish-Emirates-lawyer-diplomatic-pressure.html", "title": "Lifeline for air stewardess 'trapped in Dubai'", "body": "An air stewardess trapped in Dubai after drinking alcohol and trying to take her own life having allegedly suffered domestic abuse has now been offered a lifeline.\n\nIt was announced this morning that authorities have offered the 28-year-old Irish Emirates worker a lawyer following diplomatic pressure.\n\nTori Towey, from Boyle in County Roscommon and who works for Emirates Airlines in the UAE, said she was attacked in her home and has now been banned from leaving the state.\n\nThe CEO of legal group Detained in Dubai said: 'Dubai authorities have offered to provide a lawyer to Tori Towey after Irish diplomatic efforts.\n\n'Dubai police should just drop the charges at this point. Tori did not deserve to be charged in the first place and should be allowed to go home immediately.'\n\nA spokesperson for the group claimed Ms Towey's South African husband went after her with a knife and punched her, before slamming her arm in the bathroom door trying to break it.\n\nTori Towey has been left stranded in Dubai after being faced with an attempted suicide charge\n\nIt was announced this morning that authorities have offered the Irish Emirates worker a lawyer\n\nTori was pictured with extensive bruises over her body, which she says are from an assault\n\nMs Towey said she tried to take her own life after the attack, which left her with severe bruises and injuries.\n\nBut after being taken to a police station, she is now facing charges of alcohol consumption and attempting suicide by a court in Dubai.\n\nShe said she is unable to leave the country as her passport was blocked, meaning she can't travel back home to Ireland.\n\nSpeaking through outreach group DiD, who are assisting the family, Ms Towey said: 'I don't know what's going to happen in court next week.\n\nDubai's draconian laws: Why attempting suicide and drinking alcohol is a 'crime'\n\nPrior to 2019, anyone found guilty of attempting suicide in Dubai faced a 5000AED fine (\u00a31050) or six months in prison.\n\nThe 'offence' was one of 28 'minor crimes' downgraded to free up space in the Emirates' overcrowded courts system.\n\nThose found guilty of attempting suicide in the Gulf state now have to pay a fine of 1000AED (\u00a3210) instead of facing a judge.\n\nIn the same year, the Gulf state loosened its liquor laws to allow tourists to purchase alcohol in state-controlled stores, previously only accessible to licence-holding residents.\n\nThe new laws also let visitors obtain liquor permits themselves for the first time, by applying online or going to a registered alcohol store to get one for free.\n\nEven in your own home, it is illegal to drink without holding a permit.\n\nIt is also illegal to drink or even be under the influence of alcohol in public, outside of a licensed premises.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n'I'm desperate to go home to Ireland and put all of this in the past. I'm asking the Taoiseach to please help us.'\n\nThe DiD has said Ms Towey could face a lengthy prison sentence in a jail known for 'human rights abuses and torture'.\n\nRadha Stirling, CEO of Detained in Dubai, said: 'We are calling on Dubai authorities to urgently drop the charges against Tori, remove the travel ban and let her fly home to Ireland with her mother. She has been charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\n\n'Strangely, the UAE has gone to great public relations efforts to promote alcohol as legal in the country. In reality, people are still regularly charged with alcohol consumption and possession. Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive.'\n\nShe explained: 'Tori arranged to fly home to Ireland but, when she arrived at the airport, was told a case against her by her husband had been dropped but the travel ban remained.\n\n'She attended the police station who assured her the travel ban would be lifted but it never happened. The next day, Tori and her husband had some wine and he became enraged, accusing her of having an affair.'\n\nMs Towey then attempted to take her own life and ended up in a police station.\n\nMs Stirling explained: 'The next thing she remembers is an ambulance crew and police waking her up. She was taken to Al Barsha police station and kept for several hours before going home again.\n\n'Her mother pleaded to the Irish Consulate but in the absence of their assistance, boarded a flight to Dubai. When she arrived, she wasn't allowed to see Tori alone, her abuser wouldn't allow it.\n\n'The three met at Emirates mall then attended the prosecutor's office to find out what charges had been registered against her.'\n\nMs Towey, who graduated from the Dublin Institute Of Technology, moved to the UAE in April 2023\n\nTori is pictured in 2021, before her move to the UAE - where she now hopes to return to Ireland\n\nIrish premier Simon Harris has said he will work to intervene in the 'appalling' case, while Sinn Fein president Mary Lou McDonald raised Ms Towey's case in the Irish Parliament on Tuesday afternoon.\n\nMr Harris thanked Ms McDonald for bringing the case to his attention, saying: 'I'm not directly appraised of the situation, but I'm very happy to be directly appraised of it now.'\n\nHe said he would work with the deputy 'to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be - based on what you tell me - the most appalling circumstances'.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs told the Irish Daily Mail it was aware of the case and was offering consular assistance.\n\nMs McDonald told Dail Eireann that Ms Towey has been the victim of domestic violence and is subject to a travel ban over alleged charges.\n\nShe said she has spoken to Ms Towey, and that the 28-year-old's mother has travelled to Dubai to be with her.\n\n'Tori wants to come home, simple as that. She is a Roscommon woman and she wants to come home,' she said.\n\n'I am asking now, as a matter of absolute urgency, that we have a statement from this House, that you intervene Taoiseach, that the ambassador is called and that it is made absolutely plain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way, and an Irish citizen, an Irish woman will not be treated in this way.'\n\nRadha Stirling, CEO of DiD says Tori's husband attacked her with a knife and punched her, before slamming her arm in the bathroom door trying to break it. Pictured the injuries said to be from the alleged attack\n\nThe 28-year-old moved to the UAE in April 2023 when she was offered a job as a flight attendant with Emirates\n\nMr Harris responded saying he was not aware of Ms Towey's case, and thanked Ms McDonald for bringing it to his attention and that of the Minister of Foreign Affairs Micheal Martin.\n\nHe pledged to work 'to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be, based on what you tell me, the most appalling circumstances'.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs told the Irish Daily Mail it was aware of the case and was offering consular assistance.\n\nTalking to Sky News, Tori's aunt Ann Flynn said: 'She's doing her best.' She added: 'It's very stressful, it's stressful for all the family.'\n\nShe described her niece as 'a beautiful young woman' who is 'fun-loving and loved to travel'.\n\nMs Flynn said: 'She got the job of her dreams working for Emirates, and she could continue travelling with work.\n\n'She loved Dubai, and had a good network of friends there.'\n\nThe airline hostess has been told 'nothing could be {"uri": "8218167844", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "06:58:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T06:58:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T06:57:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://extra.ie/2024/07/10/news/irish-news/dubai-irishwoman-domestic-abuse", "title": "Irish 'domestic abuse victim' begs to be allowed to go home from Dubai after attempted suicide charge", "body": "An Irishwoman has begged the Government here to get her out of Dubai after she was charged following a suicide attempt brought on by alleged domestic abuse.\n\nTori Towey, 28, from Boyle in Co. Roscommon, is not allowed to leave the country and faces imprisonment instead for attempted suicide as well as drinking alcohol.\n\nTaoiseach Simon Harris yesterday responded to Ms Towey's plight, telling the D\u00e1il he was ready to 'intervene' in the case, which he described as 'appalling'. He was replying to Sinn F\u00e9in leader Mary Lou McDonald, who called on the Government to take action over the situation.\n\nMs Towey moved to the UAE in April 2023 when she began work as a flight attendant with Emirates. She married a South African man and they had been living together until their relationship allegedly became abusive. It is also alleged he ripped up her passport when she tried to leave and physically abused her. While in the process of replacing her passport, she found out there was a travel ban against her but wasn't sure why.\n\nOutreach group Detained in Dubai (DiD), which is helping Ms Towey, confirmed it is commonplace for spouses to open preemptive cases against the victim to try to immunise themselves from their own criminal cases.\n\nSpeaking through DiD, Ms Towey said: 'I don't know what's going to happen in court next week. I'm desperate to go home to Ireland and put all of this in the past. I'm asking the Taoiseach to please help us.'\n\nMs McDonald told the D\u00e1il: 'Following one particularly severe beating, in which her husband repeatedly tried to break her arm, Tori escaped upstairs and she attempted to take her own life.\n\n'Tori now faces charges in Dubai of attempted suicide and the abuse of alcohol. The system over there, rather than protecting this woman who is an Irish citizen, chose instead to detain her, to charge her. She's now under the most incredible stress.'\n\nShe continued: 'Tori wants to come home, simple as that. She's a Roscommon woman. She wants to come home. And I'm asking now, as a matter of absolute urgency, that we have a statement from this House, that you intervene, Taoiseach, that the Ambassador comes in and that you explain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way. That an Irish citizen, an Irish woman will not be treated in this way.'\n\nMr Harris thanked Ms McDonald for bringing the case to his attention, saying: 'I'm not directly appraised of the situation, but I'm very happy to be directly appraised of it now.'\n\nHe said he would work with the deputy 'to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be - based on what you tell me - the most appalling circumstances'.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs said it was aware of the case and was offering consular assistance.\n\nDiD founder Radha Stirling said Ms Towey is terrified she may go to jail and was interrogated for hours. She added: 'Tori arranged to fly home to Ireland but, when she arrived at the airport, was told a case against her by her husband had been dropped but the travel ban remained.\n\n'She attended the police station who assured her the travel ban would be lifted but it never happened. The next day, Tori and her husband had some wine and he became enraged, accusing her of having an affair.'\n\nMs Towey then attempted to take her own life and ended up in a police station.\n\nMs Stirling explained: 'Once she was discharged she was brought to a police station. The next thing she remembers is an ambulance crew and police waking her up. She was taken to Al Barsha police station and kept for several hours before going home again.\n\n'Her mother pleaded to the Irish Consulate but in the absence of their assistance, boarded a flight to Dubai. When she arrived, she wasn't allowed to see Tori alone, her abuser wouldn't allow it.\n\n'The three met at Emirates mall then attended the prosecutor's office to find out what charges had been registered against her.' Ms Towey was told nothing could be done and the cases against her were going to court on July 18. She had been charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption. 'Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive,' said Ms Stirling.\n\n'It's amazing that authorities did not intervene for Tori's protection, given the state her body was in when she was hospitalised the first time.' She added: 'Worse than failing her, authorities travelbanned her and kept her in the country when she was trying to get away. They put her in a hopeless position resulting in her attempt to kill herself to escape the imminent threat of assault and likely murder.\n\n'As if that wasn't enough, Dubai police then want to prosecute her for trying to get away via the only means she saw available at the time. She's now under the most incredible stress when I spoke to her this afternoon,\" Ms McDonald said.\n\n\"Tori wants to come home, simple as that. She is a Roscommon woman and she wants to come home,\" she said.\n\n\"I am asking now, as a matter of absolute urgency, that we have a statement from this House, that you intervene Taoiseach, that the ambassador is called and that it is made absolutely plain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way, and an Irish citizen, an Irish woman will not be treated in this way.\"\n\nMr Harris responded saying he was not aware of Ms Towey's case, and thanked Ms McDonald for bringing it to his attention and that of the Minister of Foreign Affairs Miche\u00e1l Martin.\n\nHe pledged to work \"to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be, based on what you tell me, the most appalling circumstances\".\n\nIn response to queries, a spokesman for the Department of Foreign Affairs said the department \"is aware of the case and is providing consular assistance. {"uri": "8219288991", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "19:35:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T19:35:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T19:34:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13621181/Air-stewardess-Dubai-husband-freed-moon-Ireland.html", "title": "Air stewardess held in Dubai is 'over the moon' after being freed", "body": "An Irish air stewardess, who was detained in Dubai and charged with attempted suicide after suffering brutal domestic violence, is 'over the moon' to return home.\n\nTori Towey, 28, a flight attendant from County Roscommon, woke up in a police station in Dubai after she was attacked by her South African husband.\n\nPolice in the United Arab Emirates charged the young woman with alcohol abuse and attempted suicide which she was due to fight in court later this month.\n\nHer passport was banned, preventing Ms Towey from returning home to her family in Ireland and sparking fears she was headed towards a jail term in an Emirati prison.\n\nBut a campaign group working on her case has confirmed that the charges have been withdrawn, the travel ban lifted and that Ms Towey is 'relieved' to be headed home.\n\nTori Towey has been left stranded in Dubai after being faced with an attempted suicide charge\n\nTori was pictured with extensive bruises over her body, which she says are from an assault\n\nDetained in Dubai CEO Radha Stirling said: 'She is thrilled and relieved. She said she is over the moon and looking forward to getting home to Ireland and seeing the rest of her family.\n\n'She is a little nervous too because there is that worry that something could happen before she gets on a plane but the overriding feeling is one of joy.'\n\nMs Towey's family has thanked the Irish government and campaigners for their help, with her mum Caroline telling MailOnline the support 'has been incredible'.\n\nCaroline said: 'The support from the Irish government and the Irish people has been incredible and we weren't expecting it at all. It's a small country and the politicians are real people.\n\nRead MoreBREAKING NEWS Air stewardess is FREED in Dubai after she was detained for 'attempting suicide'\n\n'We are both exhausted and desperate to get home. Thank you so much to everyone supporting us.'\n\nShe added that her daughter had been through 'the worst time of her life and needs to come home with me and heal'.\n\nTori's aunt Ann Flynn also told Sky News: 'She's doing her best. It's very stressful, stressful for all the family.\n\n'Tori's a beautiful young woman, fun-loving, loves to travel. She got the job of her dreams working for Emirates, and she could continue travelling with work.'\n\n'It's really terrible that this has happened to a young woman who was full of life and full of adventure.'\n\nMr Harris, a lawyer working on the case, said: 'The embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go and that the embassy of course will continue to follow up on the case, which is still active as of now.'\n\nHe thanked the Irish embassy in the United Arab Emirates for their work on the case.\n\nIt comes hours after Tori's mother said she was 'desperate to get home' and has been through 'the worst time of her life'.\n\nTori, pictured left with aunt, has been banned from leaving the UAE and told she faces jail for drinking alcohol and attempting to take her own life\n\nTori had been banned from leaving the UAE and told she faced jail for drinking alcohol and attempting to take her own life following the alleged beating by her husband.\n\nA spokesperson for legal group Detained in Dubai (DiD) claimed Tori's South African husband went after her with a knife and punched her, before slamming her arm in the bathroom door trying to break it.\n\nTori said she tried to take her own life after the attack, which left her with severe bruises and injuries.\n\nBut after being taken to a police station, Ms Towey was facing charges of alcohol consumption and attempting suicide by a court in Dubai.\n\nShe said she was unable to leave the country as her passport had been blocked.\n\nSpeaking through outreach group DiD, who are assisting the family, Ms Towey said prior to the lifting of the travel ban: 'I don't know what's going to happen in court next week.\n\n'I'm desperate to go home to Ireland and put all of this in the past. I'm asking the Taoiseach to please help us.'\n\nRead MoreEXCLUSIVE Air stewardess facing jail in Dubai for 'attempting suicide' is 'desperate to come home', mum says\n\nThe DiD said Ms Towey had faced a lengthy prison sentence in a jail known for 'human rights abuses and torture'.\n\nRadha Stirling, CEO of DiD, said: 'We are calling on Dubai authorities to urgently drop the charges against Tori, remove the travel ban and let her fly home to Ireland with her mother. She has been charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\n\n'Strangely, the UAE has gone to great public relations efforts to promote alcohol as legal in the country. In reality, people are still regularly charged with alcohol consumption and possession. Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive.'\n\nShe explained: 'Tori arranged to fly home to Ireland but, when she arrived at the airport, was told a case against her by her husband had been dropped but the travel ban remained.\n\n'She attended the police station who assured her the travel ban would be lifted but it never happened. The next day, Tori and her husband had some wine and he became enraged, accusing her of having an affair.'\n\nMs Stirling explained: 'The next thing she remembers is an ambulance crew and police waking her up. She was taken to Al Barsha police station and kept for several hours before going home again.\n\n'Her mother pleaded to the Irish Consulate but in the absence of their assistance, boarded a flight to Dubai. When she arrived, she wasn't allowed to see Tori alone, her abuser wouldn't allow it.\n\n'The three met at Emirates mall then attended the prosecutor's office to find out what charges had been registered against her.'\n\nMs Towey, who graduated from the Dublin Institute Of Technology, moved to the UAE in April 2023\n\nTori is pictured in 2021, before her move to the UAE - where she now hopes to return to Ireland\n\nBe the first to commentBe one of the first to commentCommentsShould Ireland intervene to bring Tori Towey home from Dubai?Comment now\n\nIrish premier Harris said he would intervene in the 'appalling' case as Sinn Fein president Mary Lou McDonald raised Ms Towey's case in the Irish Parliament on Tuesday afternoon.\n\nMr Harris thanked Ms McDonald for bringing the case to his attention, saying: 'I'm not directly appraised of the situation, but I'm very happy to be directly appraised of it now.'\n\nRead More Lifeline for air stewardess 'trapped in Dubai' after 'charged with attempting suicide'\n\nHe said he would work with the deputy 'to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be - based on what you tell me - the most appalling circumstances'.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs told the Irish Daily Mail it was aware of the case and was offering consular assistance.\n\nMs McDonald told Dail Eireann that Ms Towey has been the victim of domestic violence and is subject to a travel ban over alleged charges.\n\nShe said she had spoken to Ms Towey, and that the 28-year-old's mother travelled to Dubai to be with her.\n\n'Tori wants to come home, simple as that. She is a Roscommon woman and she wants to come home,' she said.\n\nRadha Stirling, CEO of DiD says Tori's husband attacked her with a knife and punched her, before slamming her arm in the bathroom door trying to break it. Pictured the injuries said to be from the alleged attack\n\nThe 28-year-old moved to the UAE in April 2023 when she was offered a job as a flight attendant with Emirates\n\nIn 2018, one member of Dubai Police said that they would focus on treatment rather than punishment when it came to suicide victims, even though suicide and suicide attempts are a crime in the country.\n\nBrig Ahmed bin Ghalaita, then director of Al Refaa Police Station, told The National: 'The move is taken to provide support to suicide attempters and deal with them as victims who need moral support and help.\n\n'Suicide cases are being examined by a police unit and experts in the psychology field to identify the causes behind their attempts and find solutions for them.'\n\nIt comes as earlier this year, British wives boasting of luxury new lives funded by millionaire husbands in Dubai have been warned they risk being dumped homeless on the streets at any moment.\n\nExperts have revealed a surge in complaints from not only women but also men betrayed and dumped by wealthy partners after upping sticks for the Middle East.\n\nThe alert comes amid a TikTok and Instagram trend of UK women sharing footage of spending sprees in the United Arab Emirates after wedding wealthy husbands.\n\nMailOnline had also reported on an influx of expats pampered by rich partners, enjoying days filled with shopping trips, extravagant meals and property upgrades.\n\nDubai's draconian laws: Why attempting suicide and drinking alcohol is a 'crime'\n\nPrior to 2019, anyone found guilty of attempting suicide in Dubai faced a 5000AED fine (\u00a31050) or six months in prison.\n\nThe 'offence' was one of 28 'minor crimes' downgraded to free up space in the Emirates' overcrowded courts system.\n\nThose found guilty of attempting suicide in the Gulf state now have to pay a fine of 1000AED (\u00a3210) instead of facing a judge.\n\nIn the same year, the Gulf state loosened its liquor laws to allow tourists to purchase alcohol in state-controlled stores, previously only accessible to licence-holding residents.\n\nThe new laws also let visitors obtain liquor permits themselves for the first time, by applying online or going to a registered alcohol store to get one for free.\n\nWhile visitors must have a permit, it's no longer a criminal offence not to have one.\n\nA 30 per cent tax on alcohol was also axed on New Year's Eve 2022 to encourage tourists to flock to the Emirate.\n\nWhile the relaxation of the laws sends a message that it's safe to drink, the reality is more complicated.\n\nIt is illegal to drink or even be under the influence of alcohol in public outside of a licensed premises.\n\nRadha Stirling, founder and CEO of Detained in Dubai previously told MailOnline: 'Reducing the cost of alcohol in Dubai is sending a clear message to tourists and that is to drink. Considering Dubai's alcohol laws prohibit the possession of alcohol in public, drinking in Dubai is inherently dangerous.\n\n'If a visitor's blood is tested and shows up even one drink, they can be criminally charged. Alcohol tests are often conducted when a complaint is made by a local. If a local is offended by a visitor's dress sense, language or behaviour, they may call the police and have the visitor arrested, even if that person has only consumed a small beer.\n\n'Dubai's laws are highly contradictory. On the one hand, people are encouraged to drink but on the other, it's a criminal offence to have any amount of alcohol in your blood in public. Encouraging visitors to drink more alcohol will most certainly result in increased detentions of Brits abroad in prisons notorious for human rights abuses and police brutality'.", "source": {"uri": I'm asking the Taoiseach to please help us.\n\nTori's mother Caroline added: \"We are calling on our local representatives, the Department of Foreign Affairs, embassy and Taoiseach to please do everything to get my daughter home safely.\n\n\"She's been through the worst time of her life and needs to come home with me and heal.\"\n\nThe 28-year-old United Arab Emirates cabin crew member from Co Roscommon, Ireland has been detained in Dubai after her passport was taken off her.\n\nTori's husband was named as her attacker by the Sinn Fein's leader May Lou McDonald in the Dail, Ireland's parliament.\n\nThe young woman, who is supported by her mother in Dubai, said they were pleading with Ireland's president Simon Harris, the Taoiseach, to help them.\n\nShe said: \"I'm glad I'm with my mother now but I don't know what's going to happen in court next week.\n\n\"I'm desperate to go home to Ireland and put all of this in the past. I'm asking the Taoiseach to please help us.\n\nTori's mother Caroline added: \"We are calling on our local representatives, the Department of Foreign Affairs, embassy and Taoiseach to please do everything to get my daughter home safely.\n\n\"She's been through the worst time of her life and needs to come home with me and heal.\"\n\nSpeaking to Sky News from her home in Co Roscommon, Tori's aunt Ann Flynn said: \"She's doing her best.\n\n\"I spoke to her this afternoon. Her mother Caroline has travelled to be with her.\n\nTori wants to come home, simple as that. She's a Roscommon woman.\n\n\"She wants to come home.\"\n\nMs Flynn continued: \"Following one particularly severe beating in which her husband repeatedly tried to break her arm, Tori escaped upstairs and she attempted to take her own life.\n\n\"Tori now faces charges in Dubai of attempted suicide and the abuse of alcohol. The system over there, rather than protecting this woman who is an Irish citizen, chose instead to detain her, to charge her. She's now under the most incredible stress.\n\nThe family are being assisted by the Detained In Dubai advocacy group.\n\nCEO of Detained In Dubai Radha Stirling said: \"Strangely, the UAE has gone to great public relations efforts to promote alcohol as legal in the country.\n\n\"In reality, people are still regularly charged with alcohol consumption and possession.\n\n\"Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive.\"\n\nSinn Fein president Mary Lou McDonald raised Ms Towey's case in the Irish Parliament on Tuesday afternoon.\n\nMs McDonald told Dail Eireann that Ms Towey has been the victim of domestic violence and is subject to a travel ban over alleged charges.\n\nShe said she had spoken to Ms Towey, and that the 28-year-old's mother had travelled to Dubai to be with her.\n\n\"She said: \"I am asking now, as a matter of absolute urgency, that we have a statement from this House, that you intervene Taoiseach, that the ambassador is called and that it is made absolutely plain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way, and an Irish citizen, an Irish woman will not be treated in this way.\"\n\nMs McDonald urged the Irish Prime Minister Simon Harris to \"urgently intervene\" in the case and ensure that Ms Towey could return to Ireland.\n\nIrish premier Simon Harris has said he will work to intervene in the shocking case.\n\nMr Harris responded by saying he was not aware of Ms Towey's case and thanked Ms McDonald for bringing it to his attention and that of the Minister of Foreign Affairs Micheal Martin.\n\nHe pledged to work \"to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be, based on what you tell me, the most appalling circumstances\".", Harris said he was not aware of the case but noted that her plight had been raised with the minister for foreign affairs by Sinn F\u00e9in.\n\nThe Taoiseach, who was responding to a question from McDonald, said: \"Thank you, deputy McDonald, for bringing the case of Tori to my attention,\" RT\u00c9 reported.\n\n\"I'm not directly apprised of the situation, but I'm very happy to be directly apprised of it now,\" he added.\n\nHarris added he would work with the deputy \"to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be - based on what you tell me - the most appalling circumstances\".\n\nIreland's department of foreign affairs told Sky News it is \"aware of the case and is providing consular assistance\".\n\nIt added: \"As with all consular cases, the department does not comment on the details of individual cases.\"\n\nAttempted suicide is a crime in the Arab state, carrying a sentence of up to six months.\n\nMs McDonald said she has spoken to Ms Towey, and that the young woman's mother, Caroline, has travelled to Dubai to be with her.\n\nThe Sinn F\u00e9in leader told the D\u00e1il: \"She's under incredible stress.\n\n\"Unfortunately, Tori now faces charges in Dubai of attempted suicide and the abuse of alcohol, the system over there rather than protecting this woman who is an Irish citizen, chose instead to detain her to charge her. {"uri": "2024-07-417293543", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "10:39:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T10:39:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T10:27:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/news/irish-air-stewardess-stranded-dubai-102756527.html", "title": "Irish air stewardess stranded in Dubai after attempted suicide charge", "body": "Irish air stewardess stranded in Dubai after attempted suicide charge\n\nJames Crisp\n\n10 July 2024 at 0:27 pm\n\nAn Irish air stewardess has been left stranded in Dubai after being charged for attempting suicide following alleged domestic abuse.\n\nTori Towey is banned from leaving the UAE, where she works for the Emirates airline, and is charged with attempted suicide and drinking alcohol.\n\nThe 28-year-old, from Boyle in County Roscommon, said that she tried to take her own life after her South African husband allegedly attacked her, leaving her with severe bruises and injuries.\n\nShe survived but was told she would face criminal charges at a police station.\n\nHer passport has been blocked, meaning she cannot return to Ireland, and her case is due to go to court on July 18.\n\n'I'm desperate to go home to Ireland and put all of this in the past. I'm asking the taoiseach to please help us,\" Ms Towey said, speaking through the Detained in Dubai advocacy group.\n\nOn Monday, her plight was raised in Ireland's parliament, the D\u00e1il.\n\n\"She's under incredible stress\", said Mary Lou McDonald, the Sinn F\u00e9in leader. \"Tori is a Roscommon woman, and she wants to come home.\"\n\nSpeaking under parliamentary privilege, Ms McDonald said that Ms Towey had been a victim \"of the most gross domestic violence\".\n\nSimon Harris, Ireland's taoiseach, said he would be happy \"to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be, based on what you tell me, the most appalling circumstances\".\n\nThe Irish department of foreign affairs is providing consular support to Ms Towey, who moved to the Gulf state in April last year for the job with Emirates, where she met her husband.\n\nOn Tuesday, Dubai authorities offered Ms Towey a lawyer, after diplomatic pressure from Dublin.\n\nMs Towey is currently staying in a rented property in Dubai with her mother, Caroline, who has flown to the UAE to be with her daughter.\n\nRadha Stirling, the chief executive of Detained in Dubai, said: \"Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic.\n\n'We are calling on Dubai authorities to urgently drop the charges against Tori, remove the travel ban and let her fly home to Ireland with her mother.\n\n'Strangely, the UAE has gone to great public relations efforts to promote alcohol as legal in the country. In reality, people are still regularly charged with alcohol consumption and possession.\"\n\nAnyone found guilty of attempting suicide in Dubai faced a \u00a31,050 fine or six months in prison before 2019, when it was downgraded to a \u00a3210 fine.\n\nThe Gulf state also relaxed its alcohol laws to allow tourists to buy alcohol in state-controlled shops, which were previously only accessible for {"uri": "2024-07-416535339", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "17:22:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T17:22:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T17:19:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.thesun.ie/news/13369763/tori-towey-jail-dubai-domestic-violence-trapped-dail-roscommon/", "title": "Fears for Irish flight attendant facing jail & trapped in Dubai after attack", "body": "Taoiseach Simon Harris told the Dail that he is ready to 'intervene' after branding Tori's plight 'the most appalling circumstances'\n\nAN IRISH Emirates Airlines flight attendant who is facing jail in Dubai after attempting to take her own life following a horror attack in her home declared last night: I just want to get back to Ireland.\n\nAuthorities have charged Tori Towey with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\n\nThe 28-year-old, from Boyle, Co Roscommon, says she suffered severe bruising and other injuries that required hospital treatment after being brutally attacked in her own home.\n\nBut after an attempt to take her own life in the wake of the domestic violence assault, authorities in Dubai instead charged Tori with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\n\nAnd rather than helping her go home to Ireland, the assault victim says she is trapped in Dubai after the authorities hit her with a travel ban.\n\nTori is now facing criminal charges in court next week which could lead to lengthy imprisonment in jails notorious for human rights abuses and torture.\n\nThe young woman, who is being supported by her mum Caroline in Dubai, told the Irish Sun: \"I'm glad I'm with my mother now but I don't know what's going to happen in court next week.\n\n\"I'm desperate to go home to Ireland and put all of this in the past. I'm asking the Taoiseach to please help us.\"\n\nTori's mother Caroline added: \"We are calling on our local representatives, the Department of Foreign Affairs, embassy and Taoiseach to please do everything to get my daughter home safely.\n\n\"She's been through the worst time of her life and needs to come home with me and heal.\"\n\nAn advocacy group has also urged the Irish government to intervene to have the charges against Tori dropped and to allow her to travel home.\n\nRadha Stirling, CEO of Detained in Dubai, branded the case and the travel ban against Ms Towey as \"outrageous.\"\n\nStirling, who has helped in numerous domestic violence cases including that of Princess Latifa, said: \"Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive.\n\n\"It's amazing that authorities did not intervene for Tori's protection, given the state her body was in when she was hospitalised the first time.\n\nDubai cops 'need to be educated'\n\n\"Worse than failing her, authorities in Dubai actually travel-banned her and kept her in the country when she was trying to get away.\n\n\"The UAE used to charge rape victims with sex outside marriage. Now they're charging violence victims with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption. Dubai police need to be educated on victim care.\n\n\"We are calling on Dubai authorities to urgently drop the charges against Tori, remove the travel ban and let her fly home to Ireland with her mother.\n\n\"We are also calling on Ireland's Taoiseach Simon Harris, the head of Foreign Affairs Micheal Martin, Ambassador Alison Milton and local TDs, Michael Fitzmaurice, Claire Kerrane and Denis Naughten as well as the UAE's Ambassador to Ireland, H.E. Mohammed Hmoud Hamad Rahma Alshamsi to help bring Tori home.\"\n\nMs McDonald outlined how Tori was being detained in Dubai after attempting to take her own life in the wake of \"one particularly severe beating\".\n\nAnd with Tori stranded in the United Arab Emirates facing criminal charges, the Sinn Fein boss pleaded for the Taoiseach to intervene to help get the Roscommon woman home.\n\nMs McDonald said: \"She has been the victim of the most gross domestic violence.\n\n'Severe beating'\n\n\"Her passport has been destroyed. There was a travel ban imposed on her and she had gone to the authorities seeking protection many times but to absolutely no avail.\n\n\"But following one particularly severe beating in which her husband repeatedly tried to slam doors on her arms and break her limbs, she escaped upstairs and she attempted to take her own life.\n\n\"Unfortunately, Tori now faces charges in Dubai of attempted suicide and the abuse of alcohol, the system over there rather than protecting this woman who is an Irish citizen, chose instead to detain her to charge her.\"\n\nThe Sinn Fein supremo told how she talked to Tori on the phone today.\n\nUnder 'most incredible stress'\n\nMs McDonald continued: \"She's now under the most incredible stress when I spoke to her this afternoon.\n\n\"Her mother Caroline has travelled to be with her. Tori wants to come home. Simple as that. She's a Roscommon woman, she wants to come home.\n\n\"And I'm asking now as a matter of absolute urgency that we have a statement from this house, that you intervene, that the ambassador is called and it made absolutely plain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way. And an Irish citizen, an Irish woman will not be treated in this way.\"\n\nTaoiseach Harris told the Dail that he is ready to \"intervene\" after branding Tori's plight \"the most appalling circumstances\".\n\nHe said: \"Thank you, Deputy McDonald, for bringing the case of Tori to my attention.\n\n\"I'm not directly appraised of the situation, but I'm very happy to be directly appraised of it now.\"\n\nThe Taoiseach pledged to work with the deputy \"to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be - based on what you tell me - the most appalling circumstances\".\n\n'Absolutely frightening'\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs confirmed it was aware of the case.\n\nA spokesperson for the Department told the Irish Sun: \"The Department of Foreign Affairs is aware of the case and is providing consular assistance. As with all consular cases, the Department does not comment on the details of individual cases.\"\n\nClaire Kerrane, Sinn Fein TD for Roscommon & Galway, also vowed to press Tanaiste and Foreign Affairs Minister Micheal Martin for help.\n\nKerrane said: \"This is absolutely frightening. I have been in touch with Micheal Martin and I will be raising this in the Dail. The Irish Government needs to intervene on this urgently.\"\n\nDubai move\n\nTori moved to Dubai in April 2023 when she was offered a job with Emirates Airlines.\n\nBut the cabin crew employee's life in the United Arab Emirates turned into a nightmare after she was attacked in her home.\n\nTori says the trauma of the assault led to an attempt to take her own life.\n\nAnd as the shocked victim tried to return home to Ireland, she later discovered she had been charged by Dubai authorities with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption - and was subject to a travel ban.\n\nDetained in Dubai said: \"The victim is charged.\n\n\"Tori was told nothing could be done and that the cases against her were going to court on the 18th of July.\n\n\"She had been charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\n\n\"Strangely, the UAE has gone to great public relations efforts to promote alcohol as legal in the country. In reality, people are still regularly charged with alcohol consumption and possession.\"\n\nYou can learn more about domestic abuse and covering your tracks, as well as access support, on the HSE's {"uri": "8218683916", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:22:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:22:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:21:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/republic-of-ireland/taoiseach-confirms-travel-ban-on-irish-woman-trapped-in-dubai-has-been-lifted/a1146909501.html", "title": "Taoiseach confirms travel ban on Irish woman trapped in Dubai has been lifted", "body": "The travel ban on Tori Towey has been lifted in Dubai, the Taoiseach told the D\u00e1il this afternoon.\n\nSimon Harris interrupted questions to update the House, saying in addition: \"The embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go.\"\n\nIt is understood she could be home in Ireland as soon as tomorrow.\n\n\"The Embassy of course will continue to follow up on the case, which is still active as of now. But I just wanted to inform the House of that news,\" he said.\n\nMs Towey (28) is facing criminal charges and had been banned from leaving Dubai. She suffered severe bruising and other injuries that required hospital treatment after she was allegedly attacked in her home, according to human rights group Detained in Dubai.\n\nMs Towey, who is from Boyle in Co Roscommon, is now facing charges \"of attempted suicide and the abuse of alcohol\" and is desperate to come home.\n\nShe moved to Dubai in April 2023 for a job with Emirates and is due to appear in court next week.\n\nMr Harris this morning described the situation facing Irish woman Tori Towey in Dubai as \"unimaginable\" and said it is his priority to get Ms Towey back to her home in Ireland.\n\nSpeaking to media at Leinster House, Mr Harris said he spoke with Ms Towey and her mother Caroline this morning.\n\n\"I don't want to say too much because there is a lot of diplomatic activity going on in the background. Tori has been through in my view the most horrific situation and it is utterly, utterly unacceptable how an Irish citizen is being treated, that is my language in terms of how I feel,\" the Taoiseach said.\n\n\"Tori has been a victim of male violence and she needs to be supported. She needs to be brought back home to her home here in Ireland,\" Mr Harris added.\n\nThe Taoiseach said earlier he had also spoken to the T\u00e1naiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs Miche\u00e1l Martin on the situation as well as the Irish Ambassador, who the Taoiseach said has been working on Ms Towey's case for \"a period of time\".\n\nTodays News in 90 Seconds - 10th July 2024\n\n\"I had a conversation with the T\u00e1naiste who is also working on this matter as our Minister for Foreign Affairs.\n\n\"I have spoken to our ambassador in the region as well who have been in constant contact with her on this matter since yesterday.\n\n\"I want to acknowledge our ambassador and embassy team have been working on this case for a period of time and let me just say there is a lot of work going on in the background here,\" the Taoiseach said.\n\nMr Harris described Ms Towey's situation as \"unimaginable\" and said he will support Ms Towey in getting home.\n\n\"What Tori has been through is, I think, unimaginable for so many people. A woman who has been the victim of a brutal attack, to find herself waking up not in a hospital but in a police station,\" the Taoiseach said.\n\n\"It is my absolute priority as the Taoiseach of this country to get Tori, an Irish citizen, back home to Roscommon and I will be staying in regular contact with her and her mum and supporting them,\" he added.\n\nSpeaking to RT\u00c9 Radio One's Morning Ireland, the aunt of Tori Towey said Tori and her mother Caroline are very nervous about the situation and the family in Roscommon are hoping they will get word they are on a plane on the way home.\n\n\"I don't know will this court case go ahead and if it goes, what will happen?,\" Tori's aunt, Ann Flynn, said.\n\n\"You know, we're just very hopeful.\n\n\"And it's really terrible that this has happened to a young woman that was full of life and full of adventure.\n\n\"And she loved travelling. And, you know, she's a beautiful young woman.\"\n\nAnn said she has been in touch with the two women every day, several times a day.\n\nShe added that the pair are trying to keep positive and the family are all hoping that the charges against Tori will not go to court.\n\n\"It's on your mind constantly, and I'm sure it's on their minds because all the family is getting in touch with them, you know?\n\n\"And, it's so far away.\n\n\"But hopefully with Radha Stirling, the Taoiseach and all the ministers that is helping now, hopefully, we'll hear good news.\n\n\"We're hoping that, just something will happen that it won't go to court.\n\n\"It's hard to believe that this young woman has been charged with trying to commit suicide.\n\n\"It is very, very hard to believe,\" Ann added.\n\nRadha Stirling, CEO of advocacy group Detained in Dubai, described the case and the travel ban against Ms Towey as \"outrageous\".\n\n\"Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive\", added Stirling, who has helped in numerous domestic violence cases including that of Dubai's Princess Latifa.\n\nCEO of advocacy group Detained in Dubai Ms Stirling confirmed this morning that Ms Towey is currently living in an Airbnb.\n\n\"Right now, she's just happy to be with her mother in safety, because this is all very recent, but she is able to leave the apartment and move freely within the country,\" she said.\n\nShe continued;\n\n\"It's terrible PR for the country. You're going to have people worried to go there in the future. And of course, this is on the back of historically charging rape victims with sex outside marriage so they don't have the best reputation to start with. They've been trying to improve it.\n\n\"So I think there'll be agreeable with the Irish government if there's enough diplomatic pressure put on them, letting them know that we absolutely want Tori home and there's just going to be no negotiation on that,\" she added.\n\n\"In a best-case scenario, they will simply say: 'We're not going to proceed beyond this hearing- and we're going to let you go'.\n\n\"When it comes to a case like this, it's all about diplomacy. Without the support of the Irish government, she would be likely to face prison and charges and deportation.\n\n\"With the support of the Irish Government and diplomacy and there has been a lot - various members of the Irish government have contacted UAE ambassador to Ireland, and of course, Ireland's ambassador in the UAE, and they're trying to get those diplomatic talks happening.\n\n\"If that happens, that is the best and fastest way to get her home,\" Ms Stirling added.\n\n\"The UAE has gone to great public relations efforts to promote alcohol as legal in the country. In reality, people are still regularly charged with alcohol consumption and possession,\" added Stirling.\n\nA spokesperson for the Department of Foreign Affairs confirmed it is aware of Ms Towey's situation.\n\n\"The Department of Foreign Affairs is aware of the case and is providing consular assistance.\n\n\"As with all consular cases, the department does not comment on the details of "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/29104085/tori-towey-travel-ban-dubai-arrested-abuse-ireland/", "title": "Flight attendant FREED after arrest for 'attempted suicide' in Dubai", "body": "Tori Towey had been detained by authorities in Dubai after being charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption\n\nTHE travel ban against Irish Emirates Airlines flight attendant Tori Towey in Dubai has been lifted, Taoiseach Simon Harris has told the Dail.\n\nThe Irish woman had been detained by authorities in Dubai after being charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\n\nShe was facing jail in Dubai after attempting to take her own life following a horror attack in her home.\n\nTaoiseach Harris today revealed in the Dail that ban has now been lifted and efforts are being made to get her home.\n\nHe said: \"I've just been informed that the travel ban has been lifted, that the Embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go, and that the Embassy will, of course, continue to follow up on the case, which is still active as of now.\"\n\nHarris gave the update which he \"just received in real time\" to the Dail chamber this afternoon.\n\nHe also thanked the Irish embassy in the United Arab Emirates for their work on the case.\n\nTori had been living a nightmare in Dubai after being charged with with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption following a horror attack.\n\nThe 28-year-old, from Boyle, Co Roscommon, suffered severe bruising and other injuries that required hospital treatment after being brutally attacked in her own home.\n\nBut after an attempt to take her own life in the wake of the domestic violence assault, authorities in Dubai instead charged Tori and she was hit with a travel ban.\n\nTori and her family have been pleading for help from the Irish State to get her home safely.\n\nTori's husband was named as her attacker by the Sinn Fein's leader Mary Lou McDonald in the Dail.\n\nPleading to the Government, Tori urged them to step in regarding her case.\n\nShe said: \"I'm glad I'm with my mother now but I don't know what's going to happen in court next week.\n\n\"I'm desperate to go home to Ireland and put all of this in the past. I'm asking the Taoiseach to please help us.\n\nSpeaking on RTE's Morning Ireland earlier today, Ann Flynn, the sister of Ms Towey's mother Caroline, said that \"Tori can't travel, so Caroline has to stay with Tori, so we're just all very anxious\".\n\nShe added that the family are now hoping that they will soon get word that the mum and daughter are on a plane home.\n\nShe said: \"I don't know will this court case go ahead, or if it does what will happen? We're just very hopeful.\"\n\n\"It's really terrible that this has happened to a young woman who was full of life and full of adventure, and loved travelling.\"\n\nSpeaking to Sky News, Flynn also said that all Towey wants is to come home and is now under \"incredible stress\".\n\nShe said: \"Tori now faces charges in Dubai of attempted suicide and the abuse of alcohol.\n\n\"The system over there, rather than protecting this woman who is an Irish citizen, chose instead to detain her, to charge her.\n\n\"She's now under the most incredible stress.\"\n\nRadha Stirling, founder of the Detained in Dubai group, said the support of the Irish people and the Irish Government had \"really warmed\" them and \"given them hope and inspiration\".\n\nShe said the case is due to be heard in court next week.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs said it was providing \"ongoing consular assistance\" in the case, as was Ireland's embassy in the United Arab Emirates.\n\nA statement said: \"The Irish ambassador to the UAE is in regular contact with our citizen (including this morning).
