Roscommon, was not allowed to leave the country and faced imprisonment instead for attempted suicide as well as drinking alcohol.\n\nHer mother, Caroline, has flown to Dubai to be with her daughter.\n\nIreland's premier Simon Harris had said earlier today that 'no effort will be spared' to get the Irish woman home.\n\nMary Lou McDonald, the leader of Ireland's main opposition party Sinn Fein, raised the case in the Irish parliament for the second day in a row, criticising what she said was the 'medieval, grotesque treatment of women' in the United Arab Emirates.\n\nShe said that Tori Towey, a 28-year-old from Co Roscommon, had been working as an airline attendant in Dubai since last March.\n\n'(Tori) does not belong to Dubai, she belongs at home in Ireland,' Ms McDonald told the Dail chamber.\n\nThe Taoiseach thanked Ms McDonald and Roscommon TD Claire Kerrane for raising the 'distressing' case.\n\nHe said the Irish embassy in the United Arab Emirates has been in constant contact with Ms Towey.\n\n'We want Tori Towey back in this country, we want her back home in Roscommon,' Mr Harris said.\n\n'No effort will be spared by us, by Ireland, to make progress on this matter, to get Tori home. There was a travel ban imposed on her.\"\n\nThe Irish government should make it \"absolutely plain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way\", Ms McDonald told the D\u00e1il, and that \"an Irish citizen, an Irish woman, will not be treated in this way\".\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs said it was aware of the case and was providing consular assistance.\n\nMs Towey is receiving assistance from human rights advocate and lawyer Radha Stirling, who runs the Detained in Dubai group.\n\n\"Tori is facing court next week. She has been charged with consumption of alcohol and also attempting suicide, both of which have been historically illegal in the country,\" Ms Stirling told BBC News NI.\n\nShe explained Ms Towey was subject to a travel ban and could not leave the UAE.\n\n\"The Irish government is rightly behind us in having the UAE police drop the case against her,\" Ms Stirling said.\n\nShe said Ms Towey was unable to afford a lawyer, \"so it's even more difficult and confusing for her\".\n\nEven if found not guilty, the legal process could take \"months and months\", she explained, but the family were feeling optimistic that international pressure would help.\n\n\"If the Irish government backs her case and does everything that they can diplomatically... it's highly likely that she will be home in {"uri": "8219120660", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "17:09:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T17:09:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T17:08:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/ireland/2024/07/10/dubai-drops-attempted-suicide-charges-against-irish-woman-as-travel-ban-lifted/", "title": "Dubai drops attempted suicide charges against Irish woman as travel ban lifted", "body": "A travel ban that had prevented Irish citizen Tori Towey from leaving Dubai has been lifted, the Taoiseach has told the D\u00e1il. Video: Oireachtas TV\n\nThe Dubai Public Prosecution service has dropped charges of attempted suicide against Co Roscommon woman Tori Towey and the travel ban against her has been lifted.\n\nMs Towey (28), who moved to the United Arab Emirates (UAE) city last year, had been prevented from leaving the country as a result of the charges.\n\nOn Tuesday, Sinn F\u00e9in leader Mary Lou McDonald told the D\u00e1il that Ms Towey was the victim of domestic violence and was subjected to a travel ban over allegations she illegally consumed alcohol and attempted suicide. Attempted suicide is a crime in the Arab state, carrying a sentence of up to six months.\n\nA statement from the Dubai Government to The Irish Times said it had \"closed the case involving Irish national Tori Towey after she and her husband, a South African national, were involved in a case featuring mutual charges of assault, dating back to May 2024. The couple reached a reconciliation and withdrew the complaints filed against each other.\n\n\"Dubai Public Prosecution has also dropped the charges of attempted suicide against her considering the circumstances of the case and to enable her to return to normal life,\" the statement said.\n\nTaoiseach Simon Harris earlier told the D\u00e1il the travel ban on Ms Towey had been lifted.\n\n\"The Embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go,\" Mr Harris told TDs on Wednesday. \"And the Embassy will of course continue to follow up the case which is still active as of now.\n\n\"I just wanted to inform the House of that and to thank our Embassy,\" he said.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs was providing consular assistance to Ms Towey, who works for Emirates Airlines and whose case was first highlighted by campaign group Dubai Detained.\n\nOn Wednesday, Mr Harris told Ms McDonald that Ireland's Ambassador to the UAE, Alison Milton, \"has been in very frequent and intense contact with the Ministry for Foreign Affairs\" on Ms Towey's situation.\n\n\"I don't want to say too much more on the record in this House because I don't want to say anything that cuts across a very intense effort that is under way,\" he said.\n\nThe Taoiseach stressed that Ms Towey \"doesn't need to come home after a court case because she is not a criminal. She's a victim of gender-based violence, and we expect her to be able to return to Ireland as an Irish citizen without delay\".\n\n\"I think it's so important. Does everybody around the world including Dubai, UAE, know that we're speaking with one voice in this House in relation to this situation?\n\n\"An Irish woman, an Irish citizen, has been a victim of a horrific male violence, has been the victim of the most brutal, horrific attack one can imagine.\"\n\nT\u00e1naiste Miche\u00e1l Martin has paid tribute to Ms Milton for her role in the lifting of the travel ban against Ms Towey.\n\nSpeaking on RT\u00c9 radio's News at One, Mr Martin said\n\nhe anticipated Ms Towey and her mother, Caroline, would be returning to Ireland at the earliest opportunity now that her passport had been returned.\n\n\"It has been very, very challenging, and traumatic for Tori over the last while. But I think our team there has been in contact and has engaged with the family and indeed with the authorities as well. And, it's been a constructive engagement. And they have responded with the issue being resolved.\"\n\nCommenting earlier on the Government's response, Detained in Dubai chief executive Radha Stirling said: \"I'm super impressed by Ireland's response, it was so swift.\n\n\"When a Government gets behind their citizens, when they go the extra mile, they are successful in getting citizens home,\" she said on Newstalk Breakfast.\n\n\"When it comes to a case like this, it's all about diplomacy. Without the support of the Irish Government, she would be likely to face prison and charges and deportation,\" she said.\n\n\"She is exhausted and she's finding it very overwhelming. But at the same time, we're really, really warmed by all of the support that she's been getting. I don't think she expected all of that. I don't think she expected the Irish Government to motivate themselves as quickly. And this is the fastest I've ever seen this happen from a Government. So I'm super impressed by Ireland's response.\"\n\nAlso earlier today, Ann Flynn, aunt of Ms Towey, said the family was hoping that diplomatic efforts will lead to charges being dropped and her return to Ireland. \"We are just all very, very anxious,\" she told RT\u00c9 radio's Morning Ireland.\n\n\"We keep hoping that we'll get word that they're [Ms Towey and her mother, Caroline] on a plane. On the way home. I don't know. Will this court case go ahead? Or if it goes, what will happen? You know, we're just very hopeful. And it's really terrible that this has happened to a young woman, you know, that was full of life and full of adventure. And she loved travelling. And, you know, she's a beautiful young woman.\n\n\"We're hoping that just something will happen, that it won't go to court. It's hard to believe that this young woman has been charged with trying to commit suicide. And, you know, it's very, very hard to believe it.\"", "source": {"uri": "irishtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Irish Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8217617253", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "20:56:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T20:56:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T20:56:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/irish-flight-attendant-facing-prison-33206264", "title": "Flight attendant facing prison in Dubai after being 'attacked in her own home'", "body": "Tori Towey, 28, is facing prison in Dubai despite being the alleged victim of an assault\n\nAn air hostess is facing prison in Dubai after allegedly being left 'moments from death' from an attack by her husband at home.\n\nTori Towey, 28, from Co Roscommon in Ireland, is accused of violating strict laws in the Muslim country, despite being the victim of an alleged assault. Sinn Fein party leader Mary Lou McDonald identified Ms Towey's husband as the alleged perpetrator on Tuesday, stating she was a victim of \"the most gross domestic violence\".\n\nHuman rights activists reported that she wanted to exit the Middle Eastern nation after receiving hospital treatment for severe bruising and other injuries, but was held back. She was then charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption. Campaign group Detained in Dubai warned that Tori could now face a long-term imprisonment in a jail infamous for \"human rights abuses and torture\". They have now called on the government in Dublin to step in and fight to have the charges dismissed.\n\nShocking images have surfaced online showing Tori with severe bruising on her arms. Radha Stirling, the chief of Detained in Dubai, told the Irish Mirror: \"We need Tori home in Ireland.\" After graduating from Dublin Institute of Technology, Tori moved to Dubai in April last year to join Emirates Airlines. But following alleged assaults, Tori attempted to leave Dubai, according to Detained in Dubai's Radha Stirling.\n\nDescribing what happened to her next, Ms Stirling said: \"The thing she remembers is an ambulance crew and police waking her up. She was taken to Al Barsha police station and kept for several hours. Her mother pleaded to the Irish Consulate, but in the absence of their assistance, she boarded a flight to Dubai.\n\n\"Tori arranged to fly home to Ireland but when she arrived at the airport, she was told there was a travel ban. She attended the police station. She was assured that the travel ban would be lifted, but it never happened. She was stuck. Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and, quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive. The Irish Embassy and the UAE medical and police services could certainly have done more to help Tori. She was moments from death.\"\n\nThe Irish Taoiseach Simon Harris vowed to \"intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen\" in the \"most appalling circumstances\". Opposition leader Mary Lou McDonald from the Sinn Fein party had brought up the distressing case after speaking with Tori, and informed the Irish national parliament that the flight attendant's \"passport has been destroyed\" and a \"travel ban was imposed on her\".\n\nShe has spoken out about Tori's harrowing situation and said it had led her to attempt suicide. Ms McDonald said: \"Following one particularly severe beating in which her husband repeatedly tried to break her arm, Tori escaped upstairs and she attempted to take her own life. Tori now faces charges in Dubai of attempted suicide and the abuse of alcohol.\n\n\"The system over there, rather than protecting this woman, who is an Irish citizen, chose instead to detain her, to charge her. She's now under the most incredible stress. I spoke to her. Her mother Caroline has travelled to be with her. Tori wants to come home, simple as that. She's a Roscommon woman. She wants to come home.\"\n\nShe has demanded immediate action, and added: \"I'm asking now, as a matter of absolute urgency, that we have a statement from this House; that you intervene, Taoiseach; that the Ambassador comes in and that you explain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way. That an Irish citizen, an Irish woman will not be treated in this way.\"\n\nAdvocacy group Detained in Dubai has pleaded for charges to be dismissed against Tori prior to her court date next Thursday. Ms Stirling said: \"The case against her is going to court on July 18. She has been charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\"\n\nShe added: \"We are calling on Dubai authorities to urgently drop the charges against Tori, remove the travel ban, and let her fly home to Ireland with her mother. We are also calling on Ireland's Taoiseach Simon Harris, the head of Foreign Affairs Miche\u00e1l Martin, ambassador Alison Milton, and local TDs to help bring Tori home.\"\n\n*If you're struggling and need to talk, the Samaritans operate a free helpline open 24/7 on 116 123. {"uri": "8218011483", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "04:47:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T04:47:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:46:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://home.nzcity.co.nz/news/article.aspx?id=402164&ref=rss", "title": "Irish prime minister pledges to intervene after woman charged with trying to take her own life in UAE", "body": "The Irish prime minister says he will intervene to help a 28-year-old flight attendant detained in Dubai under \"the most appalling of circumstances\".\n\nIreland's leader has pledged to intervene after a 28-year-old Irish woman was detained in the United Arab Emirates on charges of using alcohol and trying to take her own life.\n\nMary Lou McDonald, leader of the Irish opposition party Sinn F\u00e9in, raised the case of Tori Towey in the Irish parliament on Tuesday.\n\nThe flight attendant, who has been living in Dubai since April 2023, was a \"victim of the most gross domestic violence\", according to Ms McDonald, with her passport destroyed and the UAE government imposing a travel ban preventing her from returning to Ireland.\n\n\"She went to the authorities seeking protection many times but to no avail,\" Ms McDonald told the parliament, describing a series of domestic violence incidents that left Ms Towey severely injured and suicidal.\n\n\"The system over there, rather than protecting this woman, who is an Irish citizen, chose instead to detain her and charge her. She is now under the most incredible stress.\"\n\nMs McDonald said Ms Towey had been charged with attempted suicide and using alcohol in Dubai. Consuming alcohol is still largely illegal outside of licensed premises such as hotels.\n\nSimon Harris, the Taoiseach (prime minister), called the situation \"the most appalling of circumstances\" and said he would work with Ms McDonald to intervene and support Ms Towey.\n\nMs Towey's mother has travelled to Dubai to be with her daughter, who will appear in court on July 18, according to Radha Stirling, the head of advocacy group Detained in Dubai.\n\n\"Without diplomatic intervention from the Irish government, Tori faces months of hearings which could end with her lengthy and unfair detention,\" Ms Stirling said.\n\nMs McDonald said Ms Towey, who comes from Roscommon in Ireland's north-west, wanted to come home.\n\nMs McDonald requested that the UAE ambassador be called to give an explanation for Ms Towey's detention, and that it be \"made plain to the authorities in Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way and that an Irish citizen, an Irish woman, will not be treated in this way\".\n\nClaire Kerrane, the member for Roscommon and Galway in the Irish parliament, wrote on Facebook to support Ms McDonald's speech and said she had been in direct contact with Ms Towey as well as the Irish foreign minister.\n\n\"I have since spoken to the Taoiseach directly and have been assured of action,\" she wrote.", "source": {"uri": "home.nzcity.co.nz", "dataType": {"uri": "8218845452", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "14:02:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T14:02:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T14:02:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/jul/10/irish-woman-charged-with-attempted-suicide-in-dubai-has-travel-ban-lifted", "title": "Irish woman charged with 'attempted suicide' in Dubai has travel ban lifted", "body": "Tori Towey's case was raised for second day in row in Irish parliament\n\nThe Irish premier Simon Harris has said that a travel ban imposed by Dubai authorities on Irish woman Tori Towey, who was reportedly charged with attempted suicide, has been lifted.\n\nTori Towey, 28, a flight attendant from Co Roscommon, was charged with attempted suicide and alcohol abuse after waking up in a police station after an attack, Irish parliamentarians were told.\n\nDubai authorities had also banned her from leaving the state, the Dail chamber heard.\n\nAddressing the Irish parliament on Wednesday afternoon, Harris said: \"I've just been informed that the travel ban has been lifted, that the embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go and that the embassy of course will continue to follow up on the case, which is still active as of now.\"\n\nHe thanked the Irish embassy in the United Arab Emirates for their work on the case.\n\nMary Lou McDonald, the leader of Ireland's main opposition party Sinn F\u00e9in, had raised the case in the Irish parliament on Wednesday for the second day in a row, criticising what she said was the \"medieval, grotesque treatment of women\" in the United Arab Emirates.\n\n\"(Tori) does not belong to Dubai, she belongs at home in Ireland,\" McDonald said.\n\nThe Taoiseach thanked McDonald and Roscommon TD Claire Kerrane for raising the \"distressing\" case and said she had spoken to Towey and her mother Caroline, who is with her in Dubai.\n\nHe said the Irish embassy in the United Arab Emirates had been in constant contact with Towey.\n\n\"We want Tori Towey back in this country, we want her back home in Roscommon,\" Harris said.\n\n\"No effort will be spared by us, by Ireland, to make progress on this matter, to get Tori home. She's not a criminal, she's a victim of gender-based violence.\"\n\nHarris said he had spoken to Ireland's deputy premier, Miche\u00e1l Martin, who is the minister of foreign affairs, and Ireland's ambassador to the United Arab Emirates.\n\nHer aunt Ann Flynn said both were trying to stay positive.\n\n\"They're very nervous and can't wait to get home,\" she told RTE's Morning Ireland.\n\n\"It's really terrible that this has happened to a young woman that was full of life, full of adventure, she loved travelling.\"\n\nRadha Stirling, founder of the Detained in Dubai group, said the support of the Irish people and the Irish government had \"given them hope and inspiration\".\n\nShe said the case is due to be heard next week.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs said it was providing \"ongoing consular assistance\" in the case, as was Ireland's embassy in the United Arab Emirates.", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": [], Irish woman in Dubai has been...", "body": "Irish premier Simon Harris has said that a travel ban imposed by Dubai authorities on Irish woman Tori Towey, who was reportedly charged with attempted suicide, has been lifted.\n\nTori Towey, 28, a flight attendant from Co Roscommon, was charged with attempted suicide and alcohol abuse after waking up in a police station after an attack, Irish parliamentarians were told.\n\nDubai authorities had also banned her from leaving the state, the Dail chamber heard.\n\nSimon Harris said it was 'utterly unacceptable\u00b4 how an Irish citizen was being treated in Dubai (Grainne Ni Aodha/PA)\n\nAddressing the Irish parliament on Wednesday afternoon, Mr Harris said: \"I've just been informed that the travel ban has been lifted, that the embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go and that the embassy of course will continue to follow up on the case, which is still active as of now.\"\n\nHe thanked the Irish embassy in the United Arab Emirates for their work on the case.\n\nMary Lou McDonald, the leader of Ireland's main opposition party Sinn Fein, had raised the case in the Irish parliament on Wednesday for the second day in a row, criticising what she said was the \"medieval, grotesque treatment of women\" in the United Arab Emirates.\n\n\"(Tori) does not belong to Dubai, she belongs at home in Ireland,\" Ms McDonald said.\n\nThe Taoiseach thanked Ms McDonald and Roscommon TD Claire Kerrane for raising the \"distressing\" case and said she had spoken to Ms Towey and her mother Caroline, who is with her in Dubai.\n\nHe said the Irish embassy in the United Arab Emirates has been in constant contact with Ms Towey.\n\n\"We want Tori Towey back in this country, we want her back home in Roscommon,\" Mr Harris said.\n\n\"No effort will be spared by us, by Ireland, to make progress on this matter, to get Tori home. She's not a criminal, she's a victim of gender-based violence.\"\n\nMr Harris said he had spoken to Ireland's deputy premier Micheal Martin, who is the Minister of Foreign Affairs, and Ireland's ambassador to the United Arab Emirates.\n\nHer aunt Ann Flynn said both were trying to stay positive.\n\n\"They're very nervous and can't wait to get home,\" she told RTE's Morning Ireland.\n\n\"It's really terrible that this has happened to a young woman that was full of life, full of adventure, she loved travelling.\"\n\nRadha Stirling, founder of the Detained in Dubai group, said the support of the Irish people and the Irish Government had \"really warmed\" them and \"given them hope and inspiration\".\n\nShe said the case is due to be heard in court next week.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs told the PA news agency on Wednesday it was providing \"ongoing consular assistance\" in the case, as was Ireland's embassy in the United Arab Emirates.\n\n\"The Irish ambassador to the UAE is in regular contact with our citizen (including this morning). The embassy is also engaging with all the relevant authorities in UAE on the case,\" the department said.\n\n\"Officials will continue to provide advice and consular assistance.\"", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-417418379", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:25:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:25:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:10:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/premier-says-travel-ban-imposed-121011387.html", "title": "Premier says travel ban imposed on Irish woman in Dubai has been lifted", "body": "Premier says travel ban imposed on Irish woman in Dubai has been lifted\n\nGr\u00e1inne N\u00ed Aodha, PA\n\n10 July 2024 at 2:10 pm\n\nIrish premier Simon Harris has said that a travel ban imposed by Dubai authorities on Irish woman Tori Towey, who was reportedly charged with attempted suicide, has been lifted.\n\nTori Towey, 28, a flight attendant from Co Roscommon, was charged with attempted suicide and alcohol abuse after waking up in a police station after an attack, Irish parliamentarians were told.\n\nDubai authorities had also banned her from leaving the state, the Dail chamber heard.\n\nAddressing the Irish parliament on Wednesday afternoon, Mr Harris said: \"I've just been informed that the travel ban has been lifted, that the embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go and that the embassy of course will continue to follow up on the case, which is still active as of now.\"\n\nHe thanked the Irish embassy in the United Arab Emirates for their work on the case.\n\nMary Lou McDonald, the leader of Ireland's main opposition party Sinn Fein, had raised the case in the Irish parliament on Wednesday for the second day in a row, criticising what she said was the \"medieval, grotesque treatment of women\" in the United Arab Emirates.\n\n\"(Tori) does not belong to Dubai, she belongs at home in Ireland,\" Ms McDonald said.\n\nThe Taoiseach thanked Ms McDonald and Roscommon TD Claire Kerrane for raising the \"distressing\" case and said she had spoken to Ms Towey and her mother Caroline, who is with her in Dubai.\n\nHe said the Irish embassy in the United Arab Emirates has been in constant contact with Ms Towey.\n\n\"We want Tori Towey back in this country, we want her back home in Roscommon,\" Mr Harris said.\n\n\"No effort will be spared by us, by Ireland, to make progress on this matter, to get Tori home. She's not a criminal, she's a victim of gender-based violence.\"\n\nMr Harris said he had spoken to Ireland's deputy premier Micheal Martin, who is the Minister of Foreign Affairs, and Ireland's ambassador to the United Arab Emirates.\n\nHer aunt Ann Flynn said both were trying to stay positive.\n\n\"They're very nervous and can't wait to get home,\" she told RTE's Morning Ireland.\n\n\"It's really terrible that this has happened to a young woman that was full of life, full of adventure, she loved travelling.\"\n\nRadha Stirling, founder of the Detained in Dubai group, said the support of the Irish people and the Irish Government had \"really warmed\" them and \"given them hope and inspiration\".\n\nShe said the case is due to be heard in court next week.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs told the PA news agency on Wednesday it was providing \"ongoing consular assistance\" in the case, as was Ireland's embassy in the United Arab Emirates.\n\n\"The Irish ambassador to the UAE is in regular contact with our citizen (including this morning). {"uri": "8218805524", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:36:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:36:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:36:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/news/13109218/tori-towey-travel-ban-dubai-arrested-abuse-ireland/", "title": "Family of Irish woman detained in Dubai break silence as travel ban lifted", "body": "Tori Towey had been detained by authorities in Dubai after being charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption\n\nTHE travel ban against Irish Emirates Airlines flight attendant Tori Towey in Dubai has been lifted, Taoiseach Simon Harris has told the Dail.\n\nAnd her family have said they will have a big party to celebrate when Tori finally gets home.\n\nThe Irish woman had been detained by authorities in Dubai after being charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\n\nShe was facing jail in Dubai after attempting to take her own life following a horror attack in her home.\n\nTaoiseach Harris today revealed in the Dail that ban has now been lifted and efforts are being made to get her home.\n\nHe said: \"I've just been informed that the travel ban has been lifted, that the Embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go, and that the Embassy will, of course, continue to follow up on the case, which is still active as of now.\"\n\nHarris gave the update which he \"just received in real time\" to the Dail chamber this afternoon.\n\nHe also thanked the Irish embassy in the United Arab Emirates for their work on the case.\n\nReacting to the development, Tori's aunt, Ann Flynn, said: \"It's amazing, you can't believe the relief. I didn't believe it when I first heard it. But it's amazing. The best news ever.\"\n\nShe thanked everyone for their help with the case, adding: \"It's brilliant news! Thanks all the TDs and ministers and the Taoiseach. Mary Lou [McDonald], and Claire [Kerrane], they are all amazing. We can't say enough about them. And the Irish government, they are all amazing\"\n\nSpeaking to Newstalk's Lunchtime Live, she continued: \"We only went public yesterday morning, and to think all this has happened. We're sorry we didn't do it weeks ago.\n\n\"We will have a big party when they come home, when Tori is ready. We will have a great big get-together.\"\n\nTori had been living a nightmare in Dubai after being charged with with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption following a horror attack.\n\nThe 28-year-old, from Boyle, Co Roscommon, suffered severe bruising and other injuries that required hospital treatment after being brutally attacked in her own home.\n\nBut after an attempt to take her own life in the wake of the domestic violence assault, authorities in Dubai instead charged Tori and she was hit with a travel ban.\n\nTori and her family have been pleading for help from the Irish State to get her home safely.\n\nTori's husband was named as her attacker by the Sinn Fein's leader Mary Lou McDonald in the Dail.\n\nPleading to the Government, Tori urged them to step in regarding her case.\n\nShe said: \"I'm glad I'm with my mother now but I don't know what's going to happen in court next week.\n\n\"I'm desperate to go home to Ireland and put all of this in the past. I'm asking the Taoiseach to please help us.\n\nSpeaking on RTE's Morning Ireland earlier today, Ann, the sister of Tori's mother Caroline, said the family are now hoping that they will soon get word that the mum and daughter are on a plane home.\n\nShe said: \"I don't know will this court case go ahead, or if it does what will happen? We're just very hopeful.\"\n\n\"It's really terrible that this has happened to a young woman who was full of life and full of adventure, and loved travelling.\"\n\nSpeaking to Sky News, Flynn also said that all Towey wants is to come home and is now under \"incredible stress\".\n\nShe said: \"Tori now faces charges in Dubai of attempted suicide and the abuse of alcohol.\n\n\"The system over there, rather than protecting this woman who is an Irish citizen, chose instead to detain her, to charge her.\n\n\"She's now under the most incredible stress.\"\n\nRadha Stirling, founder of the Detained in Dubai group, said the support of the Irish people and the Irish Government had \"really warmed\" them and \"given them hope and inspiration\".\n\nShe said the case is due to be heard in court next week.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs said it was providing \"ongoing consular assistance\" in the case, as was Ireland's embassy in the United Arab Emirates.\n\nA statement said: \"The Irish ambassador to the UAE is in regular contact with our citizen (including this morning). Detained in Dubai\n\nTori Towey, the native of Co Roscommon who was facing charges and subject to a travel ban in Dubai after trying to flee her abusive husband, is now set to return home to Ireland.\n\n\"The charges against Tori Towey have been officially withdrawn by Dubai police and the travel ban lifted,\" Radha Stirling, the CEO of the advocacy group Detained in Dubai who had been assisting Towey, said on X today, Wednesday, July 10.\n\n\"Tori and her mother are both over the moon and we are ever grateful for widespread support of the public, the media, and the Irish government!\n\n\"We hope her transit at the airport will go smoothly and that no further attempts will be made to keep her in the country.\n\n\"Well done Ireland!\"\n\nThe charges against Tori Towey have been officially withdrawn by #Dubai police and the travel ban lifted. Tori and her mother are both over the moon and we are ever grateful for widespread support of the public, the media and the Irish government! We hope her transit at the... pic.twitter.com/QfzHpAfHMi -- Radha Stirling (@RadhaStirling)\n\nJuly 10, 2024\n\nTowey, 28, was severely abused by her husband in Dubai, where she moved last year after accepting a job with Emirates Airlines. During one of his attacks, he tore up the Irish woman's two passports.\n\nWhen Towey filed a police report and attempted to replace her passport, she learned that there was a travel ban against her, though she didn't know why. Detained in Dubai confirmed that \"it's commonplace for spouses to open pre-emptive cases against the victim to try to immunize themselves from their own criminal cases.\"\n\nTowey returned home to her husband, but the abuse did not subside.\n\nAccording to Detained in Dubai: \"Tori arranged to fly home to Ireland, but when she arrived at the airport, was told a case against her by her husband had been dropped but the travel ban remained.\n\n\"She attended the police station who assured her the travel ban would be lifted but it never happened.\n\n\"She was stuck.\"\n\nThe following day, her husband again launched into another rage. Towey believed he was going to kill her, as he had promised before.\n\n\"Feeling like there was no way out, Tori ran upstairs to the bathroom and wrapped an electrical lead around her neck,\" Detained in Dubai says.\n\n\"The next thing she remembers is an ambulance crew and police waking her up. She was taken to Al Barsha police station and kept for several hours before going home again.\n\n\"Her mother [Caroline] pleaded to the Irish Consulate, but in the absence of their assistance, boarded a flight to Dubai.\n\n\"When she arrived, she wasn't allowed to see Tori alone, her abuser wouldn't allow it. The three met at Emirates mall, then attended the prosecutor's office to find out what charges had been registered against her.\"\n\nTowey had been charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption. She was told nothing could be done and that the cases against her were going to court on July 18.\n\nLater that night, the husband went to the pub. When he returned home, he began verbally abusing Towey again and \"pushing her around.\"\n\nTowey and her mother packed her bags and left the home, \"this time for good.\"\n\nDetained in Dubai launched a campaign to raise awareness about Towey's plight this week, and Taoiseach Simon Harris vowed to intervene after the matter was raised to him by TDs Mary Lou McDonald and Claire Kerrane in the D\u00e1il yesterday, July 9.\n\nMyself and @ClaireKerrane raised the emergency case of Tori Towey with the Taoiseach seeking urgent intervention in her situation.\n\nThe system in Dubai, rather than protecting this Irish citizen chose to detain and charge her.\n\nShe wants to come home.\n\nThe Taoiseach must... pic.twitter.com/X9VF0afrbx -- Mary Lou McDonald (@MaryLouMcDonald)\n\nJuly 9, 2024\n\nOn Wednesday, McDonald announced on X that Towey's travel ban had been lifted and thanked people for their support.\n\nSpeaking with reporters not long later, McDonald said the situation raises \"fundamental questions about the treatment of women in Dubai.\"\n\nTori Towey will now travel home to Ireland. All of the support, all of the goodwill and all of the determination was felt very strongly by Tori and her mum Caroline.\n\nWe await her safe return to Ireland. Thank you to everybody for your support \u2764\ufe0f@MaryLouMcDonald pic.twitter.com/s17fpgyZ5v -- Sinn F\u00e9in (@sinnfeinireland)\n\nJuly 10, 2024\n\nThe Taoiseach received the news that Towey's travel ban had been lifted while in the D\u00e1il on Wednesday. the largest city in the UAE.\n\nRadha Stirling, a lawyer and human rights advocate who runs the Detained in Dubai group, said Ms Towey and her mother were \"over the moon\" at the news.\n\n\"We are ever grateful for widespread support of the public, the media and the Irish government,\" she wrote on X, formerly Twitter.\n\n\"We hope her transit at the airport will go smoothly and that no further attempts will be made to keep her in the country.\"\n\nThe BBC has approached the UAE government for comment on the case.\n\nTravel ban lifted\n\nEarlier, Taoiseach (Irish Prime Minister) Simon Harris said a travel ban preventing Ms Towey from leaving the UAE had been lifted.\n\n\"The embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go,\" he told the D\u00e1il (lower house of Irish parliament).\n\n\"The embassy will of course continue to follow up on the case which is still active as of now... and to thank our embassy for the work in relation to that\".\n\nPreviously the taoiseach said it was \"utterly, utterly unacceptable how an Irish citizen is being treated\".\n\nMr Harris also said he had spoken to Ms Towey and her mother, who is with her in the UAE.\n\nHe went on to say Ms Towey had \"been the victim of male violence\".\n\n\"What Tori has been through is, I think, unimaginable for so many people here in this country, that a woman who has been the victim of a brutal attack found herself waking up not in a hospital, but in a police station,\" he said.\n\n'Want to start a new chapter'\n\nOn Wednesday, Ann Flynn, Ms Towey's aunt, told BBC Radio Foyle's North West Today programme that Tori and her whole family had been through a huge ordeal but she hoped the end was now in sight.\n\n\"The travel ban being lifted is a huge relief, I didn't actually quite believe it when I heard it,\" Ms Flynn said.\n\n\"Hopefully they will be home tomorrow. They haven't actually got a flight sorted yet and we are just waiting to hear next steps.\"\n\nMs Flynn praised everyone who helped highlight her niece's case.\n\n\"When they arrive in Ireland, it will be such a relief,\" she said.\n\n\"We just want her home, we just want to start a new chapter with her.\"\n\nThe case came to international attention after it was raised by Sinn F\u00e9in leader Mary Lou McDonald in the D\u00e1il (Irish lower house of parliament) on Tuesday.\n\nShe said Ms Towey's mother had travelled to Dubai to be with her and that she \"wants to come home\".\n\n\"She has been the victim of the most gross domestic violence,\" Ms McDonald said.\n\n\"Her passport has been destroyed. There was a travel ban imposed on her.\"\n\nThe Irish government should make it \"absolutely plain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way\", Ms McDonald told the charged with 'attempted suicide' in Dubai", "body": "Warning: Some people may find some of the images contained within this article distressing\n\nPoliticians and campaigners are calling for the release of an Irish woman in Dubai after she was charged with \"attempting suicide\".\n\nTori Towey, from Boyle in County Roscommon, works in the United Arab Emirates as an airline cabin crew member and was left with severe bruising and other injuries after an alleged attack.\n\nFollowing the incident, the 28-year-old was taken to a police station where she charged with attempted suicide and abusing alcohol.\n\nBoth of which carry a lengthy prison sentence in the UAE.\n\nHer passport has since been blocked and she cannot return to Ireland.\n\nThe Taoiseach Simon Harris told the Dali that he is prepared to \"intervene\" in Ms Towey's case and \"support an Irish citizen\" under \"the most appalling circumstances\".\n\nHarris said he wasn't initially aware of the case, but after being told by Sinn Fein leader Mary Lou McDonald that Ms Towey was \"under incredible stress\", he would work to see how she could be helped.\n\nTori's mother Caroline has travelled to Dubai to stay with Ms Towey and the campaign group Detained in Dubai is assisting the family with their efforts to get her home.\n\nThe case against Ms Towey will be heard in court on July 18.\n\nHuman rights advocate and lawyer Radha Stirling, who runs Detained in Dubai, said: \"Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive.\n\n\"Strangely, the UAE has gone to great public relations efforts to promote alcohol as legal in the country. In reality, people are still regularly charged with alcohol consumption and possession.\"\n\nWriting on X, Stirling has said Dubai authorities have offered to provide Ms Towey with a lawyer but that \"Dubai police should just drop the charges at this point. Tori did not deserve to be charged in the first place and should be allowed to go home immediately.\"\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs told the PA news agency on Wednesday it was providing \"ongoing consular assistance\" in the case, as was Ireland's embassy in the United Arab Emirates.\n\n\"The Irish ambassador to the UAE is in regular contact with our citizen (including this morning). The embassy is also engaging with all the relevant authorities in UAE on the case,\" the department said.\n\n\"Officials will continue to provide advice and consular assistance.\"\n\nITV News has {"uri": "8218680677", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:20:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:20:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:20:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/morenews/uknews/2024/07/10/premier-says-travel-ban-imposed-on-irish-woman-in-dubai-has-been-lifted/", "title": "Premier says travel ban imposed on Irish woman in Dubai has been lifted", "body": "Irish premier Simon Harris has said that a travel ban imposed by Dubai authorities on Irish woman Tori Towey, who was reportedly charged with attempted suicide, has been lifted.\n\nTori Towey, 28, a flight attendant from Co Roscommon, was charged with attempted suicide and alcohol abuse after waking up in a police station after an attack, Irish parliamentarians were told.\n\nDubai authorities had also banned her from leaving the state, the Dail chamber heard.\n\nHe thanked the Irish embassy in the United Arab Emirates for their work on the case.\n\nMary Lou McDonald, the leader of Ireland's main opposition party Sinn Fein, had raised the case in the Irish parliament on Wednesday for the second day in a row, criticising what she said was the \"medieval, grotesque treatment of women\" in the United Arab Emirates.\n\n\"(Tori) does not belong to Dubai, she belongs at home in Ireland,\" Ms McDonald said.\n\nThe Taoiseach thanked Ms McDonald and Roscommon TD Claire Kerrane for raising the \"distressing\" case and said she had spoken to Ms Towey and her mother Caroline, who is with her in Dubai.\n\nHe said the Irish embassy in the United Arab Emirates has been in constant contact with Ms Towey.\n\n\"We want Tori Towey back in this country, we want her back home in Roscommon,\" Mr Harris said.\n\n\"No effort will be spared by us, by Ireland, to make progress on this matter, to get Tori home. She's not a criminal, she's a victim of gender-based violence.\"\n\nMr Harris said he had spoken to Ireland's deputy premier Micheal Martin, who is the Minister of Foreign Affairs, and Ireland's ambassador to the United Arab Emirates.\n\nHer aunt Ann Flynn said both were trying to stay positive.\n\n\"They're very nervous and can't wait to get home,\" she told RTE's Morning Ireland.\n\n\"It's really terrible that this has happened to a young woman that was full of life, full of adventure, she loved travelling.\"\n\nRadha Stirling, founder of the Detained in Dubai group, said the support of the Irish people and the Irish Government had \"really warmed\" them and \"given them hope and inspiration\".\n\nShe said the case is due to be heard in court next week.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs told the PA news agency on Wednesday it was providing \"ongoing consular assistance\" in the case, as was Ireland's embassy in the United Arab Emirates.\n\n\"The Irish ambassador to the UAE is in regular contact with our citizen (including this morning). The embassy is also engaging with all the relevant authorities in UAE on the case,\" the department said.\n\n\"Officials will continue to provide advice and consular assistance.\"", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8218397398", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "09:28:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T09:28:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T09:28:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.irishcentral.com/news/tori-towey-irish-dubai", "title": "Roscommon woman trapped in Dubai after trying to flee abusive husband", "body": "Tori Towey, a native of Co Roscommon who was a flight attendant for Emirates Airlines, is facing charges in Dubai after she attempted to take her own life after sustaining abuse from her husband.\n\nTowey, 28, has been charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption and faces a potentially lengthy prison sentence in Dubai.\n\nAccording to the advocacy group Detained in Dubai, which is assisting Towey, the Irish woman moved to Dubai just over a year ago when she was offered a job with Emirates Airlines.\n\nShe quickly married a man from South Africa whom she met through work, but he \"began a campaign of physical, psychological and financial abuse.\"\n\nTowey's mother Caroline, who is now in Dubai with her daughter, told Detained in Dubai: \"He cut her off from her friends and family.\n\nTowey's husband became \"out of control,\" Detained in Dubai states. In one instance, after he was thrown out of the bar for causing \"havoc,\" he launched a \"horrific\" attack on Towey that involved physical abuse.\n\nHe ripped up Towey's two passports during the hours-long \"torture,\" which only ended when some neighbors intervened.\n\nAfterward, Towey, who sustained frightening injuries, filed a police report and Emirates Airlines gave her time off to recover.\n\nHowever, when Towey attempted to replace her passport, she learned that there was a travel ban against her, though she didn't know why. Detained in Dubai confirmed that \"it's commonplace for spouses to open pre-emptive cases against the victim to try to immunize themselves from their own criminal cases.\"\n\nTowey returned home to her husband with the hope that the abuse would stop, similar to so many other abuse victims.\n\nWhen Emirates Airlines fired the husband for \"behavioral issues,\" he began to use Towey's credit cards excessively. Upon noticing, Towey put a stop on her cards, knowing that high debts can lead to travel bans and jail time in Dubai.\n\nTowey predicted that her husband would become enraged with the financial cutoff, so she left their home for a few days and stayed in a hotel that her mother had arranged for her.\n\nWhen Towey returned home, there was relative peace, but it was short-lived.\n\nAccording to Detained in Dubai: \"Tori arranged to fly home to Ireland, but when she arrived at the airport, was told a case against her by her husband had been dropped but the travel ban remained.\n\n\"She attended the police station who assured her the travel ban would be lifted but it never happened.\n\nThe following day, her husband again launched into another rage. Towey believed he was going to kill her, as he had promised before.\n\n\"Feeling like there was no way out, Tori ran upstairs to the bathroom and wrapped an electrical lead around her neck,\" Detained in Dubai says.\n\n\"The next thing she remembers is an ambulance crew and police waking her up. She was taken to Al Barsha police station and kept for several hours before going home again.\n\n\"Her mother pleaded to the Irish Consulate, but in the absence of their assistance, boarded a flight to Dubai.\n\n\"When she arrived, she wasn't allowed to see Tori alone, her abuser wouldn't allow it. The three met at Emirates mall, then attended the prosecutor's office to find out what charges had been registered against her.\"\n\nTowey had been charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption. She was told nothing could be done and that the cases against her were going to court on July 18.\n\nLater that night, the husband went to the pub. When he returned home, he began verbally abusing Towey again and \"pushing her around.\"\n\nTowey and her mother packed her bags and left the home, \"this time for good.\"\n\nRadha Stirling, CEO of Detained in Dubai, has criticized Emirates Airlines, the Irish Embassy, and the UAE medical and police services for their handling of the situation.\n\nStirling said on Tuesday: \"We are calling on Dubai authorities to urgently drop the charges against Tori, remove the travel ban, and let her fly home to Ireland with her mother.\n\n\"We are also calling on Ireland's Taoiseach (Prime Minister) Simon Harris, the head of Foreign Affairs Miche\u00e1l Martin, Ambassador Alison Milton, and local TDs Michael Fitzmaurice, Claire Kerrane, and Denis Naughten, as well as the UAE's Ambassador to Ireland, H.E. Mohammed Hmoud Hamad Rahma Alshamsi to help bring Tori home.\"\n\nTowey's situation was raised in the D\u00e1il on Tuesday by TD Mary Lou McDonald.\n\n\"The system over there, rather than protecting this woman, who is an Irish citizen, chose instead to detain her and charge her,\" McDonald said during Leaders Questions on Tuesday.\n\n\"She is now under the most incredible stress.\"\n\nMcDonald, who said she spoke with Towey's mother that day, continued: \"Tori wants to come home. It is as simple as that. She is a Roscommon woman, and she wants to come home.\n\n\"I am asking that, as a matter of absolute urgency, that we have a statement from this House; that the Taoiseach will intervene; that the ambassador is called in and; that it is made plain to the authorities in Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way and that an Irish citizen, an Irish woman, will not be treated in this way.\"\n\nMyself and @ClaireKerrane raised the emergency case of Tori Towey with the Taoiseach seeking urgent intervention in her situation.\n\nThe system in Dubai, rather than protecting this Irish citizen chose to detain and charge her.\n\nShe wants to come home.\n\nThe Taoiseach must... pic.twitter.com/X9VF0afrbx -- Mary Lou McDonald (@MaryLouMcDonald)\n\nJuly 9, 2024\n\nResponding in the D\u00e1il, the Taoiseach thanked McDonald for raising the matter and said it was his understanding that TD Kerrane had raised the matter with the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Tanaiste Miche\u00e1l Martin.\n\n\"I am not directly apprised of the situation but I am very happy to be directly apprised of it now and to work with Deputy McDonald to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be, from Deputy McDonald has told me, the most appalling of circumstances,\" the Taoiseach said, adding that he would be happy to engage directly with McDonald on the situation.\n\nIreland's Department of Foreign Affairs says it is aware of the case and is providing consular assistance.", "source": {"uri": "irishcentral.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Irish {"uri": "2024-07-417491558", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:26:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:26:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:47:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/news/irish-air-hostess-charged-attempting-085435899.html", "title": "Irish air hostess charged with attempting suicide in Dubai heading home after travel ban is lifted", "body": "Irish air hostess charged with attempting suicide in Dubai heading home after travel ban is lifted\n\nLydia Chantler-Hicks\n\n10 July 2024 at 2:47 pm\n\nAn Irish air hostess charged by police in Dubai with attempting to take her own life after she was allegedly attacked in her home has had her travel ban lifted by the authorities.\n\nTori Towey, an Emirates Airlines employee from Co Roscommon in Ireland, was reportedly attacked in her own home in Dubai across \"several hours\", leaving her with injuries that needed hospital treatment.\n\nPhotos showed her with severe bruises on her arms, and bruising to the face.\n\nShe reportedly returned home after the assault but the violence continued, and Ms Towey attempted suicide.\n\nEmergency services responded and the 28-year-old was taken to a police station in Dubai, where she was charged with \"attempted suicide and alcohol consumption\".\n\nHer passport was also reportedly blocked, meaning she is unable to return home to Ireland.\n\nMs Towey was understood to be staying in a rented apartment in Dubai with her mother, who flew out to be with her following the ordeal.\n\nAs her case was due before court in the UAE on July 18, she earlier pleaded for Irish authorities to intervene and help get her home.\n\n\"I'm glad I'm with my mother now but I don't know what's going to happen in court next week,\" she told The Sun.\n\n\"I'm desperate to go home to Ireland and put all of this in the past. I'm asking the Taoiseach to please help us.\"Her mother Caroline urged the Taoiseach, Department of Foreign Affairs, and British embassy \"to please do everything to get my daughter home safely\".\n\n\"She's been through the worst time of her life and needs to come home with me and heal,\" she told the Sun.\n\nIn a major development, Irish premier Simon Harris revealed on Wednesday that Dubai's travel ban on Ms Towey has now been lifted.\n\nAddressing the Irish parliament on Wednesday afternoon, Mr Harris said: \"I've just been informed that the travel ban has been lifted, that the embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go and that the embassy of course will continue to follow up on the case, which is still active as of now.\"\n\nSinn F\u00e9in leader Mary Lou McDonald had earlier intervened in the case.\n\nShe told the D\u00e1il, Ireland's lower house of parliament, on Tuesday that Ms Towey had been the victim of the \"most gross violence\".\n\n\"Her passport has been destroyed. There was a travel ban imposed on her.\"\n\nRadhi Stirling, a legal expert at Detained in Dubai who is working on Ms Towey's case, said: \"We are calling on Dubai authorities to urgently drop the charges against Tori, remove the travel ban and let her fly home to Ireland with her mother.\n\n\"It's outrageous, it's broken,\" she added.\n\nMs Towey's aunt Ann Flynn on Wednesday said both were trying to stay positive.\n\nMs Stirling said the support of the Irish Government had \"really warmed\" them and \"given them hope and inspiration\".\n\n\"Right now she's just happy to be with her mother in safety. It's all very recent,\" Ms Stirling added.\n\nIrish premier Simon Harris has reportedly agreed \"to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be...the most appalling circumstances\".\n\nIf you're struggling and need to talk, the Samaritans operate a free helpline open 24/7 on 116 123. {"uri": "8217418344", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "17:48:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T17:48:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T17:47:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/tori-towey-irish-woman-charged-173900737.html", "title": "Tori Towey: Irish woman charged with attempting suicide in Dubai", "body": "The Irish government is being urged to intervene in the case of a woman who has been charged with attempting suicide by a court in Dubai.\n\nTori Towey, from Boyle in County Roscommon, works in the United Arab Emirates as an airline cabin crew member and says she tried to take her own life after allegedly being attacked and left with severe bruising and other injuries.\n\nThe 28-year-old survived the suicide attempt, but was taken to a police station where she was told she was being charged with attempted suicide and abusing alcohol. Her passport was blocked from use, and she cannot return to Ireland.\n\n\"She's under incredible stress\", said Sinn Fein leader Mary Lou McDonald in the Irish parliament today. \"Tori is a Roscommon woman, and she wants to come home.\"\n\nMs McDonald urged the Irish prime minister Simon Harris to \"urgently intervene\" in the case and ensure that Ms Towey could return to Ireland.\n\nMr Harris told the Irish parliament that he was not full appraised of the case, but would be happy to work with Ms McDonald and others \"to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be, based on what you tell me, the most appalling circumstances\".\n\nIreland's department of foreign affairs told Sky News it is \"aware of the case and is providing consular assistance\".\n\nIt added: \"As with all consular cases, the department does not comment on the details of individual cases.\"\n\nMs Towey is currently staying in a rented property in Dubai with her mother Caroline, who travelled to be with her daughter. The family are being assisted by the Detained in Dubai advocacy group.\n\n\"We are calling on Dubai authorities to urgently drop the charges against Tori, remove the travel ban and let her fly home to Ireland with her mother\", said Radha Stirling, CEO of Detained in Dubai.\n\n\"She has been charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption', said Ms Stirling.\n\n\"Strangely, the UAE has gone to great public relations efforts to promote alcohol as legal in the country. In reality, people are still regularly charged with alcohol consumption and possession.\n\n\"Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive.\"\n\nMs Towey is now expecting her case to be heard in court on 18 July, and has been warned she could face potential prison time in Dubai.\n\nSky News has contacted the Dubai Media Office and the Embassy of the United Arab Emirates in Dublin for comment.\n\nNeither have currently offered a response.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8217971473", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "04:10:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T04:10:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:09:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.dublinlive.ie/news/world-news/irish-airline-stewardess-faces-jail-29510845", "title": "Irish stewardess stranded in Dubai facing jail after trying to take her own life", "body": "WARNING: DISTRESSING IMAGES Irish woman Tori Towey faces charges in Dubai of alcohol consumption and attempted suicide after she was the alleged victim of a brutal attack in her home.\n\nAn Irish air hostess is trapped in Dubai facing charges of consuming alcohol and attempted suicide.\n\nTaoiseach Simon Harris has promised to step in to assist Tori Towey, 28, from County Roscommon. Activists argue that Tori stands accused of violating severe laws in the predominantly Muslim nation despite being a victim of an alleged assault inside her own residence.\n\nSinn Fein leader Mary Lou McDonald identified Ms Towey's husband as the supposed perpetrator last Tuesday, declaring she was suffering from the \"most gross domestic violence\". Human rights advocates reveal that post receiving hospital treatment for serious bruising and further injuries, she wished to exit the Middle Eastern country but was apprehended.\n\nRead more: Spain tourists blast 'unacceptable' scenes as holidaymakers targeted by protesters\n\nRead more: Taxi driver Raymond Shorten convicted of raping girl, 7, days after her mum's funeral\n\nCampaign group, Detained in Dubai, issued a warning that Tori could be looking at serving time in a prison infamous for \"human rights abuses and torture\". It urged the Irish government to step in, demanding they fight for the charges to be withdrawn, reports the Irish Mirror.\n\nTo this grim scenario, the Taoiseach vowed to \"intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen\" caught up in the \"most appalling circumstances\". Deputy Lou McDonald brought forward this distressing case after conversing with Tori herself. Additionally, she informed the Dail that \"her passport has been destroyed\" and added that a \"travel ban was imposed on her\".\n\nSinn Fein President Mary Lou McDonald has spoken out about the harrowing experience of an Irish woman in Dubai, stating: \"Following one particularly severe beating in which her husband repeatedly tried to break her arm, Tori escaped upstairs and she attempted to take her own life. Tori now faces charges in Dubai of attempted suicide and the abuse of alcohol.\"\n\n\"The system over there, rather than protecting this woman, who is an Irish citizen, chose instead to detain her, to charge her. She's now under the most incredible stress. I spoke to her. Her mother Caroline has travelled to be with her. Tori wants to come home, simple as that. She's a Roscommon woman. She wants to come home.\"\n\nMcDonald continued, pressing for immediate action: \"I'm asking now, as a matter of absolute urgency, that we have a statement from this House; that you intervene, Taoiseach; that the Ambassador comes in and that you explain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way. That an Irish citizen, an Irish woman will not be treated in this way.\"\n\nAdding her voice to the call for intervention, Roscommon TD Claire Kerrane demanded that Tori be allowed to return to Ireland, expressing her concern online: \"This is absolutely frightening. I have been in touch with [Tanaiste] Micheal Martin and I will be raising this in the Dail. The Government needs to intervene on this urgently.\n\n\"Tori Towey must be released and allowed to return home to Roscommon urgently. This young woman has been treated in the most horrific way and simply wants to go home. I am determined to work with the Ambassador, Foreign Affairs Minister, and anyone necessary to ensure that her release is secured without delay.\"\n\nShocking images have surfaced online showing Tori, originally from Boyle in Roscommon, displaying severe bruising on her arms. Radha Stirling, the chief of Detained in Dubai, informed the Irish Mirror: \"Tori and her mother are in Dubai and it's illegal for them to talk to the media.\"\n\nFurther support comes from local political figures, as Stirling noted: \"Their local TD has committed to help. Deputy Kerrane responded in record time for calls to help. So heartwarming to see such support. We need Tori home in Ireland.\"\n\nExpressing gratitude, Stirling relayed a message to Deputy Kerrane: \"You are a gem. I've passed [your support] on to Tori and her mum and they are ever thankful.\"\n\nTori, a graduate of Dublin Institute of Technology, relocated to Dubai in April last year to join Emirates Airlines. Following alleged assaults, she attempted to leave Dubai, but her ordeal continued, as detailed by Stirling.\n\nStirling recounted the harrowing experience: \"The thing she remembers is an ambulance crew and police waking her up. She was taken to Al Barsha police station and kept for several hours. Her mother pleaded to the Irish Consulate, but in the absence of their assistance, she boarded a flight to Dubai.\n\n\"Tori arranged to fly home to Ireland but when she arrived at the airport, she was told there was a travel ban. She attended the police station. She was assured that the travel ban would be lifted, but it never happened. She was stuck. Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and, quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive.\"\n\nThe situation could have been handled better, as Stirling continues: \"The Irish Embassy and the UAE medical and police services could certainly have done more to help Tori. She was moments from death.\" Stirling also pointed out the urgency of Tori's case as her court appearance approaches: \"The case against her is going to court on July 18. She has been charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\"\n\nFinally, she made an urgent appeal for action: \"We are calling on Dubai authorities to urgently drop the charges against Tori, remove the travel ban, and let her fly home to Ireland with her mother. We are also calling on Ireland's Taoiseach Simon Harris, the head of Foreign Affairs Micheal Martin, ambassador Alison Milton, and local TDs to help bring Tori home.\"\n\nSign up to the Dublin Live Newsletter to get all the latest Dublin news straight to your inbox.\n\nFor all the latest news from Dublin and surrounding areas visit our homepage.\n\nJoin our Dublin Live breaking news service on WhatsApp. Click this link to receive your daily dose of Dublin Live content. Campaigners claim that Tori is accused of breaking strict laws in the Muslim country - even though she is the victim of an alleged attack in her home. Sinn F\u00e9in leader Mary Lou McDonald named Ms Towey's husband as her alleged attacker on Tuesday and said she was the victim of the \"most gross domestic violence\".\n\nHuman rights campaigners said that she wanted to leave the Middle Eastern state after receiving hospital treatment for severe bruising and other injuries - but was detained.\n\nREAD MORE: James McClean's daughter in hospital after 'taking turn for the worst'\n\nREAD MORE: Ryanair 'flight from hell' forced to divert after mass brawl breaks out over seat swapping\n\nCampaign group Detained in Dubai warned that Tori could now face a lengthy imprisonment in a jail that is notorious for \"human rights abuses and torture\". It urged Ireland to intervene, calling on the Government to fight to have the charges dropped.\n\nThe Taoiseach pledged to \"intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen\" in the \"most appalling circumstances\".\n\nDeputy Lou McDonald raised the harrowing case after speaking with Tori. She told the Dail that \"her passport has been destroyed\" and a \"travel ban was imposed on her\".\n\nThe Sinn Fein president said: \"Following one particularly severe beating in which her husband repeatedly tried to break her arm, Tori escaped upstairs and she attempted to take her own life. Tori now faces charges in Dubai of attempted suicide and the abuse of alcohol.\n\n\"The system over there, rather than protecting this woman, who is an Irish citizen, chose instead to detain her, to charge her. She's now under the most incredible stress. I spoke to her. Her mother Caroline has travelled to be with her. Tori wants to come home, simple as that. She's a Roscommon woman. She wants to come home.\"\n\nShe added: \"I'm asking now, as a matter of absolute urgency, that we have a statement from this House; that you intervene, Taoiseach; that the Ambassador comes in and that you explain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way. That an Irish citizen, an Irish woman will not be treated in this way.\"\n\nRoscommon TD Claire Kerrane also called for Tori to be allowed to travel home to Ireland. Deputy Kerrane posted online: \"This is absolutely frightening. I have been in touch with [Tanaiste] Miche\u00e1l Martin and I will be raising this in the D\u00e1il. The Government needs to intervene on this urgently.\"\n\nShe added: \"Tori Towey must be released and allowed to return home to Roscommon urgently. This young woman has been treated in the most horrific way and simply wants to go home. I am determined to work with the Ambassador, Foreign Affairs Minister, and anyone necessary to ensure that her release is secured without delay.\"\n\nImages online show Tori, whose family is originally from Boyle in Roscommon, holding up her arms to reveal extensive bruising. Detained in Dubai chief Radha Stirling told the Irish Mirror: \"Tori and her mother are in Dubai and it's illegal for them to talk to the media.\"\n\nShe added: \"Their local TD has committed to help. Deputy Kerrane responded in record time for calls to help. So heartwarming to see such support. We need Tori home in Ireland.\"\n\nShe told Deputy Kerrane: \"You are a gem. I've passed [your support] on to Tori and her mum and they are ever thankful.\"\n\nTori graduated from Dublin Institute of Technology and moved to Dubai in April last year to work with Emirates Airlines. After alleged attacks, Tori tried to leave Dubai, according to Detained in Dubai chief Stirling.\n\nShe said: \"The thing she remembers is an ambulance crew and police waking her up. She was taken to Al Barsha police station and kept for several hours. Her mother pleaded to the Irish Consulate, but in the absence of their assistance, she boarded a flight to Dubai.\"\n\nStirling added: \"Tori arranged to fly home to Ireland but when she arrived at the airport, she was told there was a travel ban. She attended the police station. She was assured that the travel ban would be lifted, but it never happened. She was stuck. Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and, quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive.\"\n\nShe continued: \"The Irish Embassy and the UAE medical and police services could certainly have done more to help Tori. She was moments from death.\"\n\nThe Detained in Dubai group wants the charges against Tori dropped before her case reaches court next Thursday. Its chief Stirling said: \"The case against her is going to court on July 18. She has been charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\"\n\nShe added: \"We are calling on Dubai authorities to urgently drop the charges against Tori, remove the travel ban, and let her fly home to Ireland with her mother. We are also calling on Ireland's Taoiseach Simon Harris, the head of Foreign Affairs Miche\u00e1l Martin, ambassador Alison Milton, and local TDs to help bring Tori home.\"\n\nJoin the Irish Mirror's breaking news service on WhatsApp. Click this link to receive breaking news and the latest headlines direct to your phone. {"uri": "8218310288", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "08:33:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T08:33:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T08:33:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/flight-attendant-faces-dubai-jail-33207759", "title": "Flight attendant faces Dubai jail after being 'attacked in her own home'", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nAn air hostess is facing prison in Dubai after allegedly being left 'moments from death' following an attack by her husband at home.\n\nTori Towey, 28, from Co Roscommon in Ireland, is accused of violating strict laws in the Muslim country, despite the fact she was the victim of an alleged assault. Sinn Fein party leader Mary Lou McDonald identified Ms Towey's husband as the alleged perpetrator on Tuesday, July 9, stating that she was a victim of \"the most gross domestic violence\".\n\nHuman rights activists reported that Tori wanted to leave the United Arab Emirates after receiving hospital treatment for severe bruising and other injuries, but was held back. She was then charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\n\nCampaign group Detained in Dubai warned that Tori could now face a long-term imprisonment in a jail infamous for \"human rights abuses and torture,\" and have called on the government in Dublin to step in and fight to have the charges dismissed, reports the Mirror.\n\nDisturbing images have surfaced online showing Tori with severe bruising on her arms.\n\nRadha Stirling, the chief of Detained in Dubai, told the Irish Mirror: \"We need Tori home in Ireland.\"\n\nAfter graduating from Dublin Institute of Technology, Tori moved to Dubai in April last year to join Emirates Airlines, but following alleged assaults, Tori attempted to leave Dubai, according to Radha Stirling.\n\nDescribing what happened to her next, Ms Stirling said: \"The thing she remembers is an ambulance crew and police waking her up. She was taken to Al Barsha police station and kept for several hours. Her mother pleaded to the Irish Consulate, but in the absence of their assistance, she boarded a flight to Dubai .\n\n\"Tori arranged to fly home to Ireland but when she arrived at the airport, she was told there was a travel ban. She attended the police station. She was assured that the travel ban would be lifted, but it never happened. She was stuck. Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and, quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive. The Irish Embassy and the UAE medical and police services could certainly have done more to help Tori. She was moments from death.\"\n\nThe Irish Taoiseach Simon Harris vowed to \"intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen\" in the \"most appalling circumstances\".\n\nOpposition leader Mary Lou McDonald from the Sinn Fein party brought up the distressing case after speaking with Tori, and informed the Irish national parliament that the woman's \"passport has been destroyed\" and a \"travel ban was imposed on her\".\n\nShe has spoken out about Tori's harrowing situation and said it had all led her to attempt suicide.\n\nMs McDonald said: \"Following one particularly severe beating in which her husband repeatedly tried to break her arm, Tori escaped upstairs and she attempted to take her own life. Tori now faces charges in Dubai of attempted suicide and the abuse of alcohol.\n\n\"The system over there, rather than protecting this woman, who is an Irish citizen, chose instead to detain her, to charge her. She's now under the most incredible stress. I spoke to her. Her mother Caroline has travelled to be with her. Tori wants to come home, simple as that. She's a Roscommon woman. She wants to come home.\"\n\nShe has demanded immediate action, and added: \"I'm asking now, as a matter of absolute urgency, that we have a statement from this House; that you intervene, Taoiseach; that the Ambassador comes in and that you explain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way. That an Irish citizen, an Irish woman will not be treated in this way.\"\n\nDetained in Dubai has pleaded for charges to be dismissed prior to Tori's court date next Thursday. Ms Stirling said: \"The case against her is going to court on July 18. She has been charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\"\n\nShe added: \"We are calling on Dubai authorities to urgently drop the charges against Tori, remove the travel ban, and let her fly home to Ireland with her mother. We are also calling on Ireland's Taoiseach Simon Harris, the head of Foreign Affairs Miche\u00e1l Martin, ambassador Alison Milton, and local TDs to help bring Tori home.\"\n\nDon't miss the latest news from around Scotland and beyond. There was a travel ban imposed on her.\"\n\n\"Following one particularly severe beating in which her husband repeatedly tried to slam doors on her arms and break her limbs, she escaped upstairs, and she attempted to take her own life.\"\n\nMs Towey is now facing charges \"of attempted suicide and the abuse of alcohol,\" the deputy said, and \"is now under the most incredible stress\".\n\n\"Her mother, Caroline has traveled to be with her.\"\n\nMs McDonald said that \"as a matter of urgency\" the Government must make it \"absolutely plain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be {"uri": "2024-07-416753228", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "22:36:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T22:36:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T22:19:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/news/irish-woman-charged-attempting-suicide-221936195.html", "title": "Irish woman charged with 'attempting suicide' by Dubai court", "body": "Irish woman charged with 'attempting suicide' by Dubai court\n\nNadeem Badshah\n\n10 July 2024 at 0:19 am\n\nA 28-year-old woman from Ireland has been charged with \"attempting suicide\" by a court in Dubai, with politicians and campaigners calling for her release.\n\nTori Towey, who works in the United Arab Emirates as an airline cabin crew member, said she tried to take her own life after allegedly being attacked and left with severe bruising and other injuries in a domestic violence incident.\n\nTowey, from Boyle in County Roscommon, was taken to a police station where she was told she was being charged with attempted suicide and abusing alcohol.\n\nThe Sinn F\u00e9in leader, Mary Lou McDonald, who has been supporting her, told the parliament in Ireland on Tuesday that Towey's passport was blocked and she cannot return to Ireland.\n\nSimon Harris, the taoiseach, told the D\u00e1il he is ready to \"intervene\" in the case. Harris said he was not aware of the case but noted that her plight had been raised with the minister for foreign affairs by Sinn F\u00e9in.\n\nRelated: Ex-Royal Marines reservist held in Dubai on spying charges\n\nThe taoiseach, who was responding to a question from McDonald, said: \"Thank you, deputy McDonald, for bringing the case of Tori to my attention,\" RT\u00c9 reported.\n\n\"I'm not directly apprised of the situation, but I'm very happy to be directly apprised of it now,\" he added.\n\nHarris added he would work with the deputy \"to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be - based on what you tell me - the most appalling circumstances\".\n\nIreland's department of foreign affairs told Sky News it is \"aware of the case and is providing consular assistance\".\n\nIt added: \"As with all consular cases, the department does not comment on the details of individual cases.\"\n\nMcDonald told parliament: \"She's under incredible stress.\n\n\"Tori is a Roscommon woman, and she wants to come home.\"\n\nTowey, who moved to Dubai in April 2023, is staying in a rented property with her mother, Caroline, who travelled to be with her daughter.\n\nThe case against the cabin crew employee will be heard in court on 18 July.\n\nRadha Stirling, CEO of the Detained in Dubai advocacy group, which is supporting the family, said it is calling on the country's authorities to drop the charges, remove the travel ban and let Towey fly home with her mother.\n\nRelated: Dubai influencer fined \u20ac1,800 for trespassing on Sardinia's pink beach\n\nShe added: \"She has been charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\n\n\"Strangely, the UAE has gone to great public relations efforts to promote alcohol as legal in the country. In reality, people are still regularly charged with alcohol consumption and possession.\n\n\"Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive.\"\n\nStirling wrote on X that Michael Fitzmaurice, Teachta D\u00e1la of Ireland, told her that he has made representations to the UAE's ambassador to Ireland and the department of foreign affairs.\n\nThe UAE government has been approached for comment.\n\n* In the UK, call the national domestic abuse helpline on 0808 2000 247, or visit Women's Aid. In the US, the domestic violence hotline is 1-800-799-SAFE (7233). In Australia, the national family violence counselling service is on 1800 737 732.
