{"uri": "8218193079", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "07:15:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T07:15:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T07:15:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://metro.co.uk/2024/07/10/air-steward-28-dubai-charged-attempted-suicide-domestic-abuse-21197177/", "title": "Flight attendant, 28, charged with trying to end her life in Dubai after 'attack'", "body": "An Irish air hostess is trapped in Dubai after being charged with trying to end her life following alleged domestic abuse.\n\nTori Towey, 28, from Boyle in County Roscommon, claims she was attacked in her home and is now banned from leaving the state.\n\nHer husband lunged at her with a knife before punching her and using the bathroom door to try and smash her arm, according to legal group Detained in Dubai (DiD).\n\nA spokesperson for the group claims the Emirates cabin crew member then tried to take her own life after the assault, which left her with severe bruising.\n\nShe has now been charged with alcohol consumption and attempting suicide and is unable to return home after her passport was blocked.\n\nSpeaking to the Irish Sun from a rented property where she is staying with her mum Caroline, Tori said: 'I'm glad I'm with my mother now but I don't know what's going to happen in court next week.\n\n'I'm desperate to go home to Ireland and put all of this in the past. I'm asking the Taoiseach to please help us.'\n\nRadha Stirling, CEO of Detained in Dubai, said: 'We are calling on Dubai authorities to urgently drop the charges against Tori, remove the travel ban and let her fly home to Ireland with her mother.\n\n'She has been charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption\", said Ms Stirling.\n\n'Strangely, the UAE has gone to great public relations efforts to promote alcohol as legal in the country. In reality, people are still regularly charged with alcohol consumption and possession.\n\n'Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive.'\n\nSinn Fein president Mary Lou McDonald raised Ms Towey's case in the Irish Parliament on Tuesday afternoon.\n\n'Tori wants to come home, simple as that. She is a Roscommon woman, and she wants to come home,' she said.\n\n'I am asking now, as a matter of absolute urgency, that we have a statement from this House, that you intervene Taoiseach, that the ambassador is called and that it is made absolutely plain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way, and an Irish citizen, an Irish woman will not be treated in this way.'\n\nIrish premier Simon Harris responded saying he was not aware of Ms Towey's case, and thanked Ms McDonald for bringing it to his attention and that of the Minister of Foreign Affairs Micheal Martin.\n\nHe pledged to work 'to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be, based on what you tell me, the most appalling circumstances'.\n\nTori's case is expected in court on July 18, and she has been warned she faces a possible jail term, Sky News reports.\n\nTalking to Sky News, her aunt Ann Flynn said: 'She's doing her best.'\n\nShe added: 'It's very stressful, it's stressful for all the family.' She described her niece as 'a beautiful young woman' who is 'fun-loving and loved to travel'.\n\nMs Flynn said: 'She got the job of her dreams working for Emirates, and she could continue travelling with work. She loved Dubai, and had a good network of friends there.'\n\nMORE : Five mysteries surrounding Jay Slater's disappearance as family claim 'everything stinks'", "source": {"uri": "metro.co.uk", Activists argue that despite being a victim of an alleged assault in her own home, Tori is accused of breaking strict laws in the predominantly Muslim country.\n\nSinn Fein leader Mary Lou McDonald named Ms Towey's husband as the alleged attacker last Tuesday, stating she was a victim of \"the most gross domestic violence\". Human rights advocates reveal that after receiving hospital treatment for severe bruising and other injuries, she tried to leave the Middle Eastern country but was detained.\n\nRead more: NI mum's baby and sister killed by drunk driver taking picture driving at 141mph\n\nRead more: I flew with Ryanair and saw so many passengers make the same \u00a346 mistake\n\nCampaign group Detained in Dubai warned that Tori could face time in a prison notorious for \"human rights abuses and torture\". It called on the Irish government to intervene and demand the charges be dropped, according to the Irish Mirror.\n\nIn response to the situation, the Taoiseach promised to \"intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen\" caught up in \"the most appalling circumstances\". Deputy Lou McDonald brought this distressing case to light after speaking with Tori herself, reports Dublin Live.\n\nShe also told the Dail that \"her passport has been destroyed\" and a \"travel ban was imposed on her\".\n\nSinn Fein President Mary Lou McDonald has voiced her concern over the distressing situation of an Irish woman in Dubai, stating: \"Following one particularly severe beating in which her husband repeatedly tried to break her arm, Tori escaped upstairs and she attempted to take her own life. Tori now faces charges in Dubai of attempted suicide and the abuse of alcohol.\"\n\n\"The system over there, rather than protecting this woman, who is an Irish citizen, chose instead to detain her, to charge her. She's now under the most incredible stress. I spoke to her. Her mother Caroline has travelled to be with her. Tori wants to come home, simple as that. She's a Roscommon woman. She wants to come home.\"\n\nMcDonald continued, urging for immediate action: \"I'm asking now, as a matter of absolute urgency, that we have a statement from this House; that you intervene, Taoiseach; that the Ambassador comes in and that you explain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way. That an Irish citizen, an Irish woman will not be treated in this way.\"\n\nEchoing the call for intervention, Roscommon TD Claire Kerrane demanded that Tori be allowed to return to Ireland, expressing her worry online: \"This is absolutely frightening. I have been in touch with [Tanaiste] Micheal Martin and I will be raising this in the Dail. The Government needs to intervene on this urgently.\"\n\n\"Tori Towey must be released and allowed to return home to Roscommon urgently. This young woman has been treated in the most horrific way and simply wants to go home. I am determined to work with the Ambassador, Foreign Affairs Minister, and anyone necessary to ensure that her release is secured without delay.\"\n\nDisturbing images have emerged online showing Tori, originally from Boyle in Roscommon, with severe bruising on her arms. Radha Stirling, the head of Detained in Dubai, told the Irish Mirror: \"Tori and her mother are in Dubai and it's illegal for them to talk to the media.\"\n\nFurther backing comes from local political figures, as Stirling highlighted: \"Their local TD has committed to help. Deputy Kerrane responded in record time for calls to help. So heartwarming to see such support. We need Tori home in Ireland.\"\n\nExpressing appreciation, Stirling passed on a message to Deputy Kerrane: \"You are a gem. I've passed [your support] on to Tori and her mum and they are ever thankful.\"\n\nTori, a graduate of Dublin Institute of Technology, moved to Dubai in April last year to join Emirates Airlines. After alleged assaults, she tried to leave Dubai, but her ordeal continued, as outlined by Stirling.\n\nStirling shared the troubling account: \"The thing she remembers is an ambulance crew and police waking her up. She was taken to Al Barsha police station and kept for several hours. Her mother pleaded to the Irish Consulate, but in the absence of their assistance, she boarded a flight to Dubai.\"\n\n\"Tori arranged to fly home to Ireland but when she arrived at the airport, she was told there was a travel ban. She attended the police station. She was assured that the travel ban would be lifted, but it never happened. She was stuck. Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and, quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive.\"\n\nStirling believed there were echoes of neglect throughout the entire situation: \"The Irish Embassy and the UAE medical and police services could certainly have done more to help Tori. She was moments from death.\"\n\nStirling also emphasised the severe urgency of Tori's case since her court appearance is imminent: \"The case against her is going to court on July 18. She has been charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\"\n\nStirling issued a heartfelt plea for swift action to aid in Tori's dire situation: \"We are calling on Dubai authorities to urgently drop the charges against Tori, remove the travel ban, and let her fly home to Ireland with her mother. We are also calling on Ireland's Taoiseach Simon Harris, the head of Foreign Affairs Micheal Martin, ambassador Alison Milton, and local TDs to help bring Tori home.\"\n\nFor all the latest news, {"uri": "8218420986", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "09:42:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T09:42:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T09:42:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.ladbible.com/news/world-news/tori-towey-ireland-woman-dubai-536719-20240710", "title": "Irish woman charged with 'attempting suicide' and banned from leaving Dubai after alleged attack", "body": "Warning: This article contains discussion of domestic violence and suicide which some readers may find distressing.\n\nAn Irish woman has been charged with 'attempting suicide' and banned from leaving Dubai after being the victim of an alleged attack.\n\nIt's reported that airline worker Tori Towey was attacked in her home and now cannot leave the state as the Irish premier pledges to intervene in her case.\n\nThe 28-year-old works over in the UAE as a cabin crew member and it's reported she tried to take her own life after allegedly being attacked. Left with severe bruising and other injuries, Towey survived but was taken to a police station.\n\nHere, she was charged with attempted suicide and abusing alcohol, resulting in her passport being blocked from use.\n\nSinn Fein president Mary Lou McDonald raised the airline worker's case in the Irish Parliament yesterday (9 July).\n\nAdding that Towey's mum has now travelled over to Dubai to be with her, she explained the woman has been the victim of domestic abuse.\n\n\"Tori wants to come home, simple as that. She is a Roscommon woman, and she wants to come home,\" she said.\n\n\"I am asking now, as a matter of absolute urgency, that we have a statement from this House, that you intervene Taoiseach, that the ambassador is called and that it is made absolutely plain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way, and an Irish citizen, an Irish woman will not be treated in this way.\"\n\nThe Irish premier, Simon Harris, said he wasn't aware of Towey's case but thanked McDonald for bringing it to his attention.\n\nHe said he would be happy to work with her and others 'to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be, based on what you tell me, the most appalling circumstances'.\n\nTowey and her mother are currently staying in a rental in Dubai with the family receiving assistance from the Detained In Dubai advocacy group.\n\nCEO of the group, Radha Stirling, said: \"Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive.\"\n\nShe claimed that the woman was 'moments from death either by suicide or at the hands of her violent rage driven husband'.\n\nDetained in Dubai is now: \"Calling on Dubai authorities to urgently drop the charges against Tori, remove the travel ban and let her fly home to Ireland with her mother.\"\n\nA spokesperson for Ireland's Department of Foreign Affairs told LADbible: \"The Department of Foreign Affairs and the Embassy of Ireland to the UAE are providing ongoing consular assistance in relation to this case.\n\n\"The Irish Ambassador to the UAE is in regular contact with our citizen (including this morning). The Embassy is also engaging with all the relevant authorities in UAE on the case. Officials will continue to provide advice and consular assistance.\"\n\nIf you are experiencing domestic violence, please know that you are not alone. She is now under the most incredible stress.\"\n\nMs McDonald said Ms Towey had been charged with attempted suicide and using alcohol in Dubai. Consuming alcohol is still largely illegal outside of licensed premises such as hotels.\n\nSimon Harris, the Taoiseach (prime minister), called the situation \"the most appalling of circumstances\" and said he would work with Ms McDonald to intervene and support Ms Towey.\n\nMs Towey's mother has travelled to Dubai to be with her daughter, who will appear in court on July 18, according to Radha Stirling, the head of advocacy group Detained in Dubai.\n\n\"Without diplomatic intervention from the Irish government, Tori faces months of hearings which could end with her lengthy and unfair detention,\" Ms Stirling said.\n\nMs McDonald said Ms Towey, who comes from Roscommon in Ireland's north-west, wanted to come home.\n\nMs McDonald requested that the UAE ambassador be called to give Harris said he was not aware of the case but noted that her plight had been raised with the minister for foreign affairs by Sinn F\u00e9in.\n\nRelated: Ex-Royal Marines reservist held in Dubai on spying charges\n\nThe taoiseach, who was responding to a question from McDonald, said: \"Thank you, deputy McDonald, for bringing the case of Tori to my attention,\" RT\u00c9 reported.\n\n\"I'm not directly apprised of the situation, but I'm very happy to be directly apprised of it now,\" he added.\n\nHarris added he would work with the deputy \"to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be - based on what you tell me - the most appalling circumstances\".\n\nIreland's department of foreign affairs told Sky News it is \"aware of the case and is providing consular assistance\".\n\nIt added: \"As with all consular cases, the department does not comment on the details of individual cases.\"\n\nMcDonald told parliament: \"She's under incredible stress.\n\n\"Tori is a Roscommon woman, and she wants to come home.\"\n\nTowey, who moved to Dubai in April 2023, is staying in a rented property with her mother, Caroline, who travelled to be with her daughter.\n\nThe case against the cabin crew employee will be heard in court on 18 July.\n\nRadha Stirling, CEO of the Detained in Dubai advocacy group, which is supporting the family, said it is calling on the country's authorities to drop the charges, remove the travel ban and let Towey fly home with her mother.\n\nRelated: Dubai influencer fined \u20ac1,800 for trespassing on Sardinia's pink beach\n\nShe added: \"She has been charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\n\n\"Strangely, the UAE has gone to great public relations efforts to promote alcohol as legal in the country. {"uri": "8218826169", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:50:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:50:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:49:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.kentonline.co.uk/news/national/travel-ban-imposed-on-irish-woman-in-dubai-has-been-lifted-premier-says-122710/", "title": "Travel ban imposed on Irish woman in Dubai has been lifted, premier says", "body": "Irish premier Simon Harris has said a travel ban imposed by Dubai authorities on Irish woman Tori Towey has been lifted.\n\nMs Towey, a 28-year-old flight attendant from Co Roscommon, was charged with attempted suicide and alcohol abuse after being attacked, Irish parliamentarians were told.\n\nDubai authorities also banned her from leaving the state, the Dail chamber heard.\n\nThe public reaction, the public revulsion to the idea of a victim of vicious domestic violence being charged with offences herself, I think, really raised people's hackles\n\nMinutes after telling the Irish parliament on Wednesday that \"no effort would be spared\" to get Ms Towey home, Mr Harris was given an update that the travel ban had been lifted.\n\n\"I've just been informed that the travel ban has been lifted, that the embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go, and that the embassy of course will continue to follow up on the case, which is still active as of now.\"\n\nMr Harris said he spoke to Ms Towey and her mother Caroline shortly after the update, and she \"will soon be home\".\n\nHe thanked the Irish embassy in the United Arab Emirates for their work on the case.\n\nSinn Fein leader Mary Lou McDonald had raised the case in the Irish parliament earlier on Wednesday for the second day in a row, criticising what she said was the \"medieval, grotesque treatment of women\" in the UAE.\n\n\"(Tori) does not belong to Dubai, she belongs at home in Ireland,\" Ms McDonald said.\n\nShe later welcomed the news that Ms Towey is due to return home to Ireland, saying: \"I think the public reaction, the public revulsion to the idea of a victim of vicious domestic violence being charged with offences herself, I think, really raised people's hackles.\n\n\"I hope that her return home marks the end of this ordeal, of this nightmare for her. It raises fundamental questions around the treatment of women in Dubai.\"\n\nIreland's deputy premier and minister for foreign affairs Micheal Martin welcomed the news that Ms Towey was \"free to return\" and said he hoped this would happen \"as soon as possible\".\n\nHe praised ambassador Alison Milton and the embassy in the UAE for their work on the case.\n\n\"It's been very, very challenging and traumatic for Tori over the last while but I think our team there has been in contact and has engaged with the family and indeed with the authorities as well, and it's been a constructive engagement, and they have responded with the issue being resolved, facilitating Tory's travel home.\"\n\nMs Towey's aunt Ann Flynn said Ms Towey and her mother Caroline had been trying to stay positive in recent days.\n\nIt's really terrible that this has happened to a young woman that was full of life, full of adventure, she loved travelling\n\n\"They're very nervous and can't wait to get home,\" she told RTE on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"It's really terrible that this has happened to a young woman that was full of life, full of adventure, she loved travelling.\"\n\nRadha Stirling, founder of the Detained in Dubai group, said the support of the Irish people and the Irish Government had \"really warmed\" Ms Towey and her mother and had \"given them hope and inspiration\".\n\nShe said Ms Towey's case had been due to be heard in court next week.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs said it was, along with Ireland's embassy in the UAE, providing \"ongoing consular assistance\" in the case.\n\n\"The Irish ambassador to the UAE is in regular contact with our citizen (including this morning). The embassy is also engaging with all the relevant authorities in UAE on the case,\" the department told the PA news agency.\n\n\"Officials will continue to provide advice and consular assistance.\"", {"uri": "8217699862", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "22:24:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T22:24:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T22:24:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/jul/09/irish-woman-charged-with-attempting-suicide-by-dubai-court", "title": "Irish woman charged with 'attempting suicide' by Dubai court", "body": "Public figures call for release of Tori Towey, 28, who says attempt was response to alleged domestic violence attack\n\nA 28-year-old woman from Ireland has been charged with \"attempting suicide\" by a court in Dubai, with politicians and campaigners calling for her release.\n\nTori Towey, who works in the United Arab Emirates as an airline cabin crew member, said she tried to take her own life after allegedly being attacked and left with severe bruising and other injuries in a domestic violence incident.\n\nTowey, from Boyle in County Roscommon, was taken to a police station where she was told she was being charged with attempted suicide and abusing alcohol.\n\nThe Sinn F\u00e9in leader, Mary Lou McDonald, who has been supporting her, told the parliament in Ireland on Tuesday that Towey's passport was blocked and she cannot return to Ireland.\n\nSimon Harris, the taoiseach, told the D\u00e1il he is ready to \"intervene\" in the case. Harris said he was not aware of the case but noted that her plight had been raised with the minister for foreign affairs by Sinn F\u00e9in.\n\nThe taoiseach, who was responding to a question from McDonald, said: \"Thank you, deputy McDonald, for bringing the case of Tori to my attention,\" RT\u00c9 reported.\n\n\"I'm not directly apprised of the situation, but I'm very happy to be directly apprised of it now,\" he added.\n\nHarris added he would work with the deputy \"to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be - based on what you tell me - the most appalling circumstances\".\n\nIreland's department of foreign affairs told Sky News it is \"aware of the case and is providing consular assistance\".\n\nIt added: \"As with all consular cases, the department does not comment on the details of individual cases.\"\n\nMcDonald told parliament: \"She's under incredible stress.\n\n\"Tori is a Roscommon woman, and she wants to come home.\"\n\nTowey, who moved to Dubai in April 2023, is staying in a rented property with her mother, Caroline, who travelled to be with her daughter.\n\nThe case against the cabin crew employee will be heard in court on 18 July.\n\nRadha Stirling, CEO of the Detained in Dubai advocacy group, which is supporting the family, said it is calling on the country's authorities to drop the charges, remove the travel ban and let Towey fly home with her mother.\n\nShe added: \"She has been charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\n\n\"Strangely, the UAE has gone to great public relations efforts to promote alcohol as legal in the country. In reality, people are still regularly charged with alcohol consumption and possession.\n\n\"Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive.\"\n\nStirling wrote on X that Michael Fitzmaurice, Teachta D\u00e1la of Ireland, told her that he has made representations to the UAE's ambassador to Ireland and the department of foreign affairs.\n\nThe UAE {"uri": "8217303110", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "16:17:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T16:17:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T16:17:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.thejournal.ie/tori-towey-dubai-6431389-Jul2024/", "title": "Irish woman in Dubai 'victim of domestic violence and charged with attempted suicide', D\u00e1il hears", "body": "The case was raised in the D\u00e1il today by Sinn F\u00e9in leader Mary Lou McDonald.\n\nIRISH WOMAN TORI Towey has been charged with attempted suicide and consuming alcohol in the UAE city of Dubai, the D\u00e1il has heard.\n\nThe case was raised in the D\u00e1il today by Sinn F\u00e9in leader Mary Lou McDonald, who called on Taoiseach Simon Harris to intervene and call in the UAE ambassador.\n\nHarris said he would engage with McDonald about how to intervene in Towey's case.\n\n\"She has been a victim of the most gross domestic violence. Her passport has been destroyed and a travel ban has been imposed on her,\"said McDonald, who along with along with Sinn F\u00e9in Roscommon-Galway TD Claire Kerrane has been in touch with Ms Towey.\n\nShe went to the authorities seeking protection many times, but to no avail. Following one particularly severe beating in which her husband repeatedly tried to slam doors on her arms and break her limbs, she escaped upstairs and she attempted to take her own life.\n\nMcDonald added: \"Unfortunately, Tori now faces charges in Dubai of attempted suicide and the abuse of alcohol.\"\n\n\"The system over there, rather than protecting this woman, who is an Irish citizen, chose instead to detain her and charge her. She is now under the most incredible stress.\"\n\n\"I spoke to her this afternoon. Her mother, Caroline, has travelled to be with her. Tori wants to come home. It is as simple as that. She is a Roscommon woman, and she wants to come home.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nMs Towey has lived in Dubai since April 2023 after getting a job as an airline attendant.\n\nSpeaking to The Journal, Radha Stirling of human rights advocacy group Detained in Dubai said that Ms Towey is set to appear in court next week and in a worst case scenario could face a prison sentence.\n\nShe explained that often lengthy legal processes in Dubai mean that Ms Towey's immediate future is uncertain.\n\n\"We don't know what's going to happen at that court date. The prosecutors basically told her it was going to court she's been charged. She doesn't have legal representation. It's very expensive in Dubai, and she just, frankly, couldn't afford it.\"\n\n\"So she's going in blind, and the hearings come up really quickly as well. So from the time she found out she was charged, it's only, you know, two, three weeks.\"\n\nDespite the swiftly appointed court date, the process could drag on for months, she said.\n\n\"This could take four to six months for that to happen. That's sort of a best case scenario. In a worst case scenario, she actually goes to prison.\"\n\nTowey and her mother are currently staying in an Airbnb in Dubai while she awaits her court date.\n\nReaders like you are keeping these stories free for everyone... {"uri": "8218692864", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:27:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:27:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:27:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/harris-confirms-travel-ban-on-irish-woman-detained-in-dubai-has-been-lifted-1648167.html", "title": "Harris confirms travel ban on Irish woman detained in Dubai has been lifted | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "Taoiseach Simon Harris has confirmed a travel ban imposed by authorities in Dubai on Irish woman Tori Towey has been lifted.\n\nMs Towey had been banned from leaving the United Arab Emirates (UAE) after she was charged with attempted suicide and consuming alcohol in Dubai.\n\n\"I've just been informed that the travel ban has been lifted, that the embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go and that the embassy, of course, will continue to follow up on the case, which is still active as of now,\" Mr Harris told the D\u00e1il on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nMr Harris thanked the Irish embassy in the UAE for its work on the case, and Sinn F\u00e9in leader Mary Lou McDonald and Roscommon TD Claire Kerrane who had raised the matter in the D\u00e1il on Tuesday.\n\nSpeaking in the D\u00e1il on Wednesday, Ms McDonald criticised the \"medieval, grotesque treatment of women\" in the UAE.\n\n\"(Tori) does not belong to Dubai, she belongs at home in Ireland,\" Ms McDonald said.\n\nThe update comes after the Government was commended by a human rights group for its swift action regarding Ms Towey's case.\n\nThe chief executive of Detained in Dubai, Radha Stirling, told Newstalk radio: \"I'm super impressed by Ireland's response, it was so swift.\"\n\n\"When a government gets behind their citizens, when they go the extra mile, they are successful in getting citizens home.\"\n\nMs Stirling outlined the background of the case, explaining Ms Towey had moved to Dubai last year to pursue an aviation career.\n\n\"She was working as cabin crew for Emirates Airlines, and she ended up marrying a South African man.\n\n\"Things went south very quickly, and he became physically abusive to her. She went to hospital and had severe injuries.\n\n\"After that, there was another assault, and she broke free, ran up to the bathroom, and she woke up with paramedics and police over her, and she was taken to the police station and actually charged with attempted suicide and consuming alcohol,\" Ms Stirling said.\n\nOn the outpouring of support for Ms Towey, Ms Stirling added: \"It's amazing to see people really standing behind her and wanting her home as soon as possible.\"", "source": {"uri": "breakingnews.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Breaking News.ie"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-07-417498975", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:33:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:33:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:15:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/republic-of-ireland/travel-ban-imposed-on-irish-woman-in-dubai-has-been-lifted-premier-says/a984557390.html", "title": "Travel ban imposed on Irish woman in Dubai has been lifted, premier says", "body": "Ms Towey, a 28-year-old flight attendant from Co Roscommon, was charged with attempted suicide and alcohol abuse after being attacked, Irish parliamentarians were told.\n\nDubai authorities also banned her from leaving the state, the Dail chamber heard.\n\nMinutes after telling the Irish parliament on Wednesday that \"no effort would be spared\" to get Ms Towey home, Mr Harris was given an update that the travel ban had been lifted.\n\n\"I've just been informed that the travel ban has been lifted, that the embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go, and that the embassy of course will continue to follow up on the case, which is still active as of now.\"\n\nMr Harris said he spoke to Ms Towey and her mother Caroline shortly after the update, and she \"will soon be home\".\n\nHe thanked the Irish embassy in the United Arab Emirates for their work on the case.\n\nSinn Fein leader Mary Lou McDonald had raised the case in the Irish parliament earlier on Wednesday for the second day in a row, criticising what she said was the \"medieval, grotesque treatment of women\" in the UAE.\n\n\"(Tori) does not belong to Dubai, she belongs at home in Ireland,\" Ms McDonald said.\n\nShe later welcomed the news that Ms Towey is due to return home to Ireland, saying: \"I think the public reaction, the public revulsion to the idea of a victim of vicious domestic violence being charged with offences herself, I think, really raised people's hackles.\n\n\"I hope that her return home marks the end of this ordeal, of this nightmare for her. It raises fundamental questions around the treatment of women in Dubai.\"\n\nIreland's deputy premier and minister for foreign affairs Micheal Martin welcomed the news that Ms Towey was \"free to return\" and said he hoped this would happen \"as soon as possible\".\n\nHe praised ambassador Alison Milton and the embassy in the UAE for their work on the case.\n\n\"It's been very, very challenging and traumatic for Tori over the last while but I think our team there has been in contact and has engaged with the family and indeed with the authorities as well, and it's been a constructive engagement, and they have responded with the issue being resolved, facilitating Tory's travel home.\"\n\nMs Towey's aunt Ann Flynn said Ms Towey and her mother Caroline had been trying to stay positive in recent days.\n\n\"They're very nervous and can't wait to get home,\" she told RTE on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"It's really terrible that this has happened to a young woman that was full of life, full of adventure, she loved travelling.\"\n\nRadha Stirling, founder of the Detained in Dubai group, said the support of the Irish people and the Irish Government had \"really warmed\" Ms Towey and her mother and had \"given them hope and inspiration\".\n\nShe said Ms Towey's case had been due to be heard in court next week.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs said it was, along with Ireland's embassy in the UAE, providing \"ongoing consular assistance\" in the case.\n\n\"The Irish ambassador to the UAE is in regular contact with our citizen (including this morning). The embassy is also engaging with all the relevant authorities in UAE on the case,\" the department told the PA news agency.\n\n\"Officials will continue to provide advice and consular assistance.\"", {"uri": "8218743498", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:00:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:00:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:00:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.waterford-news.ie/harris-confirms-travel-ban-on-irish-woman-detained-in-dubai-has-been-lifted_arid-24975.html", "title": "Harris confirms travel ban on Irish woman detained in Dubai has been lifted - Homepage - Waterford News & Star", "body": "Taoiseach Simon Harris has confirmed a travel ban imposed by authorities in Dubai on Irish woman Tori Towey has been lifted.\n\nMs Towey had been banned from leaving the United Arab Emirates (UAE) after she was charged with attempted suicide and consuming alcohol in Dubai.\n\n\"I've just been informed that the travel ban has been lifted, that the embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go and that the embassy, of course, will continue to follow up on the case, which is still active as of now,\" Mr Harris told the D\u00e1il on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nMr Harris thanked the Irish embassy in the UAE for its work on the case, and Sinn F\u00e9in leader Mary Lou McDonald and Roscommon TD Claire Kerrane who had raised the matter in the D\u00e1il on Tuesday.\n\nSpeaking in the D\u00e1il on Wednesday, Ms McDonald criticised the \"medieval, grotesque treatment of women\" in the UAE.\n\n\"(Tori) does not belong to Dubai, she belongs at home in Ireland,\" Ms McDonald said.\n\nT\u00e1naiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs Miche\u00e1l Martin paid tribute to the Irish Ambassador to the UAE, Alison Milton, for her role in the matter.\n\nSpeaking on RT\u00c9 radio's News at One, Mr Martin said he had anticipated \"good news\" from Tuesday evening. However, he said there was a process to go through, and he could not comment on cases until it was completed.\n\nHe said he anticipated that Ms Towey and her mother Caroline, who had travelled to Dubai to support her daughter, would be returning to Ireland at the earliest opportunity now Ms Towey's passport had been returned.\n\nThe T\u00e1naiste said Ms Milton and her team in the UAE had opened up \"good channels of communication and engagement\" with local authorities, which had facilitated the lifting of charges against Ms Towey.\n\n\"It has been very, very challenging and traumatic for Tori over the last while, but I think our team there has been in contact and has engaged with the family, and indeed with the authorities as well, and it's been a constructive engagement and they have responded with the issue being resolved,\" Mr Martin said.\n\nThat's the importance of very strong diplomats on the ground\n\nHe added: \"Different jurisdictions have different norms, and different approaches which sometimes don't approximate to ours, but we work with the authorities in such situations, and we work to try and resolve issues of this kind.\n\n\"That's the importance of very strong diplomats on the ground. People have good relationships and work those relationships to get the best outcomes for our citizens when difficulties and when challenges arise.\"\n\n\"Our objective always is to make the best judgment calls and to work as effectively as we can to bring about resolutions for our citizens, positive outcomes for our citizens, and I'm glad, in this case with Tori, that we've managed to do that and to be of assistance to her.\"\n\nThe update comes after the Government was commended by a human rights group for its swift action regarding Ms Towey's case.\n\nThe chief executive of Detained in Dubai, Radha Stirling, told Newstalk radio on Wednesday morning: \"I'm super impressed by Ireland's response, it was so swift.\"\n\n\"When a government gets behind their citizens, when they go the extra mile, they are successful in getting citizens home.\"\n\nMs Stirling outlined the background of the case, explaining Ms Towey had moved to Dubai last year to pursue an aviation career.\n\n\"She was working as cabin crew for Emirates Airlines, and she ended up marrying a South African man.\n\n\"Things went south very quickly, and he became physically abusive to her. She went to hospital and had severe injuries.\n\n\"After that, there was another assault, and she broke free, ran up to the bathroom, and she woke up with paramedics and police over her, and she was taken to the police station and actually charged with attempted suicide and consuming alcohol,\" Ms Stirling said.\n\nOn the outpouring of support for Ms Towey, Ms Stirling added: \"It's amazing to see people really standing behind her and wanting her home as soon as possible.\"", "source": {"uri": "waterford-news.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Waterford News and Star"}, "authors": [], "Premier says travel ban imposed on Irish woman in Dubai has been lifted", "body": "Tori Towey, 28, a flight attendant from Co Roscommon, was charged with attempted suicide and alcohol abuse after waking up in a police station after an attack, Irish parliamentarians were told.\n\nDubai authorities had also banned her from leaving the state, the Dail chamber heard.\n\nAddressing the Irish parliament on Wednesday afternoon, Mr Harris said: \"I've just been informed that the travel ban has been lifted, that the embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go and that the embassy of course will continue to follow up on the case, which is still active as of now.\"\n\nHe thanked the Irish embassy in the United Arab Emirates for their work on the case.\n\nMary Lou McDonald, the leader of Ireland's main opposition party Sinn Fein, had raised the case in the Irish parliament on Wednesday for the second day in a row, criticising what she said was the \"medieval, grotesque treatment of women\" in the United Arab Emirates.\n\n\"(Tori) does not belong to Dubai, she belongs at home in Ireland,\" Ms McDonald said.\n\nThe Taoiseach thanked Ms McDonald and Roscommon TD Claire Kerrane for raising the \"distressing\" case and said she had spoken to Ms Towey and her mother Caroline, who is with her in Dubai.\n\nHe said the Irish embassy in the United Arab Emirates has been in constant contact with Ms Towey.\n\n\"We want Tori Towey back in this country, we want her back home in Roscommon,\" Mr Harris said.\n\n\"No effort will be spared by us, by Ireland, to make progress on this matter, to get Tori home. She's not a criminal, she's a victim of gender-based violence.\"\n\nMr Harris said he had spoken to Ireland's deputy premier Micheal Martin, who is the Minister of Foreign Affairs, and Ireland's ambassador to the United Arab Emirates.\n\nHer aunt Ann Flynn said both were trying to stay positive.\n\n\"They're very nervous and can't wait to get home,\" she told RTE's Morning Ireland.\n\n\"It's really terrible that this has happened to a young woman that was full of life, full of adventure, she loved travelling.\"\n\nRadha Stirling, founder of the Detained in Dubai group, said the support of the Irish people and the Irish Government had \"really warmed\" them and \"given them hope and inspiration\".\n\nShe said the case is due to be heard in court next week.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs told the PA news agency on Wednesday it was providing \"ongoing consular assistance\" in the case, as was Ireland's embassy in the United Arab Emirates.\n\n\"The Irish ambassador to the UAE is in regular contact with our citizen (including this morning). {"uri": "8218620597", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:43:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:43:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T11:43:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/ireland/2024/07/10/swift-state-response-praised-in-case-of-irish-woman-detained-in-dubai-for-attempted-suicide/", "title": "Swift State response praised in case of Irish woman detained in Dubai for 'attempted suicide'", "body": "Detained in Dubai group is hopeful Ireland's diplomatic efforts will see the case dropped and Tori Towey being allowed to return to Ireland\n\nAn advocacy group has praised the Government for the speed with which it has responded to the case of Co Roscommon woman Tori Towey who has been reportedly charged with attempted suicide and consuming alcohol in Dubai.\n\nMs Towey (28), who moved to the city in the United Arab Emirates where she worked for Emirates Airlines, has been prevented from leaving the country as a result of the charges, the D\u00e1il heard on Tuesday.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs is providing consular assistance to Ms Towey, whose case was first highlighted by Dubai Detained, which said it is representing her and her mother.\n\nCommenting on the Government's response, Detained in Dubai chief executive Radha Stirling said: \"I'm super impressed by Ireland's response, it was so swift.\n\n\"When a Government gets behind their citizens, when they go the extra mile, they are successful in getting citizens home,\" she said on Newstalk Breakfast.\n\nMs Stirling, who is in daily contact with Ms Towey, was hopeful that diplomatic efforts by the Department of Foreign Affairs would lead to the case against Ms Towey being dropped and the travel ban lifted so she could return to Ireland.\n\nOn Tuesday, Sinn F\u00e9in leader Mary Lou McDonald told the D\u00e1il that Ms Towey has been the victim of domestic violence and is subject to a travel ban over allegations she illegally consumed alcohol and attempted suicide. Attempted suicide is a crime in the Arab state, carrying a sentence of up to six months.\n\nIn response to questions in the D\u00e1il, Taoiseach Simon Harris said he is prepared to intervene and offer any support required by Ms Towey.\n\nSpeaking on Wednesday morning, Mr Harris said he had spoken to Ms Towey and her mother Caroline.\n\nSpeaking to reporters in Leinster House, he said he was limited in what he could say but that Ms Towey had beeen through the \"most horrific situation\". He said it was utterly unacceptable treatment of an Irish citizen and she had been a victim of male violence and should be allowed return to her home in Ireland.\n\nHe said he had spoken to the Irish ambassador in the region who had been working on the case for some time, and he had spoken with T\u00e1naiste Micheal Martin on the matter as well. He said she was the victim of a brutal attack and found herself walking up not in a hospital but in a police station.\n\nThere was a \"lot of diplomatic activity going on in the background\", Mr Harris said. \"She needs to be supported, she needs to be brought back home, to her home here in Ireland, and we need the travel ban lifted to make that happen\".\n\nOutlining the background to the case, Ms Stirling said Ms Towey's case is due to be heard in Dubai next week.\n\nShe said Ms Towey had moved to Dubai last year to pursue an aviation career. \"She was working as cabin crew for Emirates Airlines, and she ended up marrying a South African man. Things went south very quickly, and he became physically abusive to her. She went to hospital and had severe injuries,\" Ms Stirling said.\n\n\"After that, there was another assault and she broke free, ran up to the bathroom, and she woke up with paramedics and police over her, and she was taken to the police station and actually charged with, attempted suicide and consuming alcohol.\"\n\nThe situation was \"absurd\" that a woman who had been assaulted would be further abused by the system, Ms Stirling said.\n\n\"We have seen over the years, we've seen rape victims charged with sex outside marriage. We've seen this kind of culture coming from the UAE before. They had made an effort for public relations purposes, they were starting to take women's rights a bit more seriously, victim rights. But it seems like nothing has changed.\n\n\"And this is truly astonishing that someone who's been beaten to the degree that she has bruises all over her body, and now she's being abused by the system itself again. So I find it outrageous,\" Ms Stiring said.\n\n\"And I can see that's why there's so much support out there from Irish citizens, from politicians, from your leaders in your Government. So it's amazing to see people really standing behind her and wanting her home as soon as possible.\n\n\"When it comes to a case like this, it's all about diplomacy. Without the support of the Irish Government, she would be likely to face prison and charges and deportation,\" she said.\n\n\"Various members of the Irish Government have contacted the UAE ambassador to Ireland and of course Ireland's ambassador in the UAE, and they're trying to get those diplomatic talks happening. If that happens, that is the best and fastest way to get her home.\n\n\"She was told she had been charged with alcohol abuse and attempted suicide. Now I validated this with the Department of Public Prosecutions today and it's exactly as they said. So there's been no differences to the charges. And so they are proceeding on that, which is very bizarre since they allegedly decriminalised attempted suicide in the past couple of years and also have been promoting that they have decriminalised alcohol consumption,\" Ms Stirling said.\n\n\"So it's quite surprising that they would proceed to charge, especially her, under these circumstances, and take her to court, knowing that she obviously needs help, needs to just go home with her family.\"\n\nIreland's ambassador to UAE spoke with Ms Towey last night, and she is staying in an Airbnb with her mother Caroline who flew out to support her, according to Ms Stirling.\n\n\"She is exhausted and she's finding it very overwhelming. But at the same time, we're really, really warmed by all of the support that she's been getting. I don't think she expected all of that. I don't think she expected the Irish Government to motivate themselves as quickly. And this is the fastest I've ever seen this happen from a Government. So I'm super impressed by Ireland's response.\"\n\n\"We've dealt with many human rights issues like this, and when the Government gets behind the citizen and talks to their counterparts, the foreign affairs ministry in the UAE escalates it even to the ruler, Sheikh Mohammed, or the head of the police department and the justice system. When they do that and they go the extra mile rather than just deferring it and pretending they can't do anything, when they actually make the effort, they are successful in getting the citizens home.\"\n\n\"She is very, very much looking forward to coming home and recovering from what's been an extremely terrible, shocking year for her, in fact. So I think she needs to heal. She needs to be around friends and family and the safety of her country,\" Ms Stirling said.\n\nAccording to its website, Detained in Dubai provides confidential legal help in civil and criminal cases and consults with governments internationally on UAE legal issues.\n\nAnne Flynn, aunt of Ms Towey, said the family is hoping that diplomatic efforts will lead to charges being dropped and her return to Ireland. \"We are just all very, very anxious,\" she told RT\u00c9 radio's Morning Ireland.\n\n\"We keep hoping that we'll get word that they're [Ms Towey and her mother, Caroline] on a plane. On the way home. I don't know. Will this court case go ahead? Or if it goes, what will happen? You know, we're just very hopeful. And it's really terrible that this has happened to a young woman, you know, that was full of life and full of adventure. And she loved travelling. And, you know, she's a beautiful young woman.\n\n\"I've been in touch with them every day, several times a day, since all this started - they're both trying to keep positive. We're trying to keep positive as well. But it's on your mind constantly, and I'm sure it's on their minds because all the family gets in touch with them, you know? And, it's so far away, you know, but hopefully with Radha Stirling, the Taoiseach and all the Ministers, this will help. Hopefully, we'll hear good news.\n\n\"We're hoping that just something will happen, that it won't go to court. It's hard to believe that this young woman has been charged with trying to commit suicide. And, you know, it's very, very hard to believe it.\"", "source": {"uri": "irishtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Irish Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8218650876", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:03:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:03:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:03:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/news/irish-news/politics/taoiseach-confirms-tori-towey-dubai-33210742", "title": "Taoiseach confirms Tori Towey cleared to return home as Dubai travel ban lifted", "body": "Taoiseach Simon Harris has confirmed that the travel ban preventing Irish woman Tori Towey from leaving Dubai has been lifted.\n\nThe Embassy in the United Arab Emirates will now take her to the airport to come home when she is ready.\n\nCampaigners claim that the 28-year-old air steward is accused of breaking strict laws in the Muslim country - even though she is the victim of an alleged attack in her home.\n\nHuman rights campaigners said that she wanted to leave the Middle Eastern state after receiving hospital treatment for severe bruising and other injuries - but was detained.\n\nREAD MORE: Irish woman charged with attempted suicide in Dubai 'very nervous' and wants to come home, says aunt\n\nMr Harris told the D\u00e1il: \"I've just been informed that the travel ban has been lifted. The Embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go. The Embassy of course will continue to follow the case which is still active as of now.\"\n\nSpeaking shortly before the announcement that the travel ban was lifted, the Taoiseach stated that Ms Towey is a \"victim\" and not a \"criminal\".\n\nHe confirmed that he had spoken to Tori and her mother Caroline over the previous hours.\n\n\"An Irish woman, an Irish citizen, has been a victim of horrific male violence, has been the victim of the most brutal, horrific attack one can imagine,\" Mr Harris told the D\u00e1il.\n\n\"After enduring that horrific brutal attack, Tori Towey didn't wake up in a hospital being supported and cared for and loved. She woke up in a police station. We want Tori Towey back in this country. We want her back home in Roscommon, that's what she wants as well.\"\n\nThe Taoiseach said he had spoken to Ms Towey and her mother and told them getting her home was \"a priority issue\".\n\nHe has also been in contact with the Ambassador in the United Arab Emirates and that she and the Embassy are \"working extraordinarily hard on this matter\".\n\nMr Harris added: \"No effort will be spared by us, by Ireland, to make progress on this matter and to get Tori Towey home.\n\n\"She doesn't need to come home after a court case because she is not a criminal. She is a victim of gender-based violence. We expect her to be able to return here to Ireland as an Irish citizen without delay.\"\n\nSpeaking under privilege, Ms McDonald told the D\u00e1il that Ms Towey had gotten married last March.\n\n\"Since then, Tori has been subjected to sustained and brutal domestic violence and abuse,\" she said.\n\n\"When she went to the authorities to seek help, instead of being protected, she was sent home with her husband. Her husband then destroyed her passport so she couldn't travel and she couldn't work. She couldn't come back to Ireland.\n\n\"Tori was, in effect, held captive by her abuser.\n\n\"Just over two weeks ago, she endured a particularly vicious beating. Her husband repeatedly slammed doors on her arms trying to break her limbs and he tried to strangle her. \"She fled upstairs in a desperate attempt to escape the violence and in desperation, she tried to take her own life.\n\n\"When Tori came to, she was surrounded by paramedics but instead of being taken to a hospital, she was taken to a police station.\n\n\"There she was charged with attempted suicide and alcohol abuse. Tori was placed in a cell with 50 other women. She wasn't told what she was charged with. She wasn't given any information at all.\n\n\"Tori was released on bail but her passport was blocked. She is banned from leaving the state.\"\n\nMs McDonald urged Mr Harris to act quickly as \"once the Dubai court process kicks in, it becomes harder and harder to get Tori back home to Ireland quickly.\"\n\nJoin the Irish Mirror's breaking news service on WhatsApp. Click this link to receive breaking news and the latest headlines direct to your phone. {"uri": "8218811966", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:40:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:40:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:40:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.belfastlive.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/irish-air-hostess-tori-towey-29515646", "title": "Irish air hostess stuck in Dubai to have travel ban lifted as embassy steps in", "body": "Taoiseach Simon Harris has announced that the travel restrictions preventing Irish citizen Tori Towey from departing Dubai have now been removed.\n\nThe Irish Embassy in the UAE is set to assist her in travelling to the airport for her return home at her earliest convenience.\n\nActivists have argued that Towey, a 28-year-old flight attendant, has been wrongly accused under the strict laws of the Muslim nation, despite being an alleged assault victim in her own residence.\n\nRead more: NI mum's baby and sister killed by drunk driver taking picture driving at 141mph\n\nRead more: Irish air hostess faces jail in Dubai after alleged domestic attack\n\nHuman rights advocates report that after being hospitalised with serious bruising and other injuries, she sought to exit the Gulf country but was prevented from doing so.\n\nIn the Dail, Mr Harris stated: \"I've just been informed that the travel ban has been lifted. The Embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go. The Embassy of course will continue to follow the case which is still active as of now.\", reports the Irish Mirror.\n\nAdditionally, the Taoiseach confirmed having conversations with both Tori and her mother, Caroline.\n\nOn another note, Tanaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs Micheal Martin told RTE's News at One about the \"painstaking work\" done by Alison Milton, Ireland's Ambassador to the UAE.\n\nHe also refuted any suggestion that the media attention and Sinn Fein's involvement had expedited the resolution of the case.\n\nMartin revealed: \" I would have known last evening (Tuesday) that there was positive news on the way,\" and added, \"My general view of things is I don't really comment confidently about anything until somebody is on the plane.\"\n\n\"I've had many situations that we've had to deal with in different jurisdictions. But people do things in the best of faith but you know, we tend to have a modus operandi in terms of how we operate, particularly where it involves personal information and cases and so on like that.\"\n\nThe Tanaiste also remarked on the \"twists and turns\" in the ongoing situation, yet expressed relief at the recent developments.\n\nBefore the update confirming the removal of the travel restriction, the Taoiseach underscored Ms Towey's status saying she is a \"victim\" and far from a \"criminal\".\n\nHe shared that he had engaged in conversation with both Tori and her mother Caroline in the past few hours.\n\nAn emphatic Mr Harris addressed the Dail, detailing the ordeal: \"An Irish woman, an Irish citizen, has been a victim of horrific male violence, has been the victim of the most brutal, horrific attack one can imagine,\".\n\nHe graphically outlined Ms Towey's plight following the assault: \"After enduring that horrific brutal attack, Tori Towey didn't wake up in a hospital being supported and cared for and loved. She woke up in a police station. We want Tori Towey back in this country. We want her back home in Roscommon, that's what she wants as well.\"\n\nThe Taoiseach communicated his discussions with Ms Towey and her mother, emphasising that bringing Tori home was \"a priority issue\".\n\nHe confirmed consistent communication with the Ambassador in the United Arab Emirates, commending the proactive efforts of both the Ambassador and the Embassy.\n\nMr Harris concluded with a firm commitment: \"No effort will be spared by us, by Ireland, to make progress on this matter and to get Tori Towey home.\"\n\n\"She doesn't need to come home after a court case because she is not a criminal. She is a victim of gender-based violence. We expect her to be able to return here to Ireland as an Irish citizen without delay.\"\n\nSpeaking under privilege, Ms McDonald told the Dail that Ms Towey had gotten married last March.\n\n\"Since then, Tori has been subjected to sustained and brutal domestic violence and abuse,\" she said.\n\n\"When she went to the authorities to seek help, instead of being protected, she was sent home with her husband. Her husband then destroyed her passport so she couldn't travel and she couldn't work. She couldn't come back to Ireland.\"\n\n\"Tori was, in effect, held captive by her abuser.\"\n\n\"Just over two weeks ago, she endured a particularly vicious beating. Her husband repeatedly slammed doors on her arms trying to break her limbs and he tried to strangle her. \"She fled upstairs in a desperate attempt to escape the violence and in desperation, she tried to take her own life.\n\n\"When Tori came to, she was surrounded by paramedics but instead of being taken to a hospital, she was taken to a police station.\"\n\n\"There she was charged with attempted suicide and alcohol abuse. Tori was placed in a cell with 50 other women. She wasn't told what she was charged with. She wasn't given any information at all.\"\n\n\"Tori was released on bail but her passport was blocked. She is banned from leaving the state.\"\n\nMs McDonald has called on Mr Harris to act swiftly, warning that \"once the Dubai court process kicks in, it becomes harder and harder to get Tori back home to Ireland quickly.\"\n\nFor all the latest news, visit the Belfast Live homepage here and sign up to our newsletter.", "source": {"uri": "belfastlive.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Belfast Campaigners claim that the 28-year-old air steward is accused of breaking strict laws in the Muslim country even though she is the victim of an alleged attack in her home.\n\nHuman rights campaigners said that she wanted to leave the Middle Eastern state after receiving hospital treatment for severe bruising and other injuries but was detained. Mr Harris told the Dail: \"I've just been informed that the travel ban has been lifted. The Embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go. The Embassy of course will continue to follow the case which is still active as of now.\"\n\nRead more: Irish airline stewardess faces jail in Dubai after alleged domestic attack and suicide attempt\n\nRead more: Taoiseach Simon Harris insists 'I am staying in my home' after bomb threat\n\nSpeaking shortly before the announcement that the travel ban was lifted, the Taoiseach stated that Ms Towey is a \"victim\" and not a \"criminal\". He confirmed that he had spoken to Tori and her mother Caroline over the previous hours.\n\n\"An Irish woman, an Irish citizen, has been a victim of horrific male violence, has been the victim of the most brutal, horrific attack one can imagine,\" Mr Harris told the Dail. \"After enduring that horrific brutal attack, Tori Towey didn't wake up in a hospital being supported and cared for and loved. She woke up in a police station. We want Tori Towey back in this country. We want her back home in Roscommon, that's what she wants as well.\"\n\nThe Taoiseach said he had spoken to Ms Towey and her mother and told them getting her home was \"a priority issue\". He has also been in contact with the Ambassador in the United Arab Emirates and that she and the Embassy are \"working extraordinarily hard on this matter\".\n\nMr Harris added: \"No effort will be spared by us, by Ireland, to make progress on this matter and to get Tori Towey home.\" She doesn't need to come home after a court case because she is not a criminal. She is a victim of gender-based violence. We expect her to be able to return here to Ireland as an Irish citizen without delay.\"\n\nSpeaking under privilege, Ms McDonald told the Dail that Ms Towey had gotten married last March. \"Since then, Tori has been subjected to sustained and brutal domestic violence and abuse,\" she said.\n\n\"When she went to the authorities to seek help, instead of being protected, she was sent home with her husband. Her husband then destroyed her passport so she couldn't travel and she couldn't work. She couldn't come back to Ireland.\"\n\n\"Tori was, in effect, held captive by her abuser. "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.irishpost.com/news/irish-woman-held-in-dubai-after-suffering-horrific-attack-to-return-home-274947", "title": "Irish woman held in Dubai after suffering 'horrific attack' to return home | The Irish Post", "body": "AN IRISHWOMAN who was being detained in Dubai after reportedly being the victim of a serious assault is to return home.\n\nThe case of 28-year-old Tori Towey was raised in the D\u00e1il yesterday by Sinn F\u00e9in's May Lou McDonald.\n\nShe claimed the Roscommon native had been the victim of a 'severe beating' but in the wake of the incident, was herself charged with attempted suicide and alcohol abuse as well as being handed a travel ban.\n\nTaoiseach Simon Harris said he would look into the matter and revealed in the D\u00e1il today that the travel ban on Ms Towey had been lifted.\n\n\"Embassy staff will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go,\" he added.\n\n\"The embassy, of course, will continue to follow up on the case, which is still active, as of now.\n\n\"I just wanted to inform the House of that and to thank all in our embassy for their work in relation to that.\"\n\nBefore news of the ban's lifting, Mr Harris told the D\u00e1il earlier today that Ms Towey had been the victim of 'horrific male violence'.\n\n\"She has been the victim of the most brutal, horrific attack one can imagine,\" he added.\n\n\"After enduring that horrific, brutal attack, Tori Towey did not wake up in a hospital, being supported, cared for and loved, she woke up in a police station.\"\n\nRadha Stirling, whose organisation Detained in Dubai had been working with Ms Towey, also shared the news via Twitter that the charges against the Irishwoman had been officially withdrawn.\n\nShe added that she hoped 'no further attempts will be made to keep her in the country'.\n\nForeign Affairs Minister Miche\u00e1l Martin also welcomed the news that Ms Towey had been allowed to return to Ireland.\n\n\"I hope she will be able to do so as soon as possible,\" added the T\u00e1naiste.\n\n\"This is an outcome that Ambassador Alison Milton, officials, and our Embassy in UAE have been working on for the last while.\n\n\"We are glad for Tori and her family, and we wish her all the very best in the future.\"\n\nThis evening, Ms McDonald thanked those who had supported Ms Towey since her case was highlighted.\n\n\"The ordeal Tori has been subjected to has been horrendous,\" she said.\n\n\"I know that Tori and her mum are deeply grateful for the solidarity and good will that has been shown towards them across Ireland.\n\n\"We now await their safe return to Ireland and to Roscommon.\n\n\"I will continue to work with everyone involved, to ensure this now happens and that they are home {"uri": "8219123251", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "17:11:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T17:11:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T17:10:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.news24.com/news24/world/news/irish-woman-who-says-abusive-sa-husband-trapped-her-in-dubai-is-free-to-go-after-govt-steps-in-20240710-2", "title": "Irish woman who says abusive SA husband trapped her in Dubai is free to go, after govt steps in | News24", "body": "She had been facing prosecution for attempted suicide, which the UAE treats as a crime.\n\nAn Irish woman who says her South African husband had abused and trapped her in Dubai is returning home and will seemingly no longer face charges.\n\nOn Wednesday, Irish Taoiseach (prime minister) Simon Harris said a travel ban on Tori Towey had been lifted and her legal support team in Dubai said charges against her had been dropped.\n\nTowey had faced charges in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) since 28 June, but Harris stepped in on Tuesday, 9 July, after being made aware of her case, and promised diplomatic efforts would be launched.\n\nShe had been \"the victim of a brutal attack\", said Harris at the time, then \"found herself waking up not in a hospital, but in a police station\".\n\nIreland considered Towey to have been trapped by a UAE travel ban, engineered by her husband through a pre-emptive complaint, under a system that gives men effective control over foreign travel by women considered their dependents.\n\nOn Wednesday, a day after the matter was first raised in the Irish Parliament, Harris announced to the Lower House of the Assembly that government representatives would be accompanying Towey to the airport.\n\nAn abuser sent home\n\nHer family said Towey met her then-boyfriend as a colleague at Emirates and they were quickly married.\n\nHe equally quickly became abusive, her mother told legal consultants, Detained in Dubai, and the police were summoned to at least one public venue after he went on a rampage.\n\nHe was told to go home.\n\nREAD | Lauren Dickason to serve 18 years in psychiatric facility for murder of her 3 children\n\nHis ongoing abuse was documented; Towey filed a police report in which she alleged he had tried to break her arm in a bathroom door, told her he would kill her, choked her and threatened her with a knife. After neighbours intervened, she was taken away by an ambulance.\n\nWhen Towey ultimately tried to leave for Ireland, according to Detained in Dubai, she arrived at the airport to find a travel ban in place due to an earlier complaint lodged by her husband.\n\nSuch \"pre-emptive\" complaints were not uncommon in the UAE, the group said, and allowed men to prevent wives from fleeing abuse.\n\nTowey returned home.\n\n\"The next day, Tori and her husband had some wine, and he became enraged, accusing her of having an affair,\" said Detained in Dubai.\n\nFearing a slow death by torture, Towey ran to a bathroom \"and wrapped an electrical lead around her neck\". She woke up to the police and paramedics and was taken to a police station.\n\nShe had been due to appear on 18 July on charges of alcohol consumption and attempted suicide.\n\nDetained in Dubai CEO Radha Stirling compared the case to previous instances where the UAE charged victims of rape with having sex outside of marriage.\n\n\"Now, they're charging domestic violence victims with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\"\n\nOn Wednesday, Stirling said Dubai police had dropped the charges against Towey.\n\nPolitical support\n\nSinn Fein leader Mary Lou McDonald drew attention to the case in the Irish Parliament on Tuesday.\"Tori is a Roscommon woman and she wants to come home,\" she told the Assembly and urged Harris to intervene urgently.\n\nHe immediately agreed.", "source": {"uri": "8218649860", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:03:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:03:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:02:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://kmaupdates.com/2024/07/10/irish-woman-detained-in-dubai-after-attempted-suicide-when-fleeing-domestic-violence/", "title": "Irish woman detained in Dubai after 'attempted suicide' when fleeing domestic violence - Kmaupdates", "body": "The case of Tori Towey, 28, who faces criminal charges in Dubai of \"attempted suicide\" and alcohol consumption, has been raised in the D\u00e1il.\n\nMs Towey had been hospitalised with extensive injuries after an alleged assault by her husband.\n\nHer plight was raised in the D\u00e1il by Sinn F\u00e9in's Mary Lou McDonald, who said: \"Her passport has been destroyed. There was a travel ban imposed on her and she had gone to the authorities seeking protection many times but to absolutely no avail.\n\n\"But following one particularly severe beating in which her husband repeatedly tried to slam doors on her arms and break her limbs, she escaped upstairs, and she attempted to take her own life.\n\n\"The system over there, rather than protecting this woman, who is an Irish citizen, chose instead to detain her, to charge her.\n\n\"Tori wants to come home. Simple as that. She's a Roscommon woman, she wants to come home.\n\n\"And I'm asking now as a matter of absolute urgency that we have a statement from this house, that you intervene, that the ambassador is called and it made absolutely plain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way. And an Irish citizen, an Irish woman, will not be treated in this way.\"\n\nMs Towey moved to the emirate last year to work as an airline attendant.\n\nShe married a man in March but, according to Roscommon TD Claire Kerrane, she soon began being mentally and physically abused.\n\nMs Kerrane has spoken to Ms Towey and her mother Caroline, who is now with her in Dubai.\n\n\"It's a living nightmare,\" Ms Kerrane said.\n\n\"She was put in a cell with 50 women, there was no information, she wasn't told why she had been arrested, what she was being charged with. Then there's the language barrier too. It's just horrendous.\n\n\"There was a small bit of alcohol in her system so she was charged with alcohol abuse. And with 'attempted suicide'.\"\n\nAlthough Ms Towey went to the police, she was told to go home to her husband, Ms Kerrane said.\n\n\"He ripped up her passport, so she couldn't work as an airline attendant, then she had no money, so she couldn't come home.\"\n\nA travel ban was also placed on her passport so she could not escape.\n\nDuring one allegedly brutal attack in her home, it's understood she escaped into the bathroom and tried to take her own life in a bid to escape her husband, fearing he would torture her to death.\n\n\"The next thing she knew, paramedics were there,\" Ms Kerrane said.\n\n\"Then she was arrested on June 28 and had no idea what she had been arrested for.\"\n\nMs Towey is now hiding in Dubai with her mother and hoping for help.\n\nThey are too scared to talk to the media as they fear it is illegal to do so.\n\n\"They can't speak so we have to speak for them,\" Ms Kerrane said.\n\nA court date has been set for July 18.\n\n\"And we're in the last week of the D\u00e1il so there's that pressure too,\" said Ms Kerrane.\n\nTori Towey's 'very anxious' family hoping charges will be dropped\n\nMs Towey's aunt, Anne Flynn said the family is hoping that diplomatic efforts will lead to the charges being dropped and allow Ms Towey to return to Ireland.\n\n\"We are just all very, very anxious,\" she told RT\u00c9 radio's Morning Ireland.\n\n\"We keep hoping that we'll get word that they're on a plane. On the way home. I don't know. Will this court case go ahead? Or if it goes, what will happen? You know, we're just very hopeful. And it's really terrible that this has happened to a young woman that was full of life and full of adventure. And she loved travelling. And, you know, she's a beautiful young woman.\n\n\"I've been in touch with them every day, several times a day, since all this started. They're both trying to keep positive. We're trying to keep positive as well. But it's on your mind constantly, and I'm sure it's on their minds because all the family gets in touch with them, you know? And, it's so far away. But hopefully with Radha Stirling, the Taoiseach and all the ministers this will help. Hopefully, we'll hear good news.\n\n\"We're hoping that, just something will happen that it won't go to court. It's hard to believe that this young woman has been charged with trying to commit suicide.\"\n\nPoliticians here now plan to work cross-party in a bid to get the Irish woman back home to safety and Taoiseach Simon Harris has said he's ready to intervene in the case.\n\n\"She said today: 'I just want to come home,'\" Ms Kerrane said.\n\n\"Hopefully now the Irish authorities can do something to get her home.\"\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs says it is aware of the case and is providing consular assistance.\n\nConsular assistance has been provided to the family for a number of weeks and T\u00e1naiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs Miche\u00e1l Martin is speaking to his officials in Dubai.\n\nRadha Stirling, chief executive at the human rights organization Detained in Dubai, who has been helping the Toweys, said: \"It's amazing that authorities did not intervene for Tori's protection, given the state her body was in when she was hospitalized the first time.\n\n\"Worse than failing her, authorities in Dubai actually travel-banned her and kept her in the country when she was trying to get away.\n\n\"The UAE used to charge rape victims with 'sex outside marriage'. Now they're charging domestic violence victims with 'attempted suicide' and alcohol consumption. Dubai police need to be educated on victim care.\"", "source": {"uri": "kmaupdates.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "kmaupdates.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": is in \"the most appalling circumstances\" in the United Arab Emirates [BBC]\n\nAn Irish woman is facing criminal charges - including attempted suicide and consuming alcohol - in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and has had her passport destroyed.\n\nIt is understood 28-year-old Tori Towey has been working as a flight attendant and is based in Dubai - the largest city in the UAE.\n\nA lawyer and human rights advocate who is assisting her said the 28-year-old was overwhelmed and exhausted but was hopeful of being able to leave Dubai soon.\n\nRadha Stirling, who runs the Detained in Dubai group, said she spoke to Ms Towey on Wednesday morning and that \"things seem to be moving\". \"The Irish government is certainly stepping up in record time, we usually don't see them come together that fast,\" she said.\n\nThe lawyer also said the victims' support division of the Dubai police had now contacted Ms Towey.\n\n\"I'm expecting with that diplomatic push we might be able to get her home even before the court date next week, but of course we have to plan that it could go very badly and she could end up with a prison sentence,\" she told BBC News NI.\n\nMs Stirling previously said Ms Towey had been charged with consumption of alcohol and attempting suicide, both of which she said had historically been illegal in the UAE.\n\n\"The Irish government is rightly behind us in having
