"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Ireland", "type": "loc", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Northern Ireland"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Northern Ireland"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stirling", "type": "loc", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Stirling"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Stirling"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime_and_Justice", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime and Justice", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Murder", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Murder", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Victims", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Victims", "wgt": 100}], "image": "http://island.lk/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/Tori-Towey.png", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9718655", "eventUri": "eng-9718655", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.2549019607843137, "wgt": 186, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8218435564", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "09:52:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T09:52:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T09:52:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13619247/Air-stewardess-facing-jail-Dubai-attempting-suicide-beaten-husband-exhausted-desperate-come-home-worst-time-life-says-anguished-Irish-mother.html", "title": "Air stewardess facing jail in Dubai for 'attempting suicide'", "body": "The mother of an Irish air stewardess in custody in Dubai for trying to take her own life after allegedly suffering domestic abuse at the hands of her husband said she is 'desperate to get home' and has been through 'the worst time of her life'.\n\nTori Towey, 28, has been banned from leaving the UAE and told she faces jail for drinking alcohol and attempting to take her own life following an alleged beating by her husband.\n\nIrish premier Simon Harris has said he will work to intervene in the 'appalling' case, while Sinn Fein president Mary Lou McDonald raised Ms Towey's case in the Irish Parliament on Tuesday afternoon.\n\nTori's mum Caroline told MailOnline: 'The support from the Irish government and the Irish people has been incredible and we weren't expecting it at all. It's a small country and the politicians are real people.\n\n'We are both exhausted and desperate to get home. Thank you so much to everyone supporting us.'\n\nShe added that her daughter had been through 'the worst time of her life and needs to come home with me and heal'.\n\nCaroline later said the 'victim support' unit with Dubai police have made contact to offer their support and the police have also offered the services of a lawyer - raising hopes that a travel ban and any possible charged could be dropped within days.\n\nTori Towey has been left stranded in Dubai after being faced with an attempted suicide charge\n\nTori was pictured with extensive bruises over her body, which she says are from an assault\n\nDubai's draconian laws: Why attempting suicide and drinking alcohol is a 'crime'\n\nPrior to 2019, anyone found guilty of attempting suicide in Dubai faced a 5000AED fine (\u00a31050) or six months in prison.\n\nThe 'offence' was one of 28 'minor crimes' downgraded to free up space in the Emirates' overcrowded courts system.\n\nThose found guilty of attempting suicide in the Gulf state now have to pay a fine of 1000AED (\u00a3210) instead of facing a judge.\n\nIn the same year, the Gulf state loosened its liquor laws to allow tourists to purchase alcohol in state-controlled stores, previously only accessible to licence-holding residents.\n\nThe new laws also let visitors obtain liquor permits themselves for the first time, by applying online or going to a registered alcohol store to get one for free.\n\nWhile visitors must have a permit, it's no longer a criminal offence not to have one.\n\nA 30 per cent tax on alcohol was also axed on New Year's Eve 2022 to encourage tourists to flock to the Emirate.\n\nWhile the relaxation of the laws sends a message that it's safe to drink, the reality is more complicated.\n\nIt is illegal to drink or even be under the influence of alcohol in public outside of a licensed premises.\n\nRadha Stirling, founder and CEO of Detained in Dubai previously told MailOnline: 'Reducing the cost of alcohol in Dubai is sending a clear message to tourists and that is to drink. Considering Dubai's alcohol laws prohibit the possession of alcohol in public, drinking in Dubai is inherently dangerous.\n\n'If a visitor's blood is tested and shows up even one drink, they can be criminally charged. Alcohol tests are often conducted when a complaint is made by a local. If a local is offended by a visitor's dress sense, language or behaviour, they may call the police and have the visitor arrested, even if that person has only consumed a small beer.\n\n'Dubai's laws are highly contradictory. On the one hand, people are encouraged to drink but on the other, it's a criminal offence to have any amount of alcohol in your blood in public. Encouraging visitors to drink more alcohol will most certainly result in increased detentions of Brits abroad in prisons notorious for human rights abuses and police brutality'.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nA spokesperson for legal group Detained in Dubai (DiD) claimed Tori's South African husband went after her with a knife and punched her, before slamming her arm in the bathroom door trying to break it.\n\nTori said she tried to take her own life after the attack, which left her with severe bruises and injuries.\n\nBut after being taken to a police station, Ms Towey is now facing charges of alcohol consumption and attempting suicide by a court in Dubai.\n\nShe said she is unable to leave the country as her passport was blocked, meaning she can't travel back home to Ireland.\n\nSpeaking through outreach group DiD, who are assisting the family, Ms Towey said: 'I don't know what's going to happen in court next week.\n\n'I'm desperate to go home to Ireland and put all of this in the past. I'm asking the Taoiseach to please help us.'\n\nThe DiD has said Ms Towey could face a lengthy prison sentence in a jail known for 'human rights abuses and torture'.\n\nRadha Stirling, CEO of Detained in Dubai, said: 'We are calling on Dubai authorities to urgently drop the charges against Tori, remove the travel ban and let her fly home to Ireland with her mother. She has been charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\n\n'Strangely, the UAE has gone to great public relations efforts to promote alcohol as legal in the country. In reality, people are still regularly charged with alcohol consumption and possession. Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive.'\n\nShe explained: 'Tori arranged to fly home to Ireland but, when she arrived at the airport, was told a case against her by her husband had been dropped but the travel ban remained.\n\n'She attended the police station who assured her the travel ban would be lifted but it never happened. The next day, Tori and her husband had some wine and he became enraged, accusing her of having an affair.'\n\nMs Towey then attempted to take her own life and ended up in a police station.\n\nMs Stirling explained: 'The next thing she remembers is an ambulance crew and police waking her up. She was taken to Al Barsha police station and kept for several hours before going home again.\n\n'Her mother pleaded to the Irish Consulate but in the absence of their assistance, boarded a flight to Dubai. When she arrived, she wasn't allowed to see Tori alone, her abuser wouldn't allow it.\n\n'The three met at Emirates mall then attended the prosecutor's office to find out what charges had been registered against her.'\n\nMs Towey, who graduated from the Dublin Institute Of Technology, moved to the UAE in April 2023\n\nTori is pictured in 2021, before her move to the UAE - where she now hopes to return to Ireland\n\nIrish premier Simon Harris has said he will work to intervene in the 'appalling' case, while Sinn Fein president Mary Lou McDonald raised Ms Towey's case in the Irish Parliament on Tuesday afternoon.\n\nMr Harris thanked Ms McDonald for bringing the case to his attention, saying: 'I'm not directly appraised of the situation, but I'm very happy to be directly appraised of it now.'\n\nHe said he would work with the deputy 'to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be - based on what you tell me - the most appalling circumstances'.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs told the Irish Daily Mail it was aware of the case and was offering consular assistance.\n\nMs McDonald told Dail Eireann that Ms Towey has been the victim of domestic violence and is subject to a travel ban over alleged charges.\n\nShe said she has spoken to Ms Towey, and that the 28-year-old's mother has travelled to Dubai to be with her.\n\n'Tori wants to come home, simple as that. She is a Roscommon woman and she wants to come home,' she said.\n\n'I am asking now, as a matter of absolute urgency, that we have a statement from this House, that you intervene Taoiseach, that the ambassador is called and that it is made absolutely plain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way, and an Irish citizen, an Irish woman will not be treated in this way.'\n\nRadha Stirling, CEO of DiD says Tori's husband attacked her with a knife and punched her, before slamming her arm in the bathroom door trying to break it. Pictured the injuries said to be from the alleged attack\n\nThe 28-year-old moved to the UAE in April 2023 when she was offered a job as a flight attendant with Emirates\n\nMr Harris responded saying he was not aware of Ms Towey's case, and thanked Ms McDonald for bringing it to his attention and that of the Minister of Foreign Affairs Micheal Martin.\n\nHe pledged to work 'to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be, based on what you tell me, the most appalling circumstances'.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs told the Irish Daily Mail it was aware of the case and was offering consular assistance.\n\nTalking to Sky News, Tori's aunt Ann Flynn said: 'She's doing her best.' She added: 'It's very stressful, it's stressful for all the family.'\n\nShe described her niece as 'a beautiful young woman' who is 'fun-loving and loved to travel'.\n\nMs Flynn said: 'She got the job of her dreams working for Emirates, and she could continue travelling with work.\n\n'She loved Dubai, and had a good network of friends there.'\n\nThe airline hostess has been told 'nothing could be done' and that the case will be going to court on July 18.\n\nIn 2018, one member of Dubai Police said that they would focus on treatment rather than punishment when it came to suicide victims, even thought suicide and suicide attempts are a crime in the country.\n\nBrig Ahmed bin Ghalaita, then director of Al Refaa Police Station, told The National: 'The move is taken to provide support to suicide attempters and deal with them as victims who need moral support and help.\n\n'Suicide cases are being examined by a police unit and experts in the psychology field to identify the causes behind their attempts and find solutions for them.'\n\nIt comes as earlier this year, British wives boasting of luxury new lives funded by millionaire husbands in Dubai have been warned they risk being dumped homeless on the streets at any moment.\n\nExperts have revealed a surge in complaints from not only women but also men betrayed and dumped by wealthy partners after upping sticks for the Middle East.\n\nThe alert comes amid a TikTok and Instagram trend of UK women sharing footage of spending sprees in the United Arab Emirates after wedding wealthy husbands.\n\nMail Online had also reported on an influx of expats pampered by rich partners, enjoying days filled with shopping trips, extravagant meals and property upgrades.\n\nYet there is a 'dark side' to Dubai that many women only discover too late, according to Manchester-based Aramas International Lawyers' Samara Iqbal.\n\nAdvice for British wives marrying and moving to the Middle East\n\nManchester-based lawyer Samara Iqbal has suggested potential brides moving abroad put these in place:\n\n1. A pre- or post-nuptial agreement which can be done in the UK or filed with the Abu Dhabi Civil Court\n\n2. A credit card/bank account in her own name with some emergency funds and money should she be 'cut off' from her partner's bank accounts\n\n3. A visa in her own name - as this could also be cancelled and she would need to leave within 30 days if she cannot arrange a visa for herself\n\n4. An agreement regarding the custody of any child/children - possibly in the pre-/post-nuptial agreement\n\n5. Ideally a car and some accommodation under her own name, should she find herself thrown out of the marital home\n\nAdvertisement\n\nShe told of being inundated with calls for help from not only women but also men wanting protection amid fears they have been - or could be - exploited by a partner promising an alluring new lifestyle in the Middle East.\n\nAnd she has issued a hitlist of warning signs for anyone feeling tempted - while also highlighting a new civil court in neighbouring Abu Dhabi which could offer more help to women stranded overseas and yet which remains little-known to many.\n\nMs Iqbal's firm is based in Manchester but a surge in cases has seen new branches open in Abu Dhabi, Qatar and Saudi Arabia.\n\nShe too is a watcher of TikTok videos promoting what seem to be aspirational lives in the Middle East - but is now warning women to beware of hidden dangers.\n\nShe outlined how many women find out only too late their husband might have as many as three other wives - and that while handing over upmarket clothes, cards and credit cards, everything remains documented in only his name.\n\nMs Iqbal told Mail Online: 'We've got lots of British women who are attracted by these promises of a luxurious lifestyle, even though their own families aren't happy about it - and not realising he can cut her off at any moment.\n\n'People are literally being dumped on the street. It looks nice, but there's a dark side to Dubai - it can be very scary out there if you find yourself in this position and don't know what your legal rights are.'\n\nHer firm is increasingly being approached for advice on potential pre-nuptial and also post-nuptial agreements as more and more women feel tempted by marriages to someone they've met here before moving together overseas.\n\nShe said: 'We often deal with cases more and more on a daily basis in which lots of women have married and moved out to the UAE only to be left stranded without any source of money and essentially being 'cut off' by their rich partners.\n\n'While these partners may be providing and funding their luxurious lifestyles - cars, designer items, expensive jewellery, holidays, meals out - none of this actually belongs to these women and there is nothing in their name. It's all in their partners name.\n\n'Women are thrown out of marital homes as they do not belong to them - credit cards cut off and they have no recourse to any of the possessions, houses, companies and assets the partner has solely in his own name.\n\n'These assets come under Sharia law and belongs to the person whose name its registered to and she would not be entitled to any of it if her name is not registered.'\n\nPotential husbands might swoop in during university days together, drinking and nightclubbing in a way they would no longer do when back in the UAE, she suggests.\n\nWomen are not the only ones at risk, according to Ms Iqbal - she described being asked for advice by men serenaded in London and promised a better life abroad but worried they could be abandoned or blackmailed over their sexuality.\n\nIn the past year a new civil court in Abu Dhabi has been opened which does recognise British civil orders and tends to look more favourably on UK wives wanting a settlement or at least joint custody of any children.\n\nYet too many people still remain unaware it exists, Ms Iqbal said.\n\nMs Towey's horrific story is not the first time Brits and Irish citizens in Dubai have been slammed with unfair charges.\n\nRadha Stirling - the founder of Detained in Duabi - was inspired to start up the organisation after in 2008 hearing that a colleague called Cat Le-Huy had been arrested by immigration officials in the nation.\n\nAt first, she assumed it was all a big mistake. Her friend, a London-based producer with whom she worked at the TV production company Endemol, had been initially detained because an unidentified bottle of pills was found in his suitcase.\n\nAfter they turned out to be melatonin, a perfectly legal jetlag medication, customs staff announced with a flourish that they had also discovered cannabis among some dust in the depths of the holidaymaker's bag.\n\nThe quantity of this illegal narcotic was, they claimed, exactly 0.03 grams. That's an amount smaller than a single grain of salt and virtually invisible to the human eye.\n\nCat, who hails from Belsize Park, North London, was promptly slapped in handcuffs and transported to the Al Wathba prison, 40 miles north of the airport.\n\nRadha knew that her friend did not take recreational drugs so, initially, thought he would be promptly released. But she was wrong. Instead, she was told to her horror that he faced a four-year prison sentence for 'drug possession'.\n\nIn the weeks that followed, she helped organise a noisy campaign on Cat's behalf, turning him into an international cause c\u00e9l\u00e8bre.\n\nFinally, after the best part of a month in custody, he was released without charge and allowed to return home.\n\nAs the dust settled, Radha was contacted by several other Westerners who claimed to be victims of grave miscarriages of justice in the tourist hotspot.\n\n'People were basically saying, 'I saw how you helped him, can you help me, too?' she said in an interview with the Daily Mail.\n\n'I suddenly realised that, behind the facade of this glamorous country, which touts its credentials as a popular destination with beaches and luxury hotels, there were huge problems with the rule of law and human rights, affecting vast numbers of innocent people.'\n\nShe duly founded Detained In Dubai, a pressure group that lobbies on behalf of victims of the Emirate state's hardline laws.\n\nAs of 2021, her organisation had helped an incredible 15,000 people -- an average of roughly three per day -- navigate a draconian legal system.\n\n'We have dealt with cases in which rape victims were prosecuted for unlawful sex, foreigners jailed over social media posts, people convicted on the basis of torture and forced confessions, and victims of gross police and prosecutorial misconduct of a variety that staggers the imagination,' she revealed.\n\n'All involve laws that people don't imagine could possibly exist in the modern era.'\n\nAmong the victims Radha has personally helped is Princess Latifa al-Maktoum, the daughter of Dubai's autocratic ruler Sheikh Mohammed al-Maktoum, who attempted to flee the country in a yacht in 2018.\n\nThe princess was under armed guard, in 2021 sharing videos telling how she had been seized by commandos while in international waters, before being transported back to Dubai, where she had claimed to have been held hostage ever since.\n\n'I spoke to Princess Latifa when she was on the boat and shots were going off,' Radha said. 'It was extremely harrowing. When even a member of the royal family is denied basic human rights, you can imagine how the country treats normal people who aren't even its citizens.'\n\nHowever, in 2022 the Princess Latifa said she is 'living as she wishes' a year after claiming she was being held against her will by her father.\n\nThese and other high-profile cases shine a light on the dark underbelly of a destination whose status as a celebrity hotspot is deeply at odds with its legal system, under which everything from drinking alcohol to holding hands in public and sharing a bedroom with someone who is not your spouse is officially unlawful, and consensual gay sex can earn you a prison sentence of ten years.\n\nAmong the victims Radha has personally helped is Princess Latifa al-Maktoum, the daughter of Dubai's autocratic ruler. The princess was under armed guard, in 2021 sharing videos (pictured) telling how she had been seized by commandos while in international waters, before being transported back to Dubai, where she had claimed to have been held hostage ever since\n\nAlmost any visitor is also at constant risk of prosecution under strict cyber-crime laws.\n\nShould they or any other foreigner fall foul of a policeman, minor royal, business leader or powerful local, the country's authorities can (and often do) trawl through historic social media posts.\n\n'These rules can, in theory, criminalise almost every Western visitor,' says Radha. 'If you're responsible for a Facebook post from five years ago they don't like, and if they want to go for you, then you are toast.'\n\nOne example was Briton Laleh Shahravesh, who was arrested in Dubai in 2019 following a complaint from a local that she had used the social network to brand her ex-husband's new partner 'horse-face'. She was arrested on arrival in the country and only allowed back to the UK several weeks later, after agreeing to pay a \u00a3625 fine for making the supposedly 'defamatory' claim.\n\nElsewhere Scott Richards, a 42-year-old father of two, was detained in 2016 after the police took exception to a Facebook post in which he had shared a link to a crowd-funding campaign to supply blankets for Afghan refugees.\n\nHe spent three weeks behind bars because of a law that bans soliciting donations for non-profits that have not been approved by the government's 'Islamic Affairs and Charitable Activities' department.\n\nIn 2021, Detained In Dubai was also representing a 31-year-old HR manager from Gloucestershire arrested at the airport as she tried to return home after three years living in the country.\n\nHer alleged 'crime' is having told her ex-flatmate to 'f*** off' in a WhatsApp message, during a row over the use of the dining table at their home during lockdown. This is also, apparently, defamatory.\n\nFor years, Sheikh Maktoum (pictured in 2019) has often intervened when ugly legal cases threaten his country's international reputation\n\nIt is women's rights that are most commonly abused. A 2005 law states that 'a husband's rights over his wife' include the wife's 'courteous obedience to him', and places conditions on a married woman's right to work or leave the house.\n\nThese rules are routinely used by estranged husbands to exert control over their spouses, even when both parties are Western expats.\n\nRadha says: 'We had one client, a German woman in the process of separating from her husband, who had decided to get a job. Her husband rang up the company and said, 'I didn't give her permission' and they had to fire her.'\n\nIn Dubai, extra-marital sex is punishable by one year or more in prison. On the basis of this law, Amnesty says, a Swedish-run hospital in Ajman Emirate was forced to report pregnant, unmarried women to the police.\n\nThree years ago, a 29-year-old South African resident of Dubai called Emlyn Culverwell took his fianc\u00e9e, Iryna Nohal, a Ukrainian, to a doctor, complaining of stomach pain.\n\nHe promptly diagnosed that she was pregnant. But rather than offering treatment, the doctor called the police. The couple were arrested and jailed when they could not produce a marriage license.\n\nEventually, they were released, apparently at the behest of Sheikh Maktoum. For years, he often intervened when ugly legal cases threaten his country's international reputation.\n\nIf you need to talk to someone, call the Samaritans for free on 116 123 or visit {"uri": "8219191352", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "18:05:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T18:05:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T18:05:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/tori-towey-dubai-suicide-attempt-alleged-domestic-violence-uae/", "title": "Tori Towey, woman detained in Dubai over suicide attempt amid alleged domestic violence, allowed to leave UAE", "body": "An Irish woman who had been charged by authorities in the United Arab Emirates with attempting suicide and alcohol consumption has been permitted to leave the country after being detained briefly, a legal advocacy group says.\n\nTori Towey, 28, from Ireland's County Roscommon, had been a crew member with Emirates Airlines since April 2023, was briefly detained and had her passport confiscated and destroyed, the \"Detained in Dubai\" (DiD) legal group said.\n\nDiD said Towey had been the victim of \"brutal domestic violence leading to an attempt to take her own life\" in Dubai.\n\n\"Rather than helping her go home to Ireland with her mother, Dubai authorities charged her with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption,\" the group said in a statement.\n\nMary Lou McDonald, leader of Ireland's Sinn F\u00e9in political party, confirmed Wednesday that Towey \"will now travel home\" after the travel ban, apparently along with case against Towey, was dropped. McDonald said the Irishwoman would return home with her mother from Dubai, adding: \"We await her safe return.\"\n\nThe opposition party leader had brought Towey's plight to the attention of Ireland's national leader, Taoiseach Simon Harris, during a parliamentary session on Tuesday, stressing that the cabin crew member \"is not a criminal, she is a victim of abuse.\"\n\n\"The Taoiseach must intervene, the UAE Ambassador must be called in and it must be made clear to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way, and an Irish citizen will not be treated in this way,\" McDonald said in a social media post on Tuesday.\n\nIreland's Minister of Foreign Affairs Miche\u00e1l Martin also confirmed that Towey had been permitted to return to Ireland in a tweet on Wednesday.\n\nAccording to DiD, Towey was physically and emotionally abused by her South African husband, whom she met while working in the Emirates. DiD said the man, whom it has not identified, was dismissed by UAE authorities after facing questioning over \"behavioral issues.\"\n\n\"He cut her off from her friends and family. If we tried to contact her, she got in trouble,\" Towey's mother Caroline, who few to Dubai to be with her daughter, told DiD.\n\nDiD said that after the most recent alleged attack by her spouse, Towey locked herself in a bathroom at their home and attempted to take her life.\n\n\"The next thing she remembers is an ambulance crew and police waking her up. She was taken to Al Barsha police station and kept for several hours before going home again,\" the group said.\n\n\"Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive,\" said Radha Stirling, CEO of Detained in Dubai and another advocacy group called Due Process International.\n\n\"The UAE used to charge rape victims with sex outside marriage. Now they're charging domestic violence victims with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption,\" Stirling said. \"Dubai police need to be educated on victim care.\"\n\nMedia in the UAE, a tightly controlled conservative Islamic nation, did not report on Towey's case. The Roscommon woman was detained under charges of attempted suicide and consuming alcohol. Following her detention in the UAE, she was barred from leaving the nation.\n\nIrish Premier Simon Harris earlier informed the Parliament about the development. \"I've just been informed that the travel ban has been lifted, that the embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go and that the embassy of course will continue to follow up on the case, which is still active as of now,\" he said.\n\nEarlier, the leader of the main opposition party in Ireland had raised the issue of Tori Towey's detention in the parliament for the second day in a row.\n\nAlso read: Thousands of Indian millionaires relocating to UAE in 2024, says report\n\nThe premier said now that Towey was free to walk out of the UAE, she would be brought back home as soon as possible.\n\n\"We want Tori Towey back in this country, we want her back home in Roscommon,\" said Harris. \"No effort will be spared by us, by Ireland, to make progress on this matter, to get Tori home. She's not a criminal, she's a victim of gender-based violence,\" he added.\n\n\"The embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go,\" the premier told D\u00e1il (lower house of the Irish parliament).\n\nAlso read: Lost city from 4th century famous for its pearls discovered near UAE\n\nEarlier, he criticised the UAE over how the Irish national was being treated in the Arab nation. "date": "2024-07-10", "textStart": 175, "textEnd": 181, "freq": 2}], "sentiment": 0.05098039215686279, "wgt": 183, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8218689850", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:25:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:25:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:25:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13619903/Air-stewardess-FREED-Dubai-allowed-return-Ireland-detained-attempting-suicide-beaten-husband.html", "title": "Air stewardess FREED in Dubai after 'attempting suicide'", "body": "Irish premier Simon Harris has said that a travel ban imposed by Dubai authorities on Irish woman Tori Towey, who was reportedly charged with attempted suicide, has been lifted.\n\nTori Towey, 28, a flight attendant from Co Roscommon, was charged with attempted suicide and alcohol abuse after waking up in a police station after an attack, Irish parliamentarians were told.\n\nDubai authorities had also banned her from leaving the state, the Dail chamber heard.\n\nAddressing the Irish parliament on Wednesday afternoon, Mr Harris said: 'I've just been informed that the travel ban has been lifted, that the embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go and that the embassy of course will continue to follow up on the case, which is still active as of now.'\n\nHe thanked the Irish embassy in the United Arab Emirates for their work on the case.\n\nIt comes hours after Tori's mother said she was 'desperate to get home' and has been through 'the worst time of her life'.\n\nTowey had been banned from leaving the UAE and told she faced jail for drinking alcohol and attempting to take her own life following an alleged beating by her husband.\n\nTori Towey has been left stranded in Dubai after being faced with an attempted suicide charge\n\nTori was pictured with extensive bruises over her body, which she says are from an assault\n\nTori, pictured left with aunt, has been banned from leaving the UAE and told she faces jail for drinking alcohol and attempting to take her own life\n\nDubai's draconian laws: Why attempting suicide and drinking alcohol is a 'crime'\n\nPrior to 2019, anyone found guilty of attempting suicide in Dubai faced a 5000AED fine (\u00a31050) or six months in prison.\n\nThe 'offence' was one of 28 'minor crimes' downgraded to free up space in the Emirates' overcrowded courts system.\n\nThose found guilty of attempting suicide in the Gulf state now have to pay a fine of 1000AED (\u00a3210) instead of facing a judge.\n\nIn the same year, the Gulf state loosened its liquor laws to allow tourists to purchase alcohol in state-controlled stores, previously only accessible to licence-holding residents.\n\nThe new laws also let visitors obtain liquor permits themselves for the first time, by applying online or going to a registered alcohol store to get one for free.\n\nWhile visitors must have a permit, it's no longer a criminal offence not to have one.\n\nA 30 per cent tax on alcohol was also axed on New Year's Eve 2022 to encourage tourists to flock to the Emirate.\n\nWhile the relaxation of the laws sends a message that it's safe to drink, the reality is more complicated.\n\nIt is illegal to drink or even be under the influence of alcohol in public outside of a licensed premises.\n\nRadha Stirling, founder and CEO of Detained in Dubai previously told MailOnline: 'Reducing the cost of alcohol in Dubai is sending a clear message to tourists and that is to drink. Considering Dubai's alcohol laws prohibit the possession of alcohol in public, drinking in Dubai is inherently dangerous.\n\n'If a visitor's blood is tested and shows up even one drink, they can be criminally charged. Alcohol tests are often conducted when a complaint is made by a local. If a local is offended by a visitor's dress sense, language or behaviour, they may call the police and have the visitor arrested, even if that person has only consumed a small beer.\n\n'Dubai's laws are highly contradictory. On the one hand, people are encouraged to drink but on the other, it's a criminal offence to have any amount of alcohol in your blood in public. Encouraging visitors to drink more alcohol will most certainly result in increased detentions of Brits abroad in prisons notorious for human rights abuses and police brutality'.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nTori's mum Caroline told MailOnline: 'The support from the Irish government and the Irish people has been incredible and we weren't expecting it at all. It's a small country and the politicians are real people.\n\n'We are both exhausted and desperate to get home. Thank you so much to everyone supporting us.'\n\nShe added that her daughter had been through 'the worst time of her life and needs to come home with me and heal'.\n\nTori's aunt Ann Flynn also told Sky News: 'She's doing her best. It's very stressful, stressful for all the family.\n\n'Tori's a beautiful young woman, fun-loving, loves to travel. She got the job of her dreams working for Emirates, and she could continue travelling with work.'\n\n'It's really terrible that this has happened to a young woman who was full of life and full of adventure.'\n\nA spokesperson for legal group Detained in Dubai (DiD) claimed Tori's South African husband went after her with a knife and punched her, before slamming her arm in the bathroom door trying to break it.\n\nTori said she tried to take her own life after the attack, which left her with severe bruises and injuries.\n\nBut after being taken to a police station, Ms Towey is now facing charges of alcohol consumption and attempting suicide by a court in Dubai.\n\nShe said she is unable to leave the country as her passport was blocked, meaning she can't travel back home to Ireland.\n\nSpeaking through outreach group DiD, who are assisting the family, Ms Towey said: 'I don't know what's going to happen in court next week.\n\n'I'm desperate to go home to Ireland and put all of this in the past. I'm asking the Taoiseach to please help us.'\n\nThe DiD has said Ms Towey could face a lengthy prison sentence in a jail known for 'human rights abuses and torture'.\n\nRadha Stirling, CEO of Detained in Dubai, said: 'We are calling on Dubai authorities to urgently drop the charges against Tori, remove the travel ban and let her fly home to Ireland with her mother. She has been charged with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\n\n'Strangely, the UAE has gone to great public relations efforts to promote alcohol as legal in the country. In reality, people are still regularly charged with alcohol consumption and possession. Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive.'\n\nShe explained: 'Tori arranged to fly home to Ireland but, when she arrived at the airport, was told a case against her by her husband had been dropped but the travel ban remained.\n\n'She attended the police station who assured her the travel ban would be lifted but it never happened. The next day, Tori and her husband had some wine and he became enraged, accusing her of having an affair.'\n\nMs Towey then attempted to take her own life and ended up in a police station.\n\nMs Stirling explained: 'The next thing she remembers is an ambulance crew and police waking her up. She was taken to Al Barsha police station and kept for several hours before going home again.\n\n'Her mother pleaded to the Irish Consulate but in the absence of their assistance, boarded a flight to Dubai. When she arrived, she wasn't allowed to see Tori alone, her abuser wouldn't allow it.\n\n'The three met at Emirates mall then attended the prosecutor's office to find out what charges had been registered against her.'\n\nMs Towey, who graduated from the Dublin Institute Of Technology, moved to the UAE in April 2023\n\nTori is pictured in 2021, before her move to the UAE - where she now hopes to return to Ireland\n\nBe the first to commentBe one of the first to commentCommentsShould Ireland intervene to bring Tori Towey home from Dubai?Comment now\n\nIrish premier Simon Harris has said he will work to intervene in the 'appalling' case, while Sinn Fein president Mary Lou McDonald raised Ms Towey's case in the Irish Parliament on Tuesday afternoon.\n\nMr Harris thanked Ms McDonald for bringing the case to his attention, saying: 'I'm not directly appraised of the situation, but I'm very happy to be directly appraised of it now.'\n\nHe said he would work with the deputy 'to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be - based on what you tell me - the most appalling circumstances'.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs told the Irish Daily Mail it was aware of the case and was offering consular assistance.\n\nMs McDonald told Dail Eireann that Ms Towey has been the victim of domestic violence and is subject to a travel ban over alleged charges.\n\nShe said she has spoken to Ms Towey, and that the 28-year-old's mother has travelled to Dubai to be with her.\n\n'Tori wants to come home, simple as that. She is a Roscommon woman and she wants to come home,' she said.\n\n'I am asking now, as a matter of absolute urgency, that we have a statement from this House, that you intervene Taoiseach, that the ambassador is called and that it is made absolutely plain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way, and an Irish citizen, an Irish woman will not be treated in this way.'\n\nRadha Stirling, CEO of DiD says Tori's husband attacked her with a knife and punched her, before slamming her arm in the bathroom door trying to break it. Pictured the injuries said to be from the alleged attack\n\nThe 28-year-old moved to the UAE in April 2023 when she was offered a job as a flight attendant with Emirates\n\nMr Harris responded saying he was not aware of Ms Towey's case, and thanked Ms McDonald for bringing it to his attention and that of the Minister of Foreign Affairs Micheal Martin.\n\nHe pledged to work 'to intervene and see how we can support an Irish citizen in what sounds to be, based on what you tell me, the most appalling circumstances'.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs told the Irish Daily Mail it was aware of the case and was offering consular assistance.\n\nTalking to Sky News, Tori's aunt Ann Flynn said: 'She's doing her best.' She added: 'It's very stressful, it's stressful for all the family.'\n\nShe described her niece as 'a beautiful young woman' who is 'fun-loving and loved to travel'.\n\nMs Flynn said: 'She got the job of her dreams working for Emirates, and she could continue travelling with work.\n\n'She loved Dubai, and had a good network of friends there.'\n\nThe airline hostess has been told 'nothing could be done' and that the case will be going to court on July 18.\n\nIn 2018, one member of Dubai Police said that they would focus on treatment rather than punishment when it came to suicide victims, even thought suicide and suicide attempts are a crime in the country.\n\nBrig Ahmed bin Ghalaita, then director of Al Refaa Police Station, told The National: 'The move is taken to provide support to suicide attempters and deal with them as victims who need moral support and help.\n\n'Suicide cases are being examined by a police unit and experts in the psychology field to identify the causes behind their attempts and find solutions for them.'\n\nIt comes as earlier this year, British wives boasting of luxury new lives funded by millionaire husbands in Dubai have been warned they risk being dumped homeless on the streets at any moment.\n\nExperts have revealed a surge in complaints from not only women but also men betrayed and dumped by wealthy partners after upping sticks for the Middle East.\n\nThe alert comes amid a TikTok and Instagram trend of UK women sharing footage of spending sprees in the United Arab Emirates after wedding wealthy husbands.\n\nMail Online had also reported on an influx of expats pampered by rich partners, enjoying days filled with shopping trips, extravagant meals and property upgrades.\n\nYet there is a 'dark side' to Dubai that many women only discover too late, according to Manchester-based Aramas International Lawyers' Samara Iqbal.\n\nAdvice for British wives marrying and moving to the Middle East\n\nManchester-based lawyer Samara Iqbal has suggested potential brides moving abroad put these in place:\n\n1. A pre- or post-nuptial agreement which can be done in the UK or filed with the Abu Dhabi Civil Court\n\n2. A credit card/bank account in her own name with some emergency funds and money should she be 'cut off' from her partner's bank accounts\n\n3. A visa in her own name - as this could also be cancelled and she would need to leave within 30 days if she cannot arrange a visa for herself\n\n4. An agreement regarding the custody of any child/children - possibly in the pre-/post-nuptial agreement\n\n5. Ideally a car and some accommodation under her own name, should she find herself thrown out of the marital home\n\nAdvertisement\n\nShe told of being inundated with calls for help from not only women but also men wanting protection amid fears they have been - or could be - exploited by a partner promising an alluring new lifestyle in the Middle East.\n\nAnd she has issued a hitlist of warning signs for anyone feeling tempted - while also highlighting a new civil court in neighbouring Abu Dhabi which could offer more help to women stranded overseas and yet which remains little-known to many.\n\nMs Iqbal's firm is based in Manchester but a surge in cases has seen new branches open in Abu Dhabi, Qatar and Saudi Arabia.\n\nShe too is a watcher of TikTok videos promoting what seem to be aspirational lives in the Middle East - but is now warning women to beware of hidden dangers.\n\nShe outlined how many women find out only too late their husband might have as many as three other wives - and that while handing over upmarket clothes, cards and credit cards, everything remains documented in only his name.\n\nMs Iqbal told Mail Online: 'We've got lots of British women who are attracted by these promises of a luxurious lifestyle, even though their own families aren't happy about it - and not realising he can cut her off at any moment.\n\n'People are literally being dumped on the street. It looks nice, but there's a dark side to Dubai - it can be very scary out there if you find yourself in this position and don't know what your legal rights are.'\n\nHer firm is increasingly being approached for advice on potential pre-nuptial and also post-nuptial agreements as more and more women feel tempted by marriages to someone they've met here before moving together overseas.\n\nShe said: 'We often deal with cases more and more on a daily basis in which lots of women have married and moved out to the UAE only to be left stranded without any source of money and essentially being 'cut off' by their rich partners.\n\n'While these partners may be providing and funding their luxurious lifestyles - cars, designer items, expensive jewellery, holidays, meals out - none of this actually belongs to these women and there is nothing in their name. It's all in their partners name.\n\n'Women are thrown out of marital homes as they do not belong to them - credit cards cut off and they have no recourse to any of the possessions, houses, companies and assets the partner has solely in his own name.\n\n'These assets come under Sharia law and belongs to the person whose name its registered to and she would not be entitled to any of it if her name is not registered.'\n\nPotential husbands might swoop in during university days together, drinking and nightclubbing in a way they would no longer do when back in the UAE, she suggests.\n\nWomen are not the only ones at risk, according to Ms Iqbal - she described being asked for advice by men serenaded in London and promised a better life abroad but worried they could be abandoned or blackmailed over their sexuality.\n\nIn the past year a new civil court in Abu Dhabi has been opened which does recognise British civil orders and tends to look more favourably on UK wives wanting a settlement or at least joint custody of any children.\n\nYet too many people still remain unaware it exists, Ms Iqbal said.\n\nMs Towey's horrific story is not the first time Brits and Irish citizens in Dubai have been slammed with unfair charges.\n\nRadha Stirling - the founder of Detained in Duabi - was inspired to start up the organisation after in 2008 hearing that a colleague called Cat Le-Huy had been arrested by immigration officials in the nation.\n\nAt first, she assumed it was all a big mistake. Her friend, a London-based producer with whom she worked at the TV production company Endemol, had been initially detained because an unidentified bottle of pills was found in his suitcase.\n\nAfter they turned out to be melatonin, a perfectly legal jetlag medication, customs staff announced with a flourish that they had also discovered cannabis among some dust in the depths of the holidaymaker's bag.\n\nThe quantity of this illegal narcotic was, they claimed, exactly 0.03 grams. That's an amount smaller than a single grain of salt and virtually invisible to the human eye.\n\nCat, who hails from Belsize Park, North London, was promptly slapped in handcuffs and transported to the Al Wathba prison, 40 miles north of the airport.\n\nRadha knew that her friend did not take recreational drugs so, initially, thought he would be promptly released. But she was wrong. Instead, she was told to her horror that he faced a four-year prison sentence for 'drug possession'.\n\nIn the weeks that followed, she helped organise a noisy campaign on Cat's behalf, turning him into an international cause c\u00e9l\u00e8bre.\n\nFinally, after the best part of a month in custody, he was released without charge and allowed to return home.\n\nAs the dust settled, Radha was contacted by several other Westerners who claimed to be victims of grave miscarriages of justice in the tourist hotspot.\n\n'People were basically saying, 'I saw how you helped him, can you help me, too?' she said in an interview with the Daily Mail.\n\n'I suddenly realised that, behind the facade of this glamorous country, which touts its credentials as a popular destination with beaches and luxury hotels, there were huge problems with the rule of law and human rights, affecting vast numbers of innocent people.'\n\nShe duly founded Detained In Dubai, a pressure group that lobbies on behalf of victims of the Emirate state's hardline laws.\n\nAs of 2021, her organisation had helped an incredible 15,000 people -- an average of roughly three per day -- navigate a draconian legal system.\n\n'We have dealt with cases in which rape victims were prosecuted for unlawful sex, foreigners jailed over social media posts, people convicted on the basis of torture and forced confessions, and victims of gross police and prosecutorial misconduct of a variety that staggers the imagination,' she revealed.\n\n'All involve laws that people don't imagine could possibly exist in the modern era.'\n\nAmong the victims Radha has personally helped is Princess Latifa al-Maktoum, the daughter of Dubai's autocratic ruler Sheikh Mohammed al-Maktoum, who attempted to flee the country in a yacht in 2018.\n\nThe princess was under armed guard, in 2021 sharing videos telling how she had been seized by commandos while in international waters, before being transported back to Dubai, where she had claimed to have been held hostage ever since.\n\n'I spoke to Princess Latifa when she was on the boat and shots were going off,' Radha said. 'It was extremely harrowing. When even a member of the royal family is denied basic human rights, you can imagine how the country treats normal people who aren't even its citizens.'\n\nHowever, in 2022 the Princess Latifa said she is 'living as she wishes' a year after claiming she was being held against her will by her father.\n\nThese and other high-profile cases shine a light on the dark underbelly of a destination whose status as a celebrity hotspot is deeply at odds with its legal system, under which everything from drinking alcohol to holding hands in public and sharing a bedroom with someone who is not your spouse is officially unlawful, and consensual gay sex can earn you a prison sentence of ten years.\n\nAmong the victims Radha has personally helped is Princess Latifa al-Maktoum, the daughter of Dubai's autocratic ruler. The princess was under armed guard, in 2021 sharing videos (pictured) telling how she had been seized by commandos while in international waters, before being transported back to Dubai, where she had claimed to have been held hostage ever since\n\nAlmost any visitor is also at constant risk of prosecution under strict cyber-crime laws.\n\nShould they or any other foreigner fall foul of a policeman, minor royal, business leader or powerful local, the country's authorities can (and often do) trawl through historic social media posts.\n\n'These rules can, in theory, criminalise almost every Western visitor,' says Radha. 'If you're responsible for a Facebook post from five years ago they don't like, and if they want to go for you, then you are toast.'\n\nOne example was Briton Laleh Shahravesh, who was arrested in Dubai in 2019 following a complaint from a local that she had used the social network to brand her ex-husband's new partner 'horse-face'. She was arrested on arrival in the country and only allowed back to the UK several weeks later, after agreeing to pay a \u00a3625 fine for making the supposedly 'defamatory' claim.\n\nElsewhere Scott Richards, a 42-year-old father of two, was detained in 2016 after the police took exception to a Facebook post in which he had shared a link to a crowd-funding campaign to supply blankets for Afghan refugees.\n\nHe spent three weeks behind bars because of a law that bans soliciting donations for non-profits that have not been approved by the government's 'Islamic Affairs and Charitable Activities' department.\n\nIn 2021, Detained In Dubai was also representing a 31-year-old HR manager from Gloucestershire arrested at the airport as she tried to return home after three years living in the country.\n\nHer alleged 'crime' is having told her ex-flatmate to 'f*** off' in a WhatsApp message, during a row over the use of the dining table at their home during lockdown. This is also, apparently, defamatory.\n\nFor years, Sheikh Maktoum (pictured in 2019) has often intervened when ugly legal cases threaten his country's international reputation\n\nIt is women's rights that are most commonly abused. A 2005 law states that 'a husband's rights over his wife' include the wife's 'courteous obedience to him', and places conditions on a married woman's right to work or leave the house.\n\nThese rules are routinely used by estranged husbands to exert control over their spouses, even when both parties are Western expats.\n\nRadha says: 'We had one client, a German woman in the process of separating from her husband, who had decided to get a job. Her husband rang up the company and said, 'I didn't give her permission' and they had to fire her.'\n\nIn Dubai, extra-marital sex is punishable by one year or more in prison. On the basis of this law, Amnesty says, a Swedish-run hospital in Ajman Emirate was forced to report pregnant, unmarried women to the police.\n\nThree years ago, a 29-year-old South African resident of Dubai called Emlyn Culverwell took his fianc\u00e9e, Iryna Nohal, a Ukrainian, to a doctor, complaining of stomach pain.\n\nHe promptly diagnosed that she was pregnant. But rather than offering treatment, the doctor called the police. The couple were arrested and jailed when they could not produce a marriage license.\n\nEventually, they were released, apparently at the behest of Sheikh Maktoum. For years, he often intervened when ugly legal cases threaten his country's international reputation.\n\nIf you need to talk to someone, call the Samaritans for free on 116 123 or visit {"uri": "8218732326", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:53:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:53:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:52:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.meathchronicle.ie/2024/07/10/harris-confirms-travel-ban-on-irish-woman-detained-in-dubai-has-been-lifted/", "title": "Harris confirms travel ban on Irish woman detained in Dubai has been lifted | Meath Chronicle", "body": "Harris confirms travel ban on Irish woman detained in Dubai has been lifted RSS Syndicated Content Published: Wed 10 Jul 2024, 1:15 PM Last updated: Wed 10 Jul 2024, 1:44 PM\n\nTaoiseach Simon Harris has confirmed a travel ban imposed by authorities in Dubai on Irish woman Tori Towey has been lifted.\n\nMs Towey had been banned from leaving the United Arab Emirates (UAE) after she was charged with attempted suicide and consuming alcohol in Dubai.\n\n\"I've just been informed that the travel ban has been lifted, that the embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go and that the embassy, of course, will continue to follow up on the case, which is still active as of now,\" Mr Harris told the D\u00e1il on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nMr Harris thanked the Irish embassy in the UAE for its work on the case, and Sinn F\u00e9in leader Mary Lou McDonald and Roscommon TD Claire Kerrane who had raised the matter in the D\u00e1il on Tuesday.\n\nSpeaking in the D\u00e1il on Wednesday, Ms McDonald criticised the \"medieval, grotesque treatment of women\" in the UAE.\n\n\"(Tori) does not belong to Dubai, she belongs at home in Ireland,\" Ms McDonald said.\n\nT\u00e1naiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs Miche\u00e1l Martin paid tribute to the Irish Ambassador to the UAE, Alison Milton, for her role in the matter.\n\nSpeaking on RT\u00c9 radio's News at One, Mr Martin said he had anticipated \"good news\" from Tuesday evening. However, he said there was a process to go through, and he could not comment on cases until it was completed.\n\nHe said he anticipated that Ms Towey and her mother Caroline, who had travelled to Dubai to support her daughter, would be returning to Ireland at the earliest opportunity now Ms Towey's passport had been returned.\n\nThe T\u00e1naiste said Ms Milton and her team in the UAE had opened up \"good channels of communication and engagement\" with local authorities, which had facilitated the lifting of charges against Ms Towey.\n\n\"It has been very, very challenging and traumatic for Tori over the last while, but I think our team there has been in contact and has engaged with the family, and indeed with the authorities as well, and it's been a constructive engagement and they have responded with the issue being resolved,\" Mr Martin said.\n\nAdvertisementThat's the importance of very strong diplomats on the ground\n\nHe added: \"Different jurisdictions have different norms, and different approaches which sometimes don't approximate to ours, but we work with the authorities in such situations, and we work to try and resolve issues of this kind.\n\n\"That's the importance of very strong diplomats on the ground. People have good relationships and work those relationships to get the best outcomes for our citizens when difficulties and when challenges arise.\"\n\n\"Our objective always is to make the best judgment calls and to work as effectively as we can to bring about resolutions for our citizens, positive outcomes for our citizens, and I'm glad, in this case with Tori, that we've managed to do that and to be of assistance to her.\"\n\nThe update comes after the Government was commended by a human rights group for its swift action regarding Ms Towey's case.\n\nThe chief executive of Detained in Dubai, Radha Stirling, told Newstalk radio on Wednesday morning: \"I'm super impressed by Ireland's response, it was so swift.\"\n\n\"When a government gets behind their citizens, when they go the extra mile, they are successful in getting citizens home.\"\n\nMs Stirling outlined the background of the case, explaining Ms Towey had moved to Dubai last year to pursue an aviation career.\n\n\"She was working as cabin crew for Emirates Airlines, and she ended up marrying a South African man.\n\n\"Things went south very quickly, and he became physically abusive to her. She went to hospital and had severe injuries.\n\n\"After that, there was another assault, and she broke free, ran up to the bathroom, and she woke up with paramedics and police over her, and she was taken to the police station and actually charged with attempted suicide and consuming alcohol,\" Ms Stirling said.\n\nOn the outpouring of support for Ms Towey, Ms Stirling added: \"It's amazing to see people really standing behind her and wanting her home as soon as possible.\"\n\nIf you have been affected by any of the issues raised in this article, you can contact Women's Aid (24-hour freephone helpline at 1800-341 900, email helpline@womensaid.ie), Men's Aid Ireland (confidential helpline at 01-554 3811, email hello@mensaid.ie), or the Samaritans (24-hour confidential freephone helpline at 116 123, email jo@samaritans.org) for support and information. Safe Ireland also offers a number of local services and helplines at i.\n\n-Additional reporting by PA and Vivienne Clarke.\n\nRSS Syndicated Content Published: Wed 10 Jul 2024, 1:15 PM Last updated: So, if the police drop the case against her, she will be able to get her passport and leave the country,\" Ms Stirling said.\n\nYesterday, Taoiseach Simon Harris told the D\u00e1il that he is ready to \"intervene\" in Ms Towey's case.\n\nMs Stirling said Ms Towey and her mother have been \"really, really warmed at the Irish community, at the Irish Government\" and \"everyone rallying behind them and 100% supporting them.\"\n\nMs Towey has lived in Dubai since last year after she got a job with Emirates Airlines.\n\nMs Stirling said: \"I think when it comes to a case like this, it's all about diplomacy. {"uri": "8217689867", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "22:14:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T22:14:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T22:13:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.irishexaminer.com/news/arid-41432920.html", "title": "Irish woman detained in Dubai after 'attempted suicide' when fleeing domestic violence", "body": "The case of Tori Towey, 28, who faces criminal charges in Dubai of \"attempted suicide\" and alcohol consumption, has been raised in the D\u00e1il.\n\nMs Towey had been hospitalised with extensive injuries after an alleged assault by her husband.\n\nHer plight was raised in the D\u00e1il by Sinn F\u00e9in's Mary Lou McDonald, who said: \"Her passport has been destroyed. There was a travel ban imposed on her and she had gone to the authorities seeking protection many times but to absolutely no avail.\n\n\"But following one particularly severe beating in which her husband repeatedly tried to slam doors on her arms and break her limbs, she escaped upstairs, and she attempted to take her own life.\n\n\"The system over there, rather than protecting this woman, who is an Irish citizen, chose instead to detain her, to charge her.\n\n\"Tori wants to come home. Simple as that. She's a Roscommon woman, she wants to come home.\n\n\"And I'm asking now as a matter of absolute urgency that we have a statement from this house, that you intervene, that the ambassador is called and it made absolutely plain to the authorities of Dubai that no woman should be treated in this way. And an Irish citizen, an Irish woman, will not be treated in this way.\"\n\nMs Towey moved to the emirate last year to work as an airline attendant.\n\nShe married a man in March but, according to Roscommon TD Claire Kerrane, she soon began being mentally and physically abused.\n\nMs Kerrane has spoken to Ms Towey and her mother Caroline, who is now with her in Dubai.\n\n\"It's a living nightmare,\" Ms Kerrane said.\n\n\"She was put in a cell with 50 women, there was no information, she wasn't told why she had been arrested, what she was being charged with. Then there's the language barrier too. It's just horrendous.\n\n\"There was a small bit of alcohol in her system so she was charged with alcohol abuse. And with 'attempted suicide'.\"\n\nAlthough Ms Towey went to the police, she was told to go home to her husband, Ms Kerrane said.\n\n\"He ripped up her passport, so she couldn't work as an airline attendant, then she had no money, so she couldn't come home.\"\n\nA travel ban was also placed on her passport so she could not escape.\n\nDuring one allegedly brutal attack in her home, it's understood she escaped into the bathroom and tried to take her own life in a bid to escape her husband, fearing he would torture her to death.\n\n\"The next thing she knew, paramedics were there,\" Ms Kerrane said.\n\n\"Then she was arrested on June 28 and had no idea what she had been arrested for.\"\n\nMs Towey is now hiding in Dubai with her mother and hoping for help.\n\nThey are too scared to talk to the media as they fear it is illegal to do so.\n\n\"They can't speak so we have to speak for them,\" Ms Kerrane said.\n\nA court date has been set for July 18.\n\n\"And we're in the last week of the D\u00e1il so there's that pressure too,\" said Ms Kerrane.\n\nHowever, politicians now plan to work cross-party in a bid to get the Irish woman back home to safety and Taoiseach Simon Harris has said he's ready to intervene in the case.\n\n\"She said today: 'I just want to come home,'\" Ms Kerrane said.\n\n\"Hopefully now the Irish authorities can do something to get her home.\"\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs says it is aware of the case and is providing consular assistance.\n\nConsular assistance has been provided to the family for a number of weeks and T\u00e1naiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs Miche\u00e1l Martin is speaking to his officials in Dubai.\n\nRadha Stirling, chief executive at the human rights organisation Detained in Dubai, who has been helping the Toweys, said: \"It's amazing that authorities did not intervene for Tori's protection, given the state her body was in when she was hospitalised the first time.\n\n\"Worse than failing her, authorities in Dubai actually travel-banned her and kept her in the country when she was trying to get away.\n\n\"The UAE used to charge rape victims with 'sex outside marriage'. Now they're charging domestic violence victims with 'attempted suicide' and alcohol consumption. Dubai police need to be educated on victim care.\"", "source": {"uri": "irishexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Irish Examiner"}, "authors": [{"uri": "liz_dunphy@irishexaminer.com", "name": {"uri": "8219352662", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "20:38:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T20:38:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T20:37:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.newstalk.com/news/tori-toweys-treatment-in-dubai-as-medieval-mcdonald-1743904", "title": "Tori Towey's treatment in Dubai as 'medieval' - McDonald | Newstalk", "body": "Mary Lou McDonald has described the treatment of Tori Towey in Dubai as \"medieval\" and said the State will need to learn lessons from her ordeal.\n\nThe 28-year-old woman from Boyle, County Roscommon was detained in Dubai after she was charged with attempting suicide.\n\nMs Towey said she had been injured during an attack in her own home.\n\nYesterday, Ms Towey's case was raised by Sinn F\u00e9in President Mary Lou McDonald at Leaders' Questions and Taoiseach Simon Harris promised to look into the matter.\n\n\"I hate sharing this because it's such private trauma but it's now on the public record,\" Deputy McDonald told The Hard Shoulder.\n\n\"In any event, that's the level of desperation that she was driven to.\n\n\"She awoke to paramedics treating her and rather than being taken to a hospital, she was taken to a police station where she was then charged with attempted suicide and alcohol abuse.\n\nMs Towey was then released on bail and her mother travelled to Dubai with her.\n\nThe family reached out to Sinn F\u00e9in two days ago out of a sense of \"desperation\" and the party decided to raise Ms Towey's case in the D\u00e1il.\n\nDeputy McDonald said she believes the public outrage in Ireland \"moved the dial\" and saw the travel ban was lifted today.\n\n\"I still don't know - because it hasn't been clarified - whether or not the charges that were made against her have been dropped,\" she said.\n\n\"They should be; it's absolutely outrageous, outlandish and just unacceptable that a victim of... violence and brutality, who needs support and protection, finds herself as the accused.\n\nDeputy McDonald described the decision to charge Ms Towey as \"medieval\" given what she had been through and a lesson Irish diplomats will need to learn from.\n\n\"It's utterly barbaric and it's not acceptable,\" she said.\n\n\"Let's also say this loud and clear; no Irish woman, no Irish citizen is going to be treated like that anywhere.\n\n\"Be it in Dubai or anywhere else.\n\n\"Therefore, the State, our embassies and our consular services - who do great work - have to be really, really on our game in terms of these types of cases as and when they arise.\"\n\nFollowing news that Ms Towey was free to return home, Taoiseach Simon Harris said he was delighted with the news.\n\n\"This should never have been in place,\" he said.\n\n\"No Irish citizen should ever have to experience this and I certainly wasn't going to stand for a situation where an Irish citizen who has been the victim of a gender based brutal attack would find themselves in a situation where instead of being supported, they're being subjected to criminal charges.\"\n\n\"Thanks to all the TDs and the Ministers and the Taoiseach, Mary Lou and Claire [Kerrane TD] - they're all amazing and we can't say enough about them.\"", "source": {"uri": "newstalk.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Under Construction                 "}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8218896419", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "14:34:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T14:34:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T14:33:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://time.com/6996852/irish-woman-charged-attempted-suicide-dubai-uae-law/", "title": "Irish Woman Charged With Attempted Suicide in Dubai", "body": "Tori Towey, an Irish woman facing criminal charges for attempting suicide in the United Arab Emirates (UAE), will be allowed to travel home to Ireland.\n\nOn Wednesday, Sinn F\u00e9in leader Mary Lou McDonald shared that the travel ban imposed by the UAE government has been lifted and Towey -- who hails from Boyle, Roscommon -- will travel home to Ireland. \"We await her return and the end of her nightmare,\" McDonald wrote on X (formerly Twitter).\n\nIreland's Department of Foreign Affairs is providing consular assistance to Towey, 28, who has been living in Dubai since April 2023, and working as a flight attendant for Emirates Airlines, according to a post by the Detained in Dubai group, which provides legal help in civil and criminal cases. Towey was charged with consumption of alcohol and attempting suicide, which have historically been criminalized acts in the UAE. Within Detained in Dubai's post about Towey, it is alleged that she was facing domestic abuse from her husband and that he physically attacked her before the incident took place. Her husband has yet to publicly comment on these allegations.\n\nRead More: You can view the CDC's guidance on suicide prevention here.\n\nTowey -- who survived the alleged suicide attempt -- was taken to a local police station, where she had her passport destroyed. Until Wednesday's U-turn decision, she was previously prevented from leaving the country, the D\u00e1il, the lower house of the Oireachtas, Ireland's parliament, heard on Tuesday.\n\nMcDonald told colleagues in the D\u00e1il of Towey's case and called on Taoiseach [Prime Minister] Simon Harris to intervene, The Irish Times reported. \"The system over there, rather than protecting this woman who is an Irish citizen, chose instead to detain her to charge her. She's now under the most incredible stress when I spoke to her this afternoon,\" McDonald said.\n\nMcDonald also said that Towey's mother Caroline had flown to Dubai to be with her daughter.\n\nHarris, who said he was not previously familiar with Towey's case, vowed to offer any support the Irish native requires. The Department of Foreign Affairs has said it is aware of the case and is providing consular assistance to Towey.\n\nTIME has reached out to both the Irish and UAE governments for further information and comment on Towey's case.\n\nRadha Stirling, who founded Detained in Dubai, told BBC News NI she had spoken to Towey on Wednesday morning and remarked on the momentum behind the Irish woman's case.\n\n\"The Irish government is certainly stepping up in record time, we usually don't see them come together that fast,\" Stirling said. \"I'm expecting with that diplomatic push we might be able to get her home even before the court date next week, but of course we have to plan that it could go very badly and she could end up with a prison sentence,\" she added.\n\nTowey's case is set to be heard in court on July 18.\n\nWhile suicide has historically been illegal in the UAE, it was widely reported that 2020 reforms to the Gulf nation's personal status and penal laws would see landmark changes to decriminalize suicide and attempted suicide. While survivors of suicide were rarely prosecuted, the law left them vulnerable to charges and less likely to seek help.\n\nAlcohol consumption was also decriminalized in the same wave of reforms, which aimed to modernize the nation where expats form around 88% of the population.\n\nHowever, per documents from the UAE's Ministry of Justice pertaining to the \"Federal Decree Law No. (15) of 2020,\" those accused of attempting suicide can still be subjected to incarceration of \"no more than six months,\" a fine of \"no more than 5,000 AED\" ($1,361), or both punishments. The court is also given the discretion to order that the detention period be served in a \"healing facility.\" Meanwhile, those accused of aiding an individual attempting suicide are \"subject to the punishment of incarceration.\"", "source": {"uri": "time.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "TIME"}, "authors": [{"uri": "armani_syed@time.com", "name": "Armani Syed", "type": "author", "isAgency": Today, he reiterated this commitment and said her safe return was an \"absolute priority\".\n\nREAD MORE: Taoiseach promises to intervene in case of Irish woman facing charges in Dubai who is 'lucky to be alive'\n\nREAD MORE: Tributes pour in for sports-mad teenager who died after falling from Cliffs of Moher\n\nMs Towey's mother Caroline has travelled to Dubai to be with her daughter, and both women are \"very nervous\" and most anxious to come home, the 28-year-old's aunt told RT\u00c9's Morning Ireland.\n\n\"Tori can't travel so Caroline has to stay with [her], so we're all just very anxious,\" she said.\n\n\"They're very nervous and just can't wait to get home, you know, being in a strange country on their own, it's very hard. We're all just very, very anxious.\n\n\"It's hard to believe that this young woman has been charged with trying to commit suicide... it's very, very hard to believe it.\"\n\nMs Flynn said the whole family is hoping that the phone will ring and they will be told that Caroline and Tori are on a plane on their way home to Ireland. She has been in contact with both women several times a day since the situation emerged.\n\n\"It's really terrible that this has happened to a young woman who was full of life and full of adventure and loved travelling. She's a beautiful young woman,\" Ms Flynn added.\n\n\"They're both trying to keep positive, we're trying to keep positive as well, but it's on your mind constantly, and I'm sure it's on their minds... it's so far away.\"\n\nShe said the family were hoping that a court case in relation to the charges that Ms Towey is facing won't go ahead, and admitted that they didn't know what would happen if it does.\n\nMeanwhile, Radha Stirling of the group Detained in Dubai described the charges as \"bizarre\", given that Dubai had apparently decriminalised attempted suicide in recent years.\n\nShe said the UAE had also promoted the fact that it had decriminalised alcohol consumption, \"so it's quite surprising that they would proceed to... take her to court knowing that she obviously needs help, needs to just go home with her family\".\n\nMs Towey and her mother are currently staying in an Airbnb in Dubai and are free to leave the property. However, it's understood that the authorities have seized Ms Towey's passport and she cannot leave the country.\n\n\"It wouldn't matter if she did have her passport because it will have a travel ban and she wouldn't be able to leave without it. So, if the police drop the case against her, she will be able to get her passport and leave the country,\" Ms Stirling said.\n\nJoin the Irish Mirror's breaking news service on WhatsApp. Click this link to receive breaking news and the latest headlines direct to your phone. "Travel ban lifted for Roscommon woman charged in Dubai with 'assisted suicide', Taoiseach says", "body": "Taoiseach Simon Harris said a travel ban imposed by Dubai authorities on Irish woman Tori Towey, who was reportedly charged with attempted suicide, has been lifted.\n\nThe Irish embassy in UAE will bring her to the airport to travel home as soon as she is ready to do so, the D\u00e1il has heard.\n\nHarris spoke to Towey, the Irish woman who has been charged with attempted suicide and consuming alcohol in the UAE city of Dubai, earlier today.\n\nSpeaking to reporters this morning, the Taoiseach provided an update on Tori's case and said the government is working to bring Towey home.\n\nHe said this is his \"absolute priority\".\n\nSpeaking today, Simon Harris said: \"I've just been informed that the travel ban has been lifted, that the embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go and that the embassy, of course, will continue to follow up on the case, which is still active as of now,\" Mr Harris told the Irish parliament on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nHe thanked the Irish embassy in the United Arab Emirates for its work on the case.\n\nSinn F\u00e9in Now they're charging domestic violence victims with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\"\n\n\"We are calling on Dubai authorities to urgently drop the charges against Tori, remove the travel ban and let her fly home to Ireland with her mother.\n\n\"We are also calling on Ireland's Prime Minister Simon Harris, the head of Foreign Affairs Miche\u00e1l Martin, Ambassador Alison Milton and local TD's, Michael Fitzmaurice, Claire Kerrane & Denis Naughten as well as the UAE's Ambassador to Ireland, H.E. Mohammed Hmoud Hamad Rahma Alshamsi to help bring Tori home.\"\n\nThe 28-year-old Emirates Airlines cabin crew employee, now faces lengthy imprisonment in jails which are notorious for human rights abuses and torture, according to Detained in Dubai.\n\nTori from Boyle in Co Roscommon made the move to Dubai in April 2023 when she was offered a job with Emirates Airlines.\n\nEmirates Airlines gave her time off work to recover after she suffered the injuries at her home, it was added.\n\nThe human rights campaigners said that when replacing her passport, Ms Towey found out there was a travel ban against her but wasn't sure why.\n\nShe arranged to fly home to Ireland but when she arrived at the airport, was told a case against her had been dropped but the travel ban remained.\n\n\"She attended the police station who assured her the travel ban would be lifted but it never happened. She was stuck\".\n\nTori was told nothing could be done and that the cases against her were going to court on the 18th of July, according to Detained in Dubai.\n\n\"The UAE has gone to great public relations efforts to promote alcohol as legal in the country.
