{"uri": "8218268684", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "08:06:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T08:06:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T08:06:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/ireland/2024/07/10/speedy-response-praised-in-case-of-irish-woman-detained-in-dubai-for-attempted-suicide/", "title": "Speedy response praised in case of Irish woman detained in Dubai for 'attempted suicide'", "body": "Detained in Dubai group is hopeful Ireland's diplomatic efforts will see the case dropped and Roscommon woman being allowed to return to Ireland\n\nAn advocacy group has praised the Government for the speed with which it has responded to the case of Co Roscommon woman Tori Towey who has been reportedly charged with attempted suicide and consuming alcohol in Dubai.\n\nMs Towey (28), who moved to the city in the United Arab Emirates where she worked for Emirates Airlines, has been prevented from leaving the country as a result of the charges, the D\u00e1il heard on Tuesday.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs is providing consular assistance to Ms Towey, whose case was first highlighted by Dubai Detained, which said it is representing her and her mother.\n\nCommenting on the Government's response, Detained in Dubai chief executive Radha Stirling said: \"I'm super impressed by Ireland's response, it was so swift.\n\n\"When a government gets behind their citizens, when they go the extra mile, they are successful in getting citizens home,\" she said on Newstalk Breakfast.\n\nMs Stirling, who is in daily contact with Ms Towey, was hopeful that diplomatic efforts by the Department of Foreign Affairs would lead to the case against Ms Towey being dropped and the travel ban lifted so she could return to Ireland.\n\nOn Tuesday, Sinn F\u00e9in leader Mary Lou McDonald told the D\u00e1il that Ms Towey has been the victim of domestic violence and is subject to a travel ban over allegations she illegally consumed alcohol and attempted suicide. Attempted suicide is a crime in the Arab state, carrying a sentence of up to six months.\n\nIn response to questions in the D\u00e1il, Taoiseach Simon Harris said he is prepared to intervene and offer any support required by Ms Towey.\n\nHer case is due to be heard next week, explained Ms Stirling, who went on to outline the background to the case.\n\nShe said Ms Towey had moved to Dubai last year to pursue an aviation career. \"She was working as cabin crew for Emirates Airlines, and she ended up marrying a South African man. Things went south very quickly, and he became physically abusive to her. She went to hospital and had severe injuries,\" Ms Stirling said.\n\n\"After that, there was another assault and she broke free, ran up to the bathroom, and she woke up with paramedics and police over her, and she was taken to the police station and actually charged with, attempted suicide and consuming alcohol.\"\n\nThe situation was \"absurd\" that a woman who had been assaulted would be further abused by the system, Ms Stirling said.\n\n\"We have seen over the years, we've seen rape victims charged with sex outside marriage. We've seen this kind of culture coming from the UAE before. They had made an effort for public relations purposes, they were starting to take women's rights a bit more seriously, victim rights. But it seems like nothing has changed.\n\n\"And this is truly astonishing that someone who's been beaten to the degree that she has bruises all over her body, and now she's being abused by the system itself again. So I find it outrageous,\" Ms Stiring said.\n\n\"And I can see that's why there's so much support out there from Irish citizens, from politicians, from your leaders in your Government. So it's amazing to see people really standing behind her and wanting her home as soon as possible.\n\n\"When it comes to a case like this, it's all about diplomacy. Without the support of the Irish Government, she would be likely to face prison and charges and deportation,\" she said.\n\n\"Various members of the Irish Government have contacted the UAE ambassador to Ireland and of course Ireland's ambassador in the UAE, and they're trying to get those diplomatic talks happening. If that happens, that is the best and fastest way to get her home.\n\n\"She was told she had been charged with alcohol abuse and attempted suicide. Now I validated this with the Department of Public Prosecutions today and it's exactly as they said. So there's been no differences to the charges. And so they are proceeding on that, which is very bizarre since they allegedly decriminalised attempted suicide in the past couple of years and also have been promoting that they have decriminalised alcohol consumption,\" Ms Stirling said.\n\n\"So it's quite surprising that they would proceed to charge, especially her, under these circumstances, and take her to court, knowing that she obviously needs help, needs to just go home with her family.\"\n\nIreland's ambassador to UAE spoke with Ms Towey last night, and she is staying in an Airbnb with her mother Caroline who flew out to support her, according to Ms Stirling.\n\n\"She is exhausted and she's finding it very overwhelming. But at the same time, we're really, really warmed by all of the support that she's been getting. I don't think she expected all of that. I don't think she expected the Irish Government to motivate themselves as quickly. And this is the fastest I've ever seen this happen from a government. So I'm super impressed by Ireland's response.\"\n\n\"We've dealt with many human rights issues like this, and when the government gets behind the citizen and talks to their counterparts, the foreign affairs ministry in the UAE escalates it even to the ruler, Sheikh Mohammed, or the head of the police department and the justice system. When they do that and they go the extra mile rather than just deferring it and pretending they can't do anything, when they actually make the effort, they are successful in getting the citizens home.\"\n\n\"She is very, very much looking forward to coming home and recovering from what's been an extremely terrible, shocking year for her, in fact. So I think she needs to heal. She needs to be around friends and family and the safety of her country,\" Ms Stirling said.\n\nAccording to its website, Detained in Dubai provides confidential legal help in civil and criminal cases and consults with governments internationally on UAE legal issues.", "source": {"uri": "irishtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Irish Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Her passport has been destroyed and a travel ban has been imposed on her.\"\n\nThis morning, the Taoiseach said he doesn't want to say too much given the level of diplomatic activity underway but that he has spoken to both Towey and her mother, Caroline.\n\n\"Tori has been through, in my view, the most horrific situation. The best news ever. We can't say enough about them [TDs and ministers]. The Irish government is amazing.\"\n\nWhen she first heard that Tori was facing criminal charges and had been arrested, Ann and the rest of the family couldn't believe it.\n\n\"It was so out of character for her you know?\" she said. \"The girl loves life, she loves travelling, she loves socialising. This was a normal 28-year-old, having the best life. It was unbelievable.\"\n\nAnn said that the whole experience has been incredibly hard on the family.\n\n\"It's like a nightmare, but you don't wake up from it,\" she said.\n\nIn a statement issued by the Department of Foreign Affairs this afternoon, Tanaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs Micheal Martin said: \"I warmly welcome the news that Tori Towey is now free to return to Ireland.\n\n\"I hope she will be able to do so as soon as possible. This is an outcome that Ambassador Alison Milton, officials, and our Embassy in UAE have been working on for the last while.\n\n\"We are glad for Tori and her family, and we wish her all the very best I have found this whole episode to be grotesque and medieval, in what it says around how women are treated as objects, as possessions.\n\n\"And I find it really distressing that a woman who had suffered such vicious domestic violence wasn't protected, wasn't supported, but instead was actually charged with offences herself.\"\n\nMcDonald said most people would struggle to get their heads around the details of Towey's ordeal in Dubai.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nEarlier, she told the D\u00e1il of how Towey was \"subjected to sustained and brutal domestic violence\" before being charged with attempted suicide and alcohol abuse.\n\n\"This case of Tori, who we will welcome home, highlights the need for Ireland, not alone to get our act together domestically, but also to raise concerns and issues and standards around women's human rights internationally as well,\" McDonald told reporters this afternoon.\n\nWhen asked if Towey's case raises questions for other Irish citizens in Dubai and the UAE, McDonald said there is an obligation on the Irish state to protect Irish citizens.\n\nShe said no woman should suffer what Towey did and said she believes it has been made \"very clear from Ireland\" that \"an Irish citizen, an Irish woman won't be treated like that, not anywhere\".\n\n\"And if that happens, that it will be called out very loudly and very, very clearly,\" McDonald said.\n\nShe added: \"Of course, people are going to travel and travel to Dubai, for recreation, and for other purposes. The point in question here is that when a woman suffers a violent attack, that she is supported, that the perpetrator is the criminal, not the woman.\n\n\"And that message, I think has to be articulated very clearly. And I hope understood, crystal clear by the authorities in Dubai.\"\n\nReaders like you are keeping these stories free for everyone... remain about potential legal outcomes, including the possibility of imprisonment.\n\nSpeaking in the Irish parliament, Sinn Fein leader Mary Lou McDonald condemned the treatment Towey has faced, {"uri": "8218351105", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "09:00:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T09:00:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T09:00:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.newstalk.com/news/tori-towey-outrage-as-truly-astonishing-case-sees-irishwoman-facing-prison-in-dubai-1743468", "title": "Tori Towey: Outrage as 'truly astonishing' case sees Irishwoman facing prison in Dubai", "body": "The charges against Irishwoman Tori Towey in Dubai have been branded 'absurd' and 'truly astonishing' by a human rights group.\n\nThe 28-year-old, who is from Boyle in County Roscommon, was previously detained and has been barred from leaving the United Arab Emirates (UAE).\n\nYesterday, the D\u00e1il heard she is a victim of domestic violence and has been charged with attempting to take her own life.\n\nAfter approaching police in Dubai for help, she was told she was barred from leaving the country and is facing charges of attempted suicide and abuse of alcohol.\n\nShe is now due in court before the end of the month.\n\nThe Detained in Dubai group says Ms Towey has suffered a \"campaign of physical, psychological and financial abuse\" at the hands of her South African husband, who she met through work at Emirates Airlines.\n\nIn the latest incident, the group says, he jammed her arm in a bathroom door, slamming it repeatedly.\n\nIt also says he threatened to kill her before ripping up both of their passports.\n\nThe group says Emirates Airlines fired her husband for \"behavioural issues\".\n\nDetained in Dubai CEO Radha Stirling told Newstalk Breakfast Ms Towey relocated to the UAE just last year.\n\n\"She ended up marrying a South African man - things went south very quickly and he became physically abusive to her,\" she said.\n\n\"She went to hospital and had severe injuries... and then after that there was another assault and she broke free [and] ran up to the bathroom.\n\n\"She woke up with paramedics and police over her and she was taken to the police station and actually charged with attempted suicide and consuming alcohol\".\n\nMs Stirling said Tori Towey's mother has joined her in Dubai.\n\n\"She's since left her husband and she's staying with her mother in an Airbnb safely but she's facing prosecution,\" she said.\n\n\"She's facing a potential prison sentence.\n\n\"There's a travel ban against her - she won't be able to leave Dubai until such time as police decide to drop the case against her.\"\n\nMs Stirling branded the case against Ms Towey as 'absurd'.\n\n\"We have seen over the years rape victims charged with sex outside marriage, we've seen this kind of culture coming from the UAE before,\" she said.\n\n\"They had made an effort to say, for public relations purposes I suppose, that they were starting to take women's rights a bit more seriously [but] it seems like nothing's changed\".\n\n\"This is truly astonishing that someone who's been beaten to the degree that she has - bruises all over her body - and now she's being abused by the system itself again.\n\n\"I find it outrageous\".\n\nMs Stirling added that Ms You can check out at any time. More info\n\nRepresentatives of a 28-year-old air stewardess held in Dubai say she's been freed. Tori Towey, 28, from Ireland, was taken to a police station after she was allegedly attacked, according to reports.\n\nIt resulted in the Emirates Airlines worker having her passport blocked, which prevented her from travelling back home to Ireland. Later this month she was due to face charges in the UAE of alcohol consumption and attempted suicide, reports MirrorOnline.\n\nSince her case was made public, diplomatic pressure was piled on the Middle Eastern state. Now the travel ban imposed by Dubai authorities has been lifted, Ireland's premier has said.\n\nREAD MORE: UK drivers must pay \u00a3120 to enter Europe if they don't have correct number plate\n\nGet breaking news on BirminghamLive WhatsApp, click the link to join\n\nAn update to Ireland's parliament was provided by Taoiseach Simon Harris this afternoon, July 10. He said that Ms Towey would be \"taken to the airport as soon as she is ready\", with the embassy set to follow up the case.\n\nMr Harris said: \"I've just been informed that the travel ban has been lifted, that the embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go and that the embassy of course will continue to follow up on the case, which is still active as of now.\" The Taoiseach also thanked diplomats for their help after the stewardess was initially left without recourse ahead of her expected court appearance this week.\n\nIrish diplomats were working with campaign group Detained in Dubai (DiD) to free Ms Towey, who had moved to the state in 2021 to start work at Emirates. The group said she is \"over the moon\" after learning she would be able to leave the country earlier today. CEO Radha Stirling, who has assisted the stewardess, said she is \"thrilled and relieved\" to return home.\n\nShe said: \"She said she is over the moon and looking forward to getting home to Ireland and seeing the rest of her family. She is a little nervous too because there is that worry that something could happen before she gets on a plane but the overriding feeling is one of joy.\"\n\nMs Towey's family has since thanked the Irish government and campaigners for their help, with her mum Caroline telling the Daily Mail Online the support \"has been incredible\". She said: \"The support from the Irish government and the Irish people has been incredible and we weren't expecting it at all.\n\n\"It's a small country and the politicians are real people. {"uri": "8218440838", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "09:55:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T09:55:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T09:55:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/tori-toweys-family-hopeful-diplomatic-efforts-will-free-roscommon-woman-held-in-dubai-1648059.html", "title": "Tori Towey's family hopeful diplomatic efforts will free Roscommon woman held in Dubai | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "The aunt of Tori Towey, a Roscommon woman who has been banned from leaving Dubai, has said the family are hopeful that diplomatic efforts will lead to the charges against Ms Towey being dropped.\n\nHer aunt, Anne Flynn, told RT\u00c9 radio's Morning Ireland: \"We are just all very, very anxious.\"\n\nMy Towey has been charged with attempted suicide and consuming alcohol in Dubai, a city in the United Arab Emirates (UAE), and has been banned from leaving the country.\n\nMs Flynn said her sister Caroline, Tori's mother, had flown to Dubai to support her daughter.\n\n\"We keep hoping that we'll get word that they're on a plane, on the way home.\n\n\"I don't know will this court case go ahead, or if it does, what will happen?\"\n\nMs Flynn described her niece as a beautiful young women, \"full of life and full of adventure\", adding the situation is \"really terrible\".\n\n\"I've been in touch with them (Tori and Caroline) every day, several times a day, since all this started.\n\n\"They're both trying to keep positive. We're trying to keep positive as well, but it's on your mind constantly, and I'm sure it's on their minds because all the family gets in touch with them.\"\n\nMs Flynn added that with the help of the Irish Government and a human rights advocacy group, Detained in Dubai, which focusses on these kinds of cases, the family are hopeful of a positive outcome.\n\nMeanwhile, the chief executive of Detained in Dubai, Radha Stirling, spoke to Newstalk Breakfast, praising the speedy response of the Irish Government to Ms Towey's case.\n\n\"I'm super impressed by Ireland's response, it was so swift,\" Ms Stirling said.\n\n\"When a government gets behind their citizens, when they go the extra mile, they are successful in getting citizens home.\"\n\nMs Stirling, who said she is in daily contact with Ms Towey, said she is hopeful that diplomatic efforts by the Department of Foreign Affairs would lead to the case against Ms Towey being dropped, allowing her to return to Ireland.\n\nTori's case is due to be held next week, Ms Stirling added, and outlined the background of the case.\n\nMs Stirling explained Ms Towey had moved to Dubai last year to pursue an aviation career.\n\n\"She was working as cabin crew for Emirates Airlines, and she ended up marrying a South African man.\n\n\"Things went south very quickly, and he became physically abusive to her. She went to hospital and had severe injuries.\n\n\"After that, there was another assault, and she broke free, ran up to the bathroom, and she woke up with paramedics and police over her, and she was taken to the police station and actually charged with attempted suicide and consuming alcohol,\" Ms Stirling said.\n\nShe described it as \"absurd\" that a woman who had been assaulted would be further abused by the system.\n\n\"We have seen over the years rape victims charged with sex outside marriage. We've seen this kind of culture coming from the UAE before.\n\nThis is the fastest I've ever seen this happen from a government, so I'm super impressed by Ireland's response\n\n\"They had made an effort for public relations purposes, they were starting to take women's rights a bit more seriously, victim rights, but it seems like nothing has changed, and this is truly astonishing that someone who's been beaten to the degree that she has bruises all over her body, and now she's being abused by the system itself again.\"\n\nMs Stirling added: \"I find it outrageous, and I can see that's why there's so much support out there from Irish citizens, from politicians, from your leaders in your government. It's amazing to see people really standing behind her and wanting her home as soon as possible.\"\n\nMs Stirling said Tori is currently recuperating in rental accommodation with her mother, and spoke to Ireland's ambassador to the UAE on Monday night.\n\n\"She is exhausted, and she's finding it very overwhelming, but at the same time, we're really, really warmed by all of the support that she's been getting,\" Ms Stirling said.\n\n\"I don't think she expected all of that. I don't think she expected the Irish Government to motivate themselves as quickly, and this is the fastest I've ever seen this happen from a government, so I'm super impressed by Ireland's response.\n\n\"We've dealt with many human rights issues like this, and when the government gets behind the citizen and talks to their counterparts, the Foreign Affairs Ministry in the UAE escalates it even to the ruler, Sheikh Mohammed, or the head of the police department and the justice system.\n\n\"When they do that, and they go the extra mile, rather than just deferring it and pretending they can't do anything, when they actually make the effort, they are successful in getting the citizens home.\"\n\nMs Stirling added: \"She is very, very much looking forward to coming home and recovering from what's been an extremely terrible, shocking year for her, in fact. So I think she needs to heal. She needs to be around friends and family and the safety of her country.\"", "source": {"uri": "breakingnews.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Breaking News.ie"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": as Irishwoman can leave Dubai", "body": "Tori Towey's aunt has welcomed the announcement that she is free to leave Dubai as \"the best news ever\".\n\nThe 28-year-old Roscommon woman was previously own life.\n\nAfter approaching police in Dubai for help, she was told she was barred from leaving the country and is facing charges of attempted suicide and abuse of alcohol.\n\nSpeaking in the D\u00e1il earlier today Taoiseach Simon Harris said the travel ban has now been lifted and embassy staff would bring her to the airport \"as soon as she is ready to go\".\n\nMr Harris said the ban \"should never have been in place\".\n\n\"No Irish citizen should ever have to experience this and I certainly wasn't going to stand for a situation where an Irish citizen - who has been the victim of {"uri": "8218521108", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "10:43:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T10:43:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T10:42:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.paddleyourownkanoo.com/2024/07/10/emirates-flight-attendant-faces-jail-for-attempting-to-take-her-own-after-her-husband-brutally-beat-and-tortured-her/", "title": "Emirates Flight Attendant Faces Jail For Attempting to Take Her Own After Her Husband Brutally Beat and Tortured Her", "body": "An Emirates flight attendant from Ireland faces the threat of being imprisoned in a notorious Dubai jail after being charged with attempting to take her own life after she was allegedly brutally beaten and tortured by her South African husband, who police let go.\n\n28-year-old Tori Towey from Boyle in Co Roscommon, Ireland, is now stuck in Dubai, unable to return home after the local authorities slapped her with a travel ban as prosecutors pursue charges of consuming alcohol and suicide, which is still classed as a crime under the UAE's opaque penal code.\n\nTori is now being helped by the campaign group Detained in Dubai, which helps expats and tourists caught up in Dubai's confusing legal web. Radha Stirling, the CEO of Detained in Dubai has called on prosecutors to drop the charges and let Tori return home so that she can be with her family.\n\nThe Irish flight attendant moved to Dubai in April 2023 when she landed a coveted job with Emirates and quickly fell in love with a coworker from South Africa. After a whirlwind romance, the pair got married, but it didn't take long for the relationship to turn sour.\n\nThings started to come to head after a night out at McCaffreys Pub, a popular place for a night out for Emirates crew, where Tori's husband had to be restrained by security staff after he started to cause 'havoc'.\n\nPolice were called but Tori's husband was simply sent home without any further intervention. Tori was ordered to go home with him.\n\nOnce they got home, it's alleged that Tori's husband started to brutally beat her, kicking and biting her, threatening her with a knife and repeatedly slamming her arm in a bathroom door in an attempt to break it.\n\nStirling says Tori's husband threatened to kill her and tore up both of their passports before neighbours came to the rescue and got Tori to a hospital in the back of an ambulance.\n\nTori filed a police report against her husband and Emirates gave her some time off work to allow her to recover. During this time, Tori went to replace her passport but discovered that she had been slapped with a travel ban.\n\nTori attempted to fly home to Ireland but was unable to leave due to the travel ban and she eventually returned home to her husband. The first few days were peaceful but after drinking some wine, Tori's husband suddenly accused her of having an affair.\n\nFearing that he would kill her, Tori ran to the bathroom and attempted to take her own life. The next thing she remembers is waking up in an ambulance.\n\nBut instead of taking her to a hospital, Tori was transported to the infamous Al Barsha police station where she was held for several hours. She has since been charged with consuming alcohol and attempted suicide. Her case is due to be heard in court on July 18.\n\n\"Tori's experience is nothing short of tragic and quite frankly, she is lucky to be alive,\" Stirling said after the story came to light. \"It's amazing that authorities did not intervene for Tori's protection, given the state her body was in when she was hospitalised the first time.\"\n\nStirling added: \"Emirates Airlines, the Irish Embassy and the UAE medical and police services could certainly have done more to help Tori.\"\n\n\"Worse than failing her, authorities in Dubai actually travel-banned her and kept her in the country when she was trying to get away. They put her in a hopeless position resulting in her attempt to kill herself to escape the imminent threat of assault and likely murder\".\n\nTori's family hopes that by taking her story public, the Dubai authorities will bow to international pressure drop the charges against her and allow her to return home.\n\nThe Irish embassy is now providing consular assistance and officials have now arranged a lawyer for Tori after a high-level political intervention.\n\nIn 2020, an Emirates crew member from Britain was held for months in Dubai after being charged with possession of cannabis. Derrin Crawford was arrested after going on a date with a new acquaintance and going back to his apartment which was subsequently raided by police.\n\nAt the time, Detained in Dubai said Derrin was simply in the wrong place at the wrong time.\n\nLocal media in the UAE have not reported Tori's ordeal.", "source": {"uri": "paddleyourownkanoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Paddle Your Own {"uri": "8218368620", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "09:11:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T09:11:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T09:11:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://en.protothema.gr/2024/07/10/irish-flight-attendant-beaten-by-her-husband-tried-to-commit-suicide-and-now-faces-prosecution-in-dubai/", "title": "Irish flight attendant beaten by her husband, tried to commit suicide and now faces prosecution in Dubai - ProtoThema English", "body": "The 28-year-old is stranded in the emirate after being banned from leaving the country - The Irish Prime Minister has pledged to intervene to resolve this \"appalling\" case\n\nAn Irish flight attendant who attempted suicide after consuming a large amount of alcohol while in the Arab emirate has been \"trapped\" in Dubai and has been prosecuted and banned from leaving the country.\n\nAccording to the Daily Mail, 28-year-old Tori Tawi, who works for Emirates Airlines in the UAE, claims she was the victim of domestic violence in her home. A spokesperson for the legal group Detained in Dubai (DiD) revealed that the young woman's South African husband chased her with a knife and punched her before slamming her hand into the bathroom door, trying to break it. After the attack, Taui's husband, who also worked for Emirates Airline, was fired from his job.\n\nPsychologically affected by the attack, which left her body covered in cuts and bruises, the Irish flight attendant became drunk and tried to end her life. Fortunately, she did not succeed, but was subsequently taken to the local police station, where she was informed that she would be prosecuted for drinking and attempted suicide. Since then, the 28-year-old has been desperately trying to find a way to return home as the local authorities have blocked her passport and she cannot travel.\n\nSpeaking through the DiD group, which is assisting the family, Taui said: \"I don't know what will happen in court next week. I desperately want to go back to Ireland and put all this behind me. I ask the Irish Prime Minister to help us.\" According to the support group, the girl is at risk of ending up incarcerated in a prison known for \"human rights abuses and torture\".\n\nIrish Prime Minister Simon Harris said he would intervene to find a solution to this \"appalling\" case, following a question raised by Sinn Fein leader Mary Lou MacDonald in the Irish parliament on Tuesday afternoon. Mr Harris thanked Ms McDonald for bringing the problem to his attention and pledged to work with the MP to provide help for their young compatriot.\n\nMacDonald said she had spoken to Taui and that the 28-year-old's mother had travelled to Dubai to be with her. \"Tori just wants to go home. She is a woman from Roscommon and she wants to come home,\" he said.\n\nSpeaking to Sky News, Tori's aunt, Anne Flynn, said the girl is trying to build up her courage. \"It's a very stressful situation for the whole family,\" she said, describing her niece as \"a beautiful young woman\" who \"loves to have fun and travel\".\n\n\"She was hired into her dream job at Emirates and could continue to travel as a flight attendant. {"uri": "8218831790", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:53:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:53:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:53:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/seven-strict-dubai-laws-you-33210932", "title": "strict Dubai laws you may not know as flight attendant arrested", "body": "Stefano and Nathalie opened up about the eye-watering penalties you could face in Dubai\n\nTwo travel vloggers have issued a warning over possibly unknown infractions that could land you a hefty fine or even a prison sentence in Dubai.\n\nStefano and Nathalie of Sense the Lens, who lived in the United Arab Emirates nation for more than five years, opened up last year about the eye-watering penalties you could face for a series of practices that are fairly common in the UK.\n\nIt comes after flight attendant Tori Towey, 28, from Co Roscommon in Ireland, was reportedly facing prison in Dubai. Ms Towey was charged with attempted suicide and alcohol abuse after being attacked, Irish parliamentarians were told.\n\nTori wanted to leave following hospital treatment for bruises and other injuries, according to activists, but she was prevented from doing so. Dubai authorities also banned her from leaving the state, the Dail chamber heard.\n\nDetained in Dubai has said she could face a lengthy jail sentence in a prison known for \"human rights abuses and torture\", highlighting the legal pitfalls that Brits potentially experience when moving to Dubai.\n\nIrish premier Simon Harris has now said a travel ban imposed by Dubai authorities has been lifted. He said: \"I've just been informed that the travel ban has been lifted, that the embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go, and that the embassy of course will continue to follow up on the case, which is still active as of now.\"\n\nMr Harris said he spoke to Ms Towey and her mother Caroline shortly after the update, and she \"will soon be home\".\n\nTravel vloggers Stefano and Nathalie warned they were oblivious to some of the laws as they enjoyed their lives in Dubai, with Stefano saying: \"So we got to know things that were normal for us but that could actually have gotten us in jail.\"\n\nHere are seven things you probably didn't know were illegal in Dubai, according to Sense the Lens:\n\n1. Having a dirty car in public spaces - fine of up to 500 dirhams\n\nStefano said the reason for this law is because Dubai's authorities believe that a \"dirty car will give a bad image of Dubai\" and dirt can make it difficult for the police to identify a vehicle.\n\n2. Cleaning your dirty car - fine of up to 500 dirhams\n\nDespite the previous law, you can face a fine for cleaning your own car in public because it will \"make the streets dirty\" and \"give a bad image of Dubai\", according to the YouTuber.\n\n3. Spreading rumours and fake news - one year in prison and a fine of up to 100,000 dirhams\n\nAccording to Gulf News, the law applies to \"anyone who uses the internet to publish, circulate or spread false news, rumours or misleading information, contrary to the news published by official sources\".\n\n4. Carrying poppy seeds - up to 20 years in prison\n\nPoppy seeds (which Stefano says are considered a drug in Dubai), posta or khas khas are banned throughout the UAE, reports the Economic Times.\n\n5. Swearing or bad gestures - fine of up to 500,000 dirhams\n\nThe GOV website says swearing and rude gestures are considered obscene acts and are illegal in the UAE, potentially leading to prison and deportation.\n\n6. Checking other people's phones -fine of between 50,000 and 100,000 dirhams\n\nAccording to Gulf News, the fine could apply if someone accessed the information using a password \"obtained without permission\"\n\n7. Fundraising without a licence - imprisonment and a fine of between 200,000 and 500,000 dirhams\n\nIn this particularly strict rule, anyone who runs a website or publishes information online or \"through any information technology\" to promote the collection of donations without a licence could face legal consequences.\n\nThe Department of Foreign Affairs said it was, along with Ireland's embassy in the UAE, providing \"ongoing consular assistance\" in the Ms Towey's case.\n\n\"The Irish ambassador to the UAE is in regular contact with our citizen (including this morning). The embassy is also engaging with all the relevant authorities in UAE on the case,\" the department told the PA news agency.\n\n\"Officials will continue to provide advice and consular assistance.\"", {"uri": "8218460640", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "10:07:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T10:07:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T10:06:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.43529412150383, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/abroad/2024/07/10/have-your-say-what-has-been-your-experience-of-living-in-dubai/", "title": "Have your say: What has been your experience of living in Dubai?", "body": "We would like to hear from Irish people who have lived and worked in Dubai\n\nThere has been much discussion of the experience of Irish expats living in Dubai, in light of the case of Tori Towey - the Irishwoman who has been prevented from leaving the country over allegations she illegally consumed alcohol and attempted suicide.\n\nWith around 10,000 Irish people living and working in Dubai, we'd like to hear what your experience has been of the state. Have you found some parts of society to be restrictive? Have you experienced or witnessed mistreatment of women? How has your experience been of the country's alcohol laws? Have you noticed many changes over the years in laws becoming more liberal?\n\nIf you have worked in Dubai, what were the differences between how your profession operated there and in Ireland?\n\nYou can let us know what you think using the form below. Please limit your submissions to 400 words or less. Please include a phone number for verification purposes only. {"uri": "8219378852", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "21:04:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T21:04:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T21:04:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.thesun.ie/news/13378508/tori-towey-dubai-attack-husband-breaks-silence-release/", "title": "Air hostess held in Dubai after attack by husband breaks silence on release", "body": "Tori's family are now looking forward to starting 'a new chapter with her'\n\nAN Irish victim of domestic violence who was detained by Dubai cops and charged with \"attempted suicide\" has spoken of her relief after being allowed to return home.\n\nTori Towey, 28, was facing criminal charges, including attempting suicide and consuming alcohol, following a brutal attack by her husband at their home in the United Arab Emirates.\n\nThe desperate Emirates Airlines flight attendant, from Boyle, Co Roscommon, pleaded for help from the Irish Government after she was taken to a police station and her passport blocked from use -- despite her suffering a campaign of domestic abuse.\n\nBut following a diplomatic intervention from Ireland, the shocking travel ban imposed on Tori by Dubai authorities was today lifted, allowing her to fly home.\n\nTraumatised Tori told the Irish Sun she was \"totally overwhelmed\" by the huge outpouring of support from Irish citizens amid her ordeal.\n\nAnd she declared: \"Thank you for the support. I really appreciate it.\"\n\nFrantic Tori had been facing jail time in Dubai after being charged over a bid to take her own life following the attack by her husband.\n\nThe young woman suffered severe bruising and other injuries.\n\nBut in the wake of the horrific domestic abuse, authorities in Dubai instead charged the assault victim with attempted suicide and alcohol consumption.\n\nAnd rather than helping her return to Ireland, Tori was left trapped in Dubai after she was hit with a travel ban ahead of a scheduled court showdown next week.\n\nShe had been forced to stay in a rented apartment in Dubai with mum Caroline, who flew out to support her daughter.\n\nWith Tori due before court on the criminal charges next week, the worried Towey family had urged the Irish Government to intervene and help get her home to Ireland.\n\nAnd in a major development on Wednesday, Taoiseach Simon Harris revealed that Dubai's travel ban on Ms Towey had been lifted.\n\nDelivering an update in \"real time\" in the Dail, Harris said: \"I've just been informed that the travel ban has been lifted, that the embassy will take Tori to the airport as soon as she is ready to go.\"\n\nHarris thanked the Irish embassy in the UAE for its work on the case, describing Tori's ordeal as \"unimaginable\".\n\nHe said: \"A woman who has been a victim of a brutal attack found herself waking up not in hospital, but in a police station.\"\n\nThe Taoiseach issued a special message of thanks to our embassy for its behind-the-scenes work on the case to get Tori free.\n\nCrusading lawyer and human rights campaigner Radha Stirling had first highlighted Tori's plight.\n\nStirling today confirmed police in the UAE have now withdrawn the charges against Ms Towey and lifted the travel ban.\n\nAnd the CEO of advocacy group Detained in Dubai told how the Roscommon native was \"relieved and overjoyed\". Stirling told The Irish Sun: \"Tori is absolutely over the moon.\n\n\"She is so grateful to the support of the Irish people, the media and the Irish Government, who I must commend for their swift response.\n\n\"Diplomatic conversations happened and developed quickly behind closed doors.\n\n\"There was a lot of push by Ireland over the past couple of days.\n\n\"Tori has been really overwhelmed in a good way with all the support she has received.\n\n\"She has been overwhelmed with how much genuine support she has got from Irish citizens, who had been ringing up their own local representatives saying 'please help this woman'.\n\n\"Tori has been really, really amazed at the support from Irish people.\n\n\"And the Irish Government has really stepped in and responded tremendously quickly.\n\n\"It has felt like Ireland has come together and wrapped their arms around Tori.\n\n\"It really hit home with Dubai and forced them to make this decision (letting Tori return to Ireland).\n\n\"This should never have happened to Tori in the first place.\n\n\"She is a victim, it was outrageous that the UAE acted this way towards a woman, a victim of domestic violence.\"\n\nAll charges against Tori have been dropped and the case closed.\n\nTori's overjoyed relatives in Roscommon revealed they were planning a big homecoming party for their girl.\n\nHer aunt, Ann Flynn, beamed: \"It's amazing, you can't believe the relief. But it's amazing. The best news ever.\"\n\nAnd she praised both Government and opposition TDs for the \"amazing\" support they had given to their crisis-hit family.\n\nAnn told how her stressed niece was facing \"no light at the end of the tunnel\" until dramatic diplomatic interventions from Ireland.\n\nTori's family are now looking forward to starting \"a new chapter with her\".\n\nAnn, who spoke to Tori's mum Caroline on the phone after news broke that travel ban had been lifted, said: \"Life starts again.\n\n\"It's all our Christmases come together, we're so excited and can't wait to get the two home.\"\n\nAnother aunt, Trish Beirne, called it \"great news\" that Tori was coming home and also paid tribute to friends in the Roscommon area who had offered support to the family.\n\nTrish said: \"Until the chips are down you don't realise how good people are.\"\n\nSinn Fein president Mary Lou McDonald had raised the matter in the Dail on Tuesday, telling how Tori was the victim of domestic violence at the hands of her husband.\n\nMcDonald on Wednesday welcomed news of a breakthrough on Ms Towey's travel ban while blasting the \"medieval, grotesque treatment of women\" in the UAE.\n\nMcDonald said: \"I want to thank everyone for the huge support shown to Tori and Caroline over the last number of days.\n\n\"The ordeal Tori has been subjected to has been horrendous.\n\n\"I know that Tori and her mum are deeply grateful for the solidarity and good will that has been shown towards them across Ireland. We now await their safe return to Ireland and to Roscommon.\"\n\nSinn Fein Roscommon-Galway TD Claire Kerrane also pressed Micheal Martin for help to resolve Tori's \"absolutely frightening\" situation.\n\nTanaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs Martin paid tribute to the Irish Ambassador to the UAE, Alison Milton, for her role in solving the matter.\n\nThe Tanaiste told how Ms Milton and her team in the UAE had opened up \"good channels of communication and engagement\" with the Dubai authorities that had facilitated the lifting of the travel ban against Ms Towey.", "source":
